TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Census
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned shows:
That the current practice of destroying the Census is denying future generations an invaluable and irreplaceable resource of data on medical, historical, social, scientific, and demographic factors.
Your Petitioners request that the Senate should:

Request the Government to review its current policy of destroying the Census; and support a proposal to retain the census forms for release for specific research purposes in either 70 or 100 years time.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium Exports to Indonesia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled the petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That the export of uranium extends the nuclear cycle which fuels the development of nuclear weapons;
That no satisfactory means of dealing with nuclear waste has yet been devised;
That the mining and exporting of Australian uranium contributes to the nuclear fuel cycle.
Your Petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Government:
To withdraw from any treaty or agreement with Indonesia which will lead to the export of uranium to that country;
To foster research and development of safe and sustainable energy generation technologies in Australia and Indonesia;
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Women: Pension Age
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned strongly opposes the increase in the Pension age for women from 60 to 65 years.
Your Petitioners ask that the Senate take action to reverse this decision.

Motion (by Senator Schacht)—by leave—proposed:

Senator Panizza—Mr President, I thought we might have some explanation from the minister as to why he wants these exempted from the cut-off motion.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Panizza for inviting the government to indicate the reason that this motion has been moved. I believe that the Prawn Boat Levy Bill 1994 was introduced into the House of Representatives on 7 December 1994 and the Prawn Export Charge Bill 1994 was introduced into the House of Representatives on 8 December 1994.

PARA.TAB: I think nearly all honourable senators would agree, in relation to both these bills, that they are important pieces of legislation. But I think I can say very honestly and frankly to the Senate that they are considered to be non-controversial. I think there is an expectation that they will receive overwhelming support from the chamber. I think these two bills, or I should say three bills—indeed, how could I have forgotten the Prawn Export Promotion Bill of 1994, which I think also was introduced on 8 December last year—could be fairly described as bills that had been caught up in the cut-off motion which was—

TALK.START.PARA: —Has it got anything to do with promoting your government?

—I hope so. This is a matter where an unexpected consequence of the cut-off motion was to see these three particular bills caught up. I would seek the Senate's support for the motion, that has been moved by Senator Schacht, to allow these three important pieces of legislation to be dealt with outside the constraints that are placed upon it by the order of the Senate of 29 November 1994.

—I do not suggest that the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, Senator Faulkner, is attempting to come the raw prawn with the Senate on these particular measures, but I do feel that he is trying to use these in an attempt to suggest to the Senate that this is an unintended consequence of the November decision. It is not an unintended consequence.

PARA.TAB: It was specifically decided, in Senator Chamarette's motion last November, that there should be a situation where legislation that is introduced in one session should not be debated until the next session. That is to say, legislation introduced in the Senate in one session will not be debated until the next session of the Senate. Let us have no unders and overs about that; that was perfectly clear. It is unfair for the minister to come in here and use this occasion every time to suggest that this is an unintended consequence. It was not an unintended consequence.

As I understand it, Senator Chamarette made perfectly clear—Senator Chamarette can talk for herself—the reason that she moved that motion and it was all part of keeping the government honest, particularly Senator Evans, which is a difficult task, from my experience. I am not suggesting that he is dishonest in the pejorative sense; I am talking about politically.

I support this motion because of the matters that Senator Faulkner has outlined about the legislation. It is non-controversial, it has the full support of everybody concerned and there is no reason why, in the circumstances, it should not be exempted from the cut-off motion. But let us not use these occasions as unintended consequences of the motion moved by Senator Chamarette and adopted by this chamber. If the minister is suggesting that because these bills were introduced into the House of Representatives at the end of the session—one of them was introduced on the last day of the session—they should be able to be debated in the Senate the next session, that is quite contrary to the spirit of the Chamarette motion.

I remind the Senate that if that were the case the government could come in with 50 packages of bills on the last day that the House of Representatives meets at the end of this month or in early April, dump them on the table in the House of Representatives, not debate them until May and expect us to deal with them in May. That is not what the motion meant at all. For the other reasons that Minister Faulkner has given, I support the motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to speak at any length, but I wish to endorse the comments made by Senator Harradine. This in a sense can be seen as a Trojan Horse. I think it is very important that we put on the record—certainly I do so on behalf of the opposition—that we do not accept that this should be treated as a precedent. Any bills that the government wishes to have exemption for must be treated as a special case.

PARA.TAB: The fact that we have agreed in these circumstances to have the legislation come forward at lunchtime as non-controversial and important matters should not be read by the government that it will automatically be able to use this as an example in the future for why any other bills should be exempted. I have no quibble with anything that Senator Harradine has said, and the government should be warned not to accept this as a right and a precedent for the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to delay the Senate but I want briefly to concur with the remarks that have already been made. I think Senator Harradine explained it perfectly clearly that the reason for the cut-off motion was two-fold. It was to allow time for scrutiny, so that when a bill is introduced in one session it is not debated until the next and we can consult the community, look at the legislation and do our job in the Senate. The second reason was to prevent the abuse of the parliamentary process that goes on when there is a log jam of legislation passed on the final day. We are getting pretty close to that and I believe the government's amendment to that procedural motion is being deferred to the first day of the next sitting.

PARA.TAB: I believe that we are actually allowing the log jam in the last session of the House of Representatives to cause a log jam in the Senate in the last couple of weeks of this session. I believe the procedural motion should be enforced so that not only does the Senate have adequate time for scrutiny but also it conducts its business in an orderly fashion and is not pushed into the same kind of log jam as occurred in the House of Representatives. I do not have any objections to the exemptions to allow these bills to be dealt with today. I think it is perfectly appropriate that the Senate agree that those bills should come on. That does not mean that we agree that the principle of introducing a bill in one session and debating it the next is not a valid one.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

Motion (by Senator Chapman)—as amended by leave—proposed:
That:

PROCTEXT.PARA: (1)A select committee, to be known as the Select Committee on the Dangers of Radioactive Waste, be appointed to inquire into and report, on or before the last sitting day of December 1995, on the following matters:

PARA.TAB: (a)the extent to which radioactive waste is being produced, stored, transported, treated and disposed of in Australia;

(b)the nature, efficiency and effectiveness of the administration, monitoring and control of such production, storage, transport, treatment and disposal, and whether these are adequate to protect the public interest; and
(c)what existing guidelines and legislation require revision by government to better protect the future public interest in an area of intrinsic potential danger to public health and the environment.

PROCTEXT.PARA: (2)In considering these terms of reference the committee is to take into account, and where necessary report on, the following issues:

PARA.TAB: (a)the effectiveness and extent of application, on a national basis, of the following Codes of Practice formulated and approved under the Environment Protection (Nuclear Codes) Act 1978 for regulating or controlling nuclear activities in Australia:

TAB.TAB: (i)the Code of Practice for the Safe Transport of Radioactive Substances (1990),
(ii)the National Health and Medical Research Council Code of Practice for the Near-Surface Disposal of Radioactive Waste in Australia (1992),
(iii)the National Health and Medical Research Council Code of Practice for the Disposal of Radioactive Waste by the User (1985), and
(iv)any related or proposed Code of Practice for regulating or controlling nuclear activities (but not including uranium mining and milling);

PARA.TAB: (b)the suitability of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 in protecting the environment and fostering consultation with the community in relation to the handling, transportation and storage of radioactive waste;
(c)the scope for independent inspection or environmental audit of sites used for the storage of radioactive waste;

(d)the significance of the expanded role for the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (ANSTO) in conditioning, managing and storing radioactive waste under the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation Act 1987 and Regulations as amended;
(e)the adequacy of funding for research in, and the training available in Australia for skilled personnel involved in, the handling, transport, storage and security of radioactive waste;
(f)the location, amount, state, age and type of radioactive waste in Australia (excluding material from uranium mining and milling);

(g)the general suitability of each existing location for the storage of radioactive waste including the consideration of such factors as population density, stability of the site in geological and hydrogeological terms, surface flooding and overall environmental significance;

(h)whether each existing location for the storage of radioactive waste has a description to indicate the likely period of duration for its use as a storage site and whether any program or plan exists for future use of the site together with a general assessment of the likely stability of existing methods of storage;

(i)the state of planning and timing for the development of a national repository for the storage of radioactive waste and the likely legislative powers and functions to be vested in the relevant government or non-government agency responsible for the proposed repository;

(j)the extent to which the establishment of a permanent national repository will result in the removal of radioactive waste from storage in areas generally considered to be unsuitable for reasons such as population density, site stability and other relevant factors;
(k)existing and, where known, future arrangements for the permanent or temporary storage of intermediate and high level radioactive waste;
(l)Australia's current and, where known, future obligations under international treaties relevant to nuclear activities;
(m)the extent of Australia's imports and exports of radioactive material (excluding uranium mining), and the adequacy of legislative controls for such material;
(n)the implications of any user-pays system for the management, storage and disposal of radioactive waste;
(o)measures taken by readioactive waste producers to avoid and/or minimise the creation of radioactive waste arising from their activities (but not including uranium mining and milling); and
(p)identification of waste avoidance and/or minimisation procedures that could be followed by these producers (but not including uranium mining and milling).

PROCTEXT.PARA: (3)The committee consist of seven senators:

PARA.TAB: (a)two nominated by the Leader of the Government in the Senate;
(b)three nominated by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate;
(c)one nominated by the Leader of the Australian Democrats; and
(d)one nominated by the Greens (WA) or Senator Harradine or Senator Devereux.

PROCTEXT.PARA: (4)The committee may proceed to the dispatch of business notwithstanding that all members have not been duly nominated and appointed and notwithstanding any vacancy.
(5)(a)The chair of the committee be elected by the members of the committee from the opposition members of the committee.

PARA.TAB: (b)In the absence of agreement on the selection of a chair, duly notified to the President, the allocation of the chair be determined by the Senate.
(c)The deputy chair of the committee be elected by the committee from the members of the committee immediately after the election of the chair.
(d)The deputy chair act as chair when there is no chair or the chair is not present at a meeting.
(e)In the event of the votes on any question before the committee being equally divided, the chair, or the deputy chair when acting as chair, have a casting vote.

PROCTEXT.PARA: (6)The quorum of the committee be four members.

(7)The committee and any subcommittee have power to send for and examine persons and documents, to move from place to place and to sit in public or in private, notwithstanding any prorogation of the Parliament or dissolution of the House of Representatives.

(8)The committee have power to appoint subcommittees consisting of three or more of its members, and to refer to any such subcommittee any of the matters which the committee is empowered to consider, and that the quorum of a subcommittee be a majority of the senators appointed to the subcommittee.
(9)Without limiting its power to pass procedural or other resolutions that are not inconsistent with this paragraph or these terms of reference, the committee observe the following procedures:

TAB.TAB: (a)As a general principle, evidence be invited in the first instance in the form of written submissions and following examination of submissions, the committee decide which witnesses are to be called for examination.

PARA.TAB: (b)Subject to any contrary order in relation to a particular submission, the submission to the committee by a person of a statement relating to the inquiry be deemed to be the giving of evidence before the committee by that person in accordance with that statement.
(c)Evidence be heard in public session except in instances where the committee or a subcommittee resolves to hear evidence in camera.
(d)The chair be authorised to make statements to the media on behalf of the committee concerning its activities.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Broadcasts and re-broadcasts of public proceedings

PARA.TAB: (e)The recording, broadcasting and re-broadcasting of public proceedings is authorised in accordance with the rules contained in the order of the Senate of 23 August 1990, as varied by the Senate from time to time, concerning the broadcasting of committee proceedings.
(f)The secretary is authorised to supply, for correction, copies of proof reports of both public and in camera proceedings to the witnesses whose evidence appears in those reports.
(g)Subject to any contrary order in relation to a particular submission, each document submitted to the committee be published.
(h)Subject to any contrary order, evidence which adversely reflects on a person, be forwarded to that person inviting their response.

PROCTEXT.PARA: (10)(a)The terms of reference of the inquiry be appropriately advertised in the media.

PARA.TAB: (b)Written submissions be sought and examined by the committee and oral evidence be heard.

PROCTEXT.PARA: (11)The committee be provided with all necessary staff, facilities and resources and be empowered to appoint persons with specialist knowledge for the purposes of the committee, with the approval of the President.
(12)The committee be empowered to print from day to day such documents and evidence as may be ordered by it, and a daily Hansard be published of such proceedings as take place in public.

(13)The committee may report from time to time its proceedings and evidence taken or any interim conclusions or recommendations arising from its inquiry, and may make regular reports on the progress of its proceedings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—It is not the government's intention to waste a great deal of the Senate's time by refusing formality for this proposal because the government is aware that a majority of senators in the chamber support this motion. We make it clear that the government opposes this motion to establish a select committee. I understand one of my colleagues has had some informal discussions with Senator Chapman and there is an acceptance that we believe it will be appropriate for me to seek leave to incorporate a statement in relation to the strong case the government has for opposing this motion. I seek leave to incorporate that statement in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: A Select Committee on the Dangers of Radioactive waste.
The Government opposes the motion to establish a select committee on the dangers of radioactive waste;
not because the Government believes the issue in question is unimportant,
but because the work of the committee will merely duplicate activity already being carried out on this important matter
Commonwealth, State and Territory governments are all responsible for overseeing aspects of the management of radioactive wastes produced within their jurisdictions
States/Territories have developed legislation and regulations covering the management of radioactive wastes generated—within their jurisdiction

the proposed terms of reference of the committee will require information to be obtained from relevant Departments within the States and Territories regarding their radioactive waste management activities and legislation relating to this subject.
Within the Commonwealth responsibility for radioactive waste management issues crosses a number of portfolios:

operational issue, such as user disposal, storage and transport are the responsibility of the action Department, responsibility for Codes of Practice lies with the Minister for Health and responsibility for establishing a national near-surface repository and general radioactive waste policy falls within the Primary Industries and Energy portfolio responsibility.
The Commonwealth Government is establishing an Australian Institute for Radiation Protection (AIRP) which will address many of the matters proposed for consideration by the Committee
the AIRP will have responsibility for reviewing and updating Codes of Practice relating to radioactive waste management
legislation will be introduced by the Minister for Health and Community Services in the next sittings of Parliament

The terms of reference as presently drafted are very broad and cover all radioactive wastes produced in Australia including uranium mining and milling wastes and wastes suitable for disposal by the user under the Code of Practice for Disposal of Radioactive Waste by the User (1985).

A Commonwealth/State Consultative Committee established in 198(:), with the objective of developing coordinated policies for managing Australia's radioactive waste, found that most of the radioactive waste generated in Australia is suitable for near-surface disposal at specially selected sites but noted that these facilities had yet to be developed. In 1985 the Committee recommended a national program for locating a disposal facility for this type of waste
this committee did not consider the management of wastes not suitable for near-surface disposal an immediate priority due to its small quantity.

Following establishment of a national repository for radioactive wastes suitable for near-surface disposal interim storage facilities will still be required within each State/Territory pending their transfer to the repository.

Progress towards identification of a national near-surface repository may need to be delayed until the proposed Select Committee reports at the end of 1995 to ensure that the project does not pre-empt the Committee's findings.

In relation to the TOR concerning `risk of Australia becoming an international dumping ground for radioactive waste' it has been made quite clear in response to Parliamentary Questions and Ministerial statements that Australian Government policy prohibits the importation of the radioactive wastes from other countries absolutely.
For these reasons, the Government opposes the formation of the proposed committee

TALK.START.PARA: —I make clear the government's position of opposition to this motion. At this point we do not wish to waste the time of the Senate, given that, unfortunately, there is majority support for the establishment of this select committee.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I hope it has been made abundantly clear that there were no discourtesies intended from our side of the chamber.
—It would be a change.
—We do not ever consciously seek to snub you on these matters and we will continue to maintain the propriety.
—I'm pleased to hear it's all unconscious.
—I will have to start carrying on if Senator Faulkner is not careful.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice and at the request of the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Hill, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Hill moving a motion relating to the conduct of the business of the Senate, namely a motion to give precedence to general business notice of motion No. 1402 standing in the name of Senator Alston for this day, relating to media ownership.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a very important motion because it seeks to put both the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and Mr Lee in a position of demonstrating to the Australian public that either they have evidence to support the outrageous allegations they have been making over the last couple of weeks or they are exposed stark naked as not having any evidence but nonetheless are prepared to make these outrageous allegations. Mr Lee last night on television was reduced to saying that the government does not have any evidence but it would like the opposition to give the government its evidence. In other words, it is now a matter for us to somehow provide material on which the government would want to rely.

PARA.TAB: Yesterday Senator Gareth Evans went through a very tawdry and tortuous process to try to demonstrate that what was on the public record somehow constituted evidence of a secret deal. I think that is the longest bow drawn since Robin Hood. But, clearly, as far as Senator Evans is concerned, it beggars imagination to think that he could be a candidate for the High Court if that is the level of his understanding of the judicial processes and the way in which these sorts of allegations ought to be dealt with. I am sure that if he were outside this chamber he would be acutely embarrassed at the fact that not a skerrick of evidence has been forthcoming.

I indicate to the Senate that when we talk about deals there is only one party and, above all, one politician with a long-held reputation for doing deals with media bosses. To whom was Conrad Black referring when he said he was told that an application to increase his stake in Fairfax would be entertained if he provided balanced political coverage? I ask whether senators know to whom editorial executive Max Suich was referring in a 1987 board minute reporting on an extended meeting with a politician when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . his motives for getting involved in the Herald and Weekly Times takeover were a desire to see the (Melbourne) Herald broken up and a desire to hurt Fairfax . . . The Treasurer is a product of the NSW right wing of the ALP and his conversation is littered with threats, references to getting even, doing deals and assisting `our crowd' in business, the press and within the ALP.

I hope people do not have any doubt to whom Max Suich was referring. He went on to say Mr Keating was `very blunt about the fact that the NSW right are "deal makers" and they provide favours to "our crowd" in return for favours given'. If the time is available subsequently, any number of further examples can be put on the record to demonstrate beyond doubt that Paul Keating has no compunction whatsoever in trying to do deals. We have just seen the one in relation to woodchipping in New South Wales and once again a decision in relation to interest rate increases—both deliberately designed to avoid damage to Bob Carr in the lead-up to the New South Wales election. I do not think the Australian public has any doubt at all what is really going on here. The Prime Minister is desperately on the defensive because he does not have John Howard's measure.

PARA.TAB: I noticed the Prime Minister was quoted in Bonn yesterday as saying that what John Howard should do is come up with a plan that will drive him mad. Of course, the fact is that John Howard has and it is. The Prime Minister is being driven out of his tree by the fact that he cannot tackle us on merits. When he should be debating the real issues, he is instead out there trying to defame as many people as possible and to intimidate businessmen who might even have the temerity to suggest that it is about time we had a change of government.

Do senators remember the episode relating to Dick Warburton reported in the Financial Review some weeks ago when he said that since the last election Mr Keating had simply been trying to bully business into silence and that he was not going to cop it any longer? That is yet another example of the way in which the Prime Minister is prepared to make these sorts of allegations.

In line with comments made by Senator Kernot in recent days, the urgency of this motion is that, if the Prime Minister and Mr Lee have any evidence, the proper place to present that evidence would be before a formal Senate committee, where they are on oath and where the allegations can be properly tested and examined. The people of Australia would then have the opportunity to assess the merits of the allegations.

But at the moment we have stony silence, a desperate Prime Minister now trying to talk up the republic as his latest diversion, presumably wanting to talk about anything but the matters that have dominated so-called public debate in Australia recently. I hope the Democrats will accept the need to provide this opportunity to people who make allegations in the public arena to come forward and justify their claims.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support establishing urgency by Senator Alston in order to move this motion. We have witnessed in this country over the last few weeks the spectacle, yet again, of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) acting as a bullyboy to public citizens, trying to get his way by asserting certain things without one shred of evidence. What is particularly disgraceful about the behaviour of the Prime Minister in this pursuit is that he has done most of it from overseas. He has severely embarrassed foreign heads of state as he has pursued a domestic political matter.

PARA.TAB: What is the real agenda behind this domestic political matter? The Prime Minister is upset that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) is well ahead in the polls and all his best efforts to tear down the Leader of the Opposition are failing. He has had a long history of personal denigration and trying to tear down leaders of the opposition. He has met his match this time because it is just not working. His own government is highly embarrassed about his behaviour. We only had to watch here yesterday Senator Gareth Evans get up and try to defend the indefensible. Here is a man who normally sits across the chamber from us and who is touted as a future member of the bench of the High Court. How on earth could he get up as he did yesterday—and it is on the Hansard record forever—to defend such an indefensible position as the Prime Minister's?

Then we have the Minster for Communications, Mr Lee, little Sir Echo, out there to doorstop yesterday, caught like a rabbit in a spotlight, knowing that the Prime Minister was telling Richos and trying to defend him. Where is the evidence? When you ask the government for the evidence, all it can come up with is what our policy position was in 1987, when we had some concerns about cross-media ownership rules—and we still do, and a lot of people have. That is quite legitimate.

The Prime Minister has been really caught out. All the major players—Mr Howard, Mr Packer, the senior executives of Fairfax, including people in the Fairfax organisation like Graham Richardson, have all come out and said that there is no deal. Why has this private citizen, Mr Packer, been bullied by the Prime Minister? He dared to take a different stance from the Prime Minister. He dared to say that John Howard would become a good Prime Minister. That so incensed this bullyboy Prime Minister that he went down his usual tack. The stories are legion about what he does to people who disagree with him. Just ask the press gallery. He roars down the phone at them if they disagree with him. He roared down the phone at a range of other people, such as people who supported us in the business community after the last election. If anyone disagrees with him they get publicly attacked. This time the Prime Minister has gone too far.

He is now trying desperately to shift the spotlight off himself and onto a new issue. This is proof that what the Prime Minister has done is wrong. He has been caught out telling Richos yet again and he is now bringing up the republic debate. That would be the surest evidence that we have the public spectacle of a Prime Minister not telling the truth. He is desperate to escape the situation. He should not be. He is the Prime Minister of this country and he should be called to account for this sort of behaviour.

The best way to call the Prime Minister to account is, as this notice of motion states in its last part, to reconvene the print media inquiry and call the Prime Minister before it for him to explain himself. That is why I believe this motion is urgent. I urge the Senate to debate it in full and I urge the minor parties, which have obviously observed the disgraceful behaviour of the Prime Minister on this matter both at home and overseas, to support it so that we can have a full and proper debate on this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to oppose this proposition. I do so on the basis that if you wanted serious debate in this country about media laws, if you wanted serious debate about the cultural direction this country should take in terms of its public media, the last place you would go is to a Senate select committee.

PARA.TAB: This particular Senate select committee has been from its very inception prejudiced and flawed. The evidence presented did not in any way support the conclusions that had been drawn well before the committee's establishment. For instance, in relation to this Fairfax inquiry, Senator Alston indicated his attitude on radio on 26 November 1993 that it was the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) who was in the dock. That was the basis on which this committee was established—that the Prime Minister was in the dock. Here again today exactly the same sorts of sentiments are being expressed—that the Prime Minister is in the dock. The Senate is not a court of law. The Senate is not the place to set up political, biased committees aimed at producing a political result which will further the case for the Liberal Party as it sees it in its own twisted view of reality.

We have here a committee that has not met for five months. It has no secretariat. Its material has been put into archive, where it belongs. Presumably the chairman of that committee has been picking up his benefits for five months without doing any work. We now have to ask ourselves why we have this proposition before the Senate today. Clearly, what we have is a political stunt by the opposition. Here we have a position being taken by the opposition to advance its grubby political agenda.

What is all this about? The political issue that would be debated publicly and fully is the political issue of who actually should own Australia's media. In this country we have very high levels of concentration of media ownership. But what do we see from the opposition? What is its policy on this matter? Mr Howard, the Leader of the Opposition, spelt it out very clearly on 17 February in the Financial Review. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I think technology has rendered the rules redundant.
He is talking there about the cross-media rules. He goes on:
I was always a bit sceptical about the wisdom of prohibitions. I was always a pro-market sort of person.

So you have the position in this country at the moment of the opposition advocating a policy of removing the cross-media laws, a position aimed at allowing the market to determine who should own Australia's media. The Liberals have said time and time again that that is their view.

PARA.TAB: We have seen in recent days five occasions on which Mr Costello and Mr Howard have refused to spell out their position. They do not resile from that proposition in fact that they are pro-market sorts of persons. We have seen quite clearly the position of Mr Howard, who has said, `What I say in public is what I say in private.' Good on him, because at least he is straight about it—unlike Senator Alston, who is implying a position completely different from that which the conservative parties actually stand for.

What is this proposal all about? Does the opposition really believe that the Prime Minister will rush before a committee such as this one, which has been stacked from the beginning and which is biased in its terms of reference? It is quite clearly prejudiced and follows a deliberate political agenda. Does it not honestly believe that that sort of process will be undertaken? If the opposition is serious about media rules, it will engage in full and public debate. It will reveal its policies up front. It will say up front what it stands for. It would not take the opportunistic and banal approach that has been taken to date of trying to suggest that it stands for something that it does not.
In reality, it has to ask itself about the role of the Senate in these proceedings. The establishment of politically biased select committees—(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support this motion for the suspension of standing orders, although I hope that we do not spend too much time debating the issue as we have a lot of business to get through today. I want to revisit some of the facts. This committee has had a lot of experience in sifting through claim and counterclaim. The jury is out on who was believed last time. We have the same problem this time.

PARA.TAB: However, all this motion requires is that the committee invite the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee) to provide evidence. That could be in written form. That is a much more simple mechanism than what we have embarked upon in the past.

It seems quite clear that since the Prime Minister and the Minister for Communications and the Arts have been challenged on this issue they have ducked for cover. It seems that there is no evidence to hand about a direct deal between Mr Packer and Mr Howard. It seems that no Packer employee will come forward to lend support to their arguments. It seems that the Prime Minister and the Minister for Communications and the Arts have rejected an opportunity to publicly put forward the evidence they say they have which is so important.

It is appropriate that we pursue the matter of this evidence as reasonably as we can. But that does not mean, to me anyway, that this is simply a matter of coalition witch-hunting. As far as I am concerned, what is at issue is media policy and the rules. The rules are crook. If the rules were transparent, it would not matter if Paul Keating had a conversation with Conrad Black or if Kerry Packer had a conversation with John Howard. It would not matter. If the rules were set in concrete and were open and transparent, no deals could be done. While ever we have this prime ministerial and ministerial discretion overriding the role of parliament, this is exactly what is going to continue to happen. The opposition needs to think about this, because it gives an opportunity for exploitation. I would be happy for the committee to yet again look at the whole notion of media ownership. It is not covered in this motion, but I would consider amending it in some form.
In any case, I foreshadow that I will seek to amend this motion. I have just discussed this with Senator Alston. I would seek to add this:

SPEECH.PARA: (d) In the event that the Prime Minister and Minister for Communications and the Arts provide the Committee with evidence, then the Leader of the Opposition be invited to refute such evidence.

In the previous committee, the Democrats requested the then Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, to appear. We seek to include both major parties in that way in this notice of motion. I am foreshadowing that I will move this amendment if we suspend the standing orders. I believe that that is probably what will happen.

PARA.TAB: Mr Keating has made serious allegations. The Senate has an opportunity to seek the evidence from him and the communications minister to support those allegations. They are equally as serious as the allegations made about deals done between Mr Black and Mr Keating and about what Mr Hawke may or may not have said in the past and what Dr Hewson may or may not have said in the past. This is about media policy. It deserves our scrutiny. There is a sense of urgency about this. I think the mechanism that is proposed in this motion to deal with it is a very sensible one.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Very briefly, the government will be opposing this suspension of standing orders and I can assure the Senate that we will also be opposing the substantive motion. I am aware of the fact that both the substantive motion and the suspension of standing orders are likely to see a majority of senators support the proposals, albeit possibly in an amended form in the way that Senator Kernot has outlined.

PARA.TAB: It is not the government's intention this morning in that circumstance to prolong a debate about this particular issue on either a suspension of standing orders or the motion that Senator Alston is proposing to move. The government is going to make it very clear that we really do consider this to be a very tawdry, very grubby political exercise. That is all it is. It is made very clear in the motion that Senator Alston has placed on notice, expressing grave concern that neither the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) nor the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee) has provided any evidence to support their allegations of a secret deal and so on. These are all the insinuations that we have come to expect from the opposition as we see what has been a continuing and deliberate misuse of the Senate committee system to further what can only be described as the lowest political motives imaginable.

This substantive motion is no more than a political statement from the opposition. It is no more than an attempt yet again to subvert the committee system and the committee processes of the Senate for these extraordinarily base political motives. This really is getting underneath the level of contempt. This really is just low life. It is absolutely despicable to see this sort of manipulation on the part of the opposition.

We have already had an explanation of what the status of this particular committee is. It completed its work, as Senator Carr indicated, quite some time ago now. We now have this attempt to stoke a bit of fire into the embers of a committee that had sunk without trace. This ought to be exposed for precisely what it is: it is an utterly transparent political exercise. The government is going to have absolutely no part of it in any way. We will not be supporting this suspension of standing orders and we will not be supporting the motion that Senator Alston has given notice of, which did not conform with the usual courtesies that are extended to senators.

At last I think we have managed to sort that out, and I appreciate the fact that the opposition got its wires crossed. But be absolutely clear: as we have indicated on many occasions, we are not going to see this continuing abuse of the Senate committee system. We are not going to facilitate this sort of operation by the Liberal Party in this chamber.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Alston's) be agreed to.
(Senator Watson did not vote, to compensate for the vacancy caused by the death of Senator Zakharov).
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Motion (by Senator Alston) agreed to:

That general business notice of motion No. 1402 standing in the name of Senator Alston for this day, relating to media ownership, may be moved immediately and have precedence over all other business this day till determined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes that:

TAB.TAB: (i)the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has repeatedly alleged that there has been a secret deal between the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and Mr Kerry Packer, and
(ii)the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee) has, in effect, reiterated this allegation by asserting that the Prime Minister has firm evidence that links Mr Howard to a secret deal;

PARA.TAB: (b)expresses its grave concern that neither the Prime Minister nor the Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided any evidence to support their allegations of a secret deal; and

(c)calls on the Select Committee on Certain Aspects of Foreign Ownership Decisions in relation to the Print Media to invite the Prime Minister and the Minister for Communications and the Arts to provide it with any evidence that they have to support these allegations.

SPEECH.PARA: I indicated earlier why there was some urgency about this matter, and the contributions that we heard from the government side simply reinforce how critical it is that we address the fundamental issue: that is, in a democratic society, it is absolutely essential that people who make very serious allegations ought to be required to substantiate them.

PARA.TAB: Given that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has a long history of making outrageous statements and then simply thumbing his nose at those who have the temerity to object, this provides a very good opportunity for him to come along in a serious forum and put his position on the record. You will recall his response to the print media inquiry when we found that he had effectively tried to bribe Conrad Black by promising him balanced coverage in exchange for an increase in the level of foreign ownership—he sent a raspberry from Paris. That is the sort of way in which the Prime Minister responds to serious issues.

Mr Acting Deputy President, I will just tell you a little anecdote about that one. I was fast asleep in a hotel in Sydney at about 2 o'clock one morning when I was woken up by the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation. The interviewer said to me, `Given that you've been the chair of this committee and that there have been a number of serious matters discussed involving Conrad Black who is a Canadian, perhaps you would like to explain to our listeners across Canada what this is all about.' So, given the convention that we on this side of the chamber believe still applies that you should be very careful about airing domestic linen internationally, I did my best to simply retell the facts of the matter—what Mr Black had said in his book, what Mr Keating then said in Seattle. When I had explained all this about the Prime Minister asking for a commitment to balanced coverage, the interviewer said to me, `Say, is that right; so when's this guy going to gaol?' That is how seriously the CBC viewed those allegations. Yet all we got from the Prime Minister was, `Raspberry to you, couldn't care less, not interested.' That is his track record.

We had the altar boy faithfully supporting Mr Keating again this week, again without a skerrick of evidence. What is very important in this debate as well is that Mr Lee's position ought to be clarified. It is not good enough for him, wanting to be the heir apparent, to somehow aspire to the leadership of this nation by simply trying to get there on the Prime Minister's coat tails, particularly when he is in a position of having to decide whether he has his own independent views on this matter or whether he should slavishly follow those of the Prime Minister. Yet time and again, in question time and elsewhere, Mr Lee has been given the chance to put up or shut up. On each occasion he has failed to provide a skerrick of evidence and claimed that the Prime Minister had received firm evidence from inside the Packer camp.

What was Mr Lee saying last night? Something to the effect of, `Well, we don't reveal our sources, we don't really know what went on, but we invite you to give us your evidence to support our allegations.' That is preposterous and outrageous. One can understand why little Sir Echo finds himself between a rock and a hard place. On the one hand, he knows that his political career depends on falling in line with the Prime Minister; yet, at the same time, he knows that the Prime Minister has simply made allegations that he cannot substantiate and that Mr Howard has comprehensively refuted them. No other person in the country has provided any solace to the Prime Minister, so he is reduced to desperately trying to change the subject overseas—very belatedly, I might say.

As Laurie Oakes made very clear yesterday, it was not accidental that Mr Keating got up in Singapore and embarrassed and humiliated the Singapore leader in the way that he did. He had decided on the plane, on the way over, that he wanted to give this another big airing. In fact, I think it was Greg Turnbull, his press secretary, who invited the media to ask questions on the very joint platform with the Singaporean Prime Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a set-up.

—It was a set-up, yes. I am sure that, if the Singaporean Prime Minister had known that he was going to be embarrassed in that way, he would not have had a bar of it. But of course that was not on Mr Keating's agenda.

PARA.TAB: So we have a person with a long history of deal making—probably the ultimate deal maker in Australian politics—very proud of himself. As I said earlier, Max Suich made the reference that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . he is very blunt about the fact that the NSW right are `deal makers' and that they provide favours to `our crowd' in return for favours given . . .
Let me just ask this question: to whom was William Shawcross referring in his biography of Rupert Murdoch when he said that he:

. . . had had dinner with Murdoch several weeks beforehand (the Cabinet decision . . . ) and told him of his plans. Murdoch said later that it sounded so fantastic that he thought it would never get through Cabinet. Keating also alerted Packer but gave no such advance warning to either the Herald or the Fairfax groups. When the Cabinet agreed to the Keating plan and it was announced, Murdoch knew that this would be the best possible time to sell his television stations and to become an even more powerful Prince of Print. He made his dash from the slopes of Aspen back to Australia to try and buy the Herald.

To whom was Shawcross referring when he spoke of an ALP caucus meeting subsequent to cabinet approving the cross-media rules at which the gentleman in question attacked the Herald and said `it would be good if it was split up' because it was `not one of us'.

PARA.TAB: I was asked on 6PR, I think it was, the other day about some of the Prime Minister's allegations, and particularly about what Mr Keating had said in November 1993 about Kerry Stokes. Remember, Kerry Stokes gave the Boyer lectures last year and made some very intelligent contributions about the future of the superhighway, its implications for Australia, and consequences for national sovereignty in relation to the transfer of data and information. Mr Stokes is an eminent Australian, not only one I would have thought deserving of being taken seriously but also one we should regard as a very great success story in this country.
What did Mr Keating say about Mr Stokes in November 1993? He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I don't have to deal with the Kerry Stokes of this world. He's a bit below my speed.
A couple of weeks back, Alan Ramsay told us—I think it was about a farewell for Geoff Walsh:

Keating told his listeners, amongst other things, that he'd `fixed Fairfax once before and now they're all back again. If I have to, I'll do it again. Alexander, the Herald's editor-in-chief spent his time sucking up to Sydney's yuppies and if he gets in my way I'll stick it right up him'—a remark accompanied by a jabbing stiff index finger.
He said:

`and if you blokes think I'll just bend over and let you day after day and I'll cop it'—I think that is expletive deleted—and if necessary he'd crush Alexander and the Herald, grinding the toe of his shoe on the floor to emphasise the point.

He even went on to say about Paul Kelly, the editor of the Australian, to whose son he is the godfather, that Kelly could not even pick his nose when it came to politics. This man has an extraordinary history. As Ramsay reported, he told an extraordinary story of how supposedly he had almost run Murdoch out of the country some years ago and that he probably should have done it again.

PARA.TAB: We all know the Prime Minister's reputation for ringing people up. If there is any media proprietor that he wants to vent his spleen on when it comes to articles that he disagrees with, he rings them up and abuses them ferociously in the foulest possible language. Again, he has tried to intimidate I think the business community at large with his attack on Mr Packer.

What is so utterly reprehensible about the current episode is that these allegations about a secret deal between Mr Packer and Mr Howard have been comprehensively refuted. Mr Keating has simply stuck to his line through thick and thin and he has been supported by Little Sir Echo. It is just not good enough to have those sorts of allegations made on the public record. It is the big lie technique. You throw a bit of mud, hope that it sticks and hope that in six months time people say, `Don't I recall there was something about a secret deal between Packer and Howard. You never know, do you. Where there is smoke there is fire.' I would have thought that anyone who was seriously addressing the issue could come to only one conclusion that there simply is no evidence at all to support these outrageous allegations. Therefore, the opportunity to present material before a Senate committee is the very least that the parliament can do to pursue the matter.

It really is breathtaking to hear Senator Faulkner talking about all the usual insinuations in this proposal. The fact is all the insinuations, all the alleged circumstantial evidence upon circumstantial evidence, is what the government relies on. The government said as recently as yesterday, when Senator Evans was asked about the matter, that the evidence of the secret deal is all on the public record. Then we go through a few bits and pieces from which any reasonable citizen would infer there must have been a secret deal. Otherwise, why would you have a view on the cross-media rules?

If that is the state of debate we have reached in this country, it is a very sorry situation. I would have thought the last thing we want in this country is for people to be accused of all sorts of nefarious activities simply on the basis of expressing an opinion about the law, particularly when the Prime Minister himself has said on a number of occasions that the onset of technology is tending to make those rules obsolete.

He is not the only one who has said that. A number of people have said it. As recently as last week Brian Johns said it in the Broadband Services Expert Group report. That will be the fact, of course, when Murdoch brings Star in from Hong Kong after 1997, as he will inevitably be allowed to do, as we get more and more on-line services accessible from Australia internationally, as we have on-line publishing, and as we have all sorts of creative ways of transmitting information. Obviously pay television is only the latest. The ABC news and current affairs channel will be yet another forum for dissemination of views. Clearly these rules are not working.

I think even Senator Kernot said they were crook. They are crook not only in the sense that they allow for a great deal of subjectivity but also in the sense that they were supposed to achieve a strict dichotomy between print and television. You were allowed to be a prince of print, queen of the screen, but not both. Yet what do we have in this country? We have major players who have a foot in both television and print media camps. Given that telecommunications is the fastest growing industry in the world, it seems bizarre that there are virtually no limits on cross-media in relation to telecommunications. I suppose the fact that magazines are excluded is more evidence of the anomalies that exist in this whole area.

It is quite clear that the rules are in need of review. When Mr Lee talked about the review of the Broadcasting Services Act, he made it clear that there could not be a sensible review unless a review of the cross-media rules was included. All we have said is, `Bring forward that review. Let's have a look at all the evidence and see what is the most effective way of promoting plurality and diversity.' On that basis, together with Mr Howard's comments which show how utterly consistent he has been in his scepticism about the effectiveness of the cross-media rules since 1987—at a time, as he points out, when Mr Packer was publicly advocating a vote for that paragon of virtue Bob Hawke—we now have the Prime Minister descending to this Fuhrer-like behaviour.

I think it is very important that those who make those allegations ought to be required to produce evidence. The Senate print media committee provides the perfect opportunity to do just that. Let us not have any more of the nonsense which suggests that somehow, because the government does not have the numbers on the committee, the committee is biased. You can say that about any parliamentary committee. Someone has got the numbers on them. We do not have the numbers outright. We rely on the Democrats for support on that committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the Greens?

—And the Greens. For many years, up until 1993, you have been used to having the absolute numbers on all your committees, and you still do in the House of Representatives. Does that mean that every committee that you ever commission to examine an issue is, by definition, biased? Does that mean that any terms of reference are fundamentally flawed? Does that mean that it is perfectly improper for the parliament to examine these issues? Does it mean that, simply because the government of the day has a contrary view, it is somehow illegitimate for an opposition to want to make use of those committee structures? Of course it does not. All you are doing is playing the partisan game. I understand that, and I can understand why you will keep saying that.

PARA.TAB: I remember Senator Collins saying—I think he said it in opposition but, undoubtedly, his view has not changed in government—that you say anything to advance your cause. So be it. No doubt we will have more of the same shortly. The fact remains that political processes are available to provide a measure of protection to witnesses who have the courage to come forward and elaborate on their concerns, to put evidence on the public record to support allegations they have made elsewhere. This is the perfect opportunity for both the Prime Minister and the nominal Minister for Communications and the Arts to put up or shut up.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —We had an informal agreement that this would not take much more than half an hour overall. I will seek to contain myself to as close to five minutes as I can and certainly to no more time than Senator Alston took. I listened to Senator Alston's contribution and thought that, if the spokesman for the opposition on communications really wanted to end any possibility that the public could think that there was a deal between Kerry Packer and the opposition, what would he say? He would say, `We will not allow Kerry Packer to buy Fairfax.' I listened carefully and did not hear any such comment. That is not surprising because the coalition has been very deliberately evading, ducking and weaving any question about its policies on this issue.

PARA.TAB: Last night, Mr Howard was interviewed on, of all things, Channel Nine. He received a very tempting invitation. Ray Martin asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Well, let's shoot straight.
That is not a bad invitation for someone who claims to be a straight shooter—
Should Kerry Packer be allowed to own Channel Nine and the Fairfax group?
Howard replied:
Well, I don't think you should deal with these things—no pun intended—on the basis of personali ties.
Ray Martin was thinking, `That was not a bad duck. I will have to ask this question more particularly.' He asked:
Should any man then?
Perhaps `any person' would have been a better way of saying it. He continues:
Let's forget personalities. Any man or woman should they own a television network in Australia and also the major publishing group?
A `no' would have ended a lot of speculation. What did the Leader of the Opposition say? He said:
Well, it depends entirely on what the other players in all of the media markets are. It depends on a whole range of factors. I'm not going to say yes or no to that question. Why should I?

I would have thought that there was one very good reason for answering that question. The Australian people would not mind knowing what your policy is. In fact, they would not mind knowing what your policies are on anything.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. We do not mind a wide ranging debate and we can talk about everyone's policies between now and the next election, but I simply say on a point of relevance that this debate is about an opportunity for the Prime Minister to substantiate allegations, not about what our policy position might be in relation to the media or any other issue. It is about specific matters that have been canvassed ad nauseam in recent days. You ought to direct the minister to direct his attention to that issue.

—On the point of order: the question of the policy of the opposition is fundamental to this issue. It goes to the substance of the deals that have to been done to reach those policies. The opposition's policy is clearly to hand over Fairfax to one of these proprietors. If it was not, why does the opposition not say that.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McGauran)—I will allow a broad ranging debate, but I will not allow utter irrelevancies.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate your tolerant ruling, which is consistent with what you applied in respect of Senator Alston. Ray Martin then went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: But don't you think someone would say well, hang on, he's quite happy, John Howard's quite happy to have a slap at the Government, but he's got no policy himself on this?
That did not seem like a bad question. John Howard then went on to say:
Well, I think to say that the market ought to have a greater say in working out things is a very effective response to that.
That is a bit elliptical and code, but I think we probably all know what it means.

TALK.START.PARA: —The code breaker.

—I will come back to that code in a minute. Do not worry. You might think I am traversing the opposition's policy, but it is actually something Senator Alston said in his comments, so I assume it is as relevant when I respond to it as when he said it. He said that the Leader of the Opposition has had a consistent policy on this issue since 1987. I will come back to some of the implications of that in a moment. One of the significant points we have to make is that between 1987 and 1995 there was a major detour taken that is directly relevant to this issue. It is very interesting to determine why, between 1991 and 1995, we have had this dramatic return to the policy of 1987.

PARA.TAB: In 1991, Mr Howard's expressed view was that he would and the government should oppose the sale of the Fairfax group to any individual or consortium that would result in a greater concentration of media ownership and thus a diminution of competition in a diversity of information sources in Australia. That was the policy he signed up to in 1991. He put his name to that in 1991. He signed a petition to that effect in 1991.

That was his policy then so why is it not his policy now? When Ray Martin asked him the same question, why did he duck and weave? He did not duck and weave in 1991. That was his policy. He has done a U-turn in relation to the policy that there should be no ownership of Fairfax that could lead to the diminution of competition and the diversity of information sources in Australia. Why is that not his policy now? What are the factors in the transition from then to now? That is a very important public policy question. I will not go through the charade of pretending that a Senate committee is going to help us find the answer to that, but the Australian people will ultimately come to a conclusion on that very important question.

In the time available to me I am not going to reiterate those points. I simply say that I endorse the points made by Senator Evans in his articulation of some of the interconnections that give reasonable grounds for suspicion, shall we say to be polite. He said that yesterday in four minutes. In the time available to me, I will not reiterate that, but simply endorse it. The capacity of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), when he returns, to say what he chooses about his evidence and what he chooses to make clear is a matter for him and I will not in any way reiterate it.

We all know that this motion is just a stunt. The Senate should start from the reasonable presumption that neither the Prime Minister nor the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee) will appear before the committee. I think that is probably a presumption that everybody shares. So why are we having this motion? It is an excuse for a few people to make speeches about this issue. There are plenty of other procedural devices. It is a pity we are getting bogged down with this one when we could be dealing with substantial issues of good governance of the country; but we have it before us, so let us deal with it.

Why are there reasonable grounds for suspicions about what has caused this transition between 1991 and 1995 in Mr Howard's view? What should we conclude about what might have been the cause of this? There is a lot of speculation about what constitutes a deal or coming to an arrangement. It seems to me that when you see individuals and/or groups taking concerted action in support of mutually advantageous goals you can start to say, `This is walking a bit like a duck, it's even quacking a bit like a duck, perhaps it is a duck.' Here we have two simultaneous events: the opposition clearly sending coded messages, clear signals that it will allow Packer to buy Fairfax—

TALK.START.PARA: —Smoke signals?

—All you are burning are your previous policy positions. The smoke signals are very easy to read. They are saying, `We will allow Packer to buy Fairfax.' Suddenly Kerry Packer said, `John Howard isn't a bad bloke.' There are a number of explanations for why these coordinated and concerted actions towards mutually advantageous goals might have taken place. One is that there could have been an overt deal. They could have said, `We will agree to change our policy in return for your support.' That is one possible explanation and there are those who think there is evidence to support that. Let us leave that there.

PARA.TAB: There is another possibility. It could be a covert deal. They could be saying, `We will make it clear, without explicitly saying so, that we are going to allow Mr Packer to buy Fairfax. We are going to say, "We'll leave it to the Trade Practices Commission," when we know the Trade Practices Commission has said, "We regard newspaper and television markets as separate, therefore, Mr Packer will be allowed to buy Fairfax".' You could say, `I still hold the policy I had in 1987 which meant I would allow Mr Packer to buy Fairfax,' and not refer to the different policy you had in 1991. That is also code for, `We will allow Mr Packer to buy Fairfax and, coincidentally, we will receive Mr Packer's support at the same time but in an entirely unrelated way.'

A third possible explanation is that coalition members have a policy which they do not want to make public, which is that they are just policy vandals who are actually determined to annihilate pluralism in our media in this country. That is a third possible explanation. If that is the one they want to opt for, I will accept it; although I think it is more likely to be one or two places higher up in the pecking order of possibilities. So we have all those elements coming together. The key thing that distinguishes government and opposition on this is typified by this argument about allowing the TPC to decide. I have great respect for the Trade Practices Commission and for its chairman. I do not agree with every decision he makes, but it is a very important institution in our country in relation to competition. As a result of Hilmer, we hope to strengthen those competition issues. But media ownership is more than an economic issue. It is more than about simple questions of competition as to who owns baked beans factories, which are important, but relate to an economic issue.

This is an economic issue, but it is also a social and a cultural issue. It is an issue about what sort of society we want in relation to media ownership, plurality and diversity. The policies Mr Howard signed up to in 1991 but has abandoned now are important policies. The concern people are entitled to have about why between 1991 and 1995 there has been this profound change is an issue that the Australian people are entitled to get an answer to from the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), and eventually they will get it. But one thing we all know is that this motion will not help them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have canvassed some of this material in the previous debate. I want to make clear that when I began this call for a re-opening of the inquiry it was very clear that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) had made serious allegations. Since the time I made this call he has been unable to produce evidence. There is one reality that I think we ought to consider here, and that is that it is likely that not much will come out of an invitation to the Prime Minister and the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee) to provide evidence. Nevertheless, I think it is important that we say to them, `You've made these allegations. They are serious allegations. Here's your opportunity to provide the evidence.' But we have to be realistic about what, from the committee's point of view, may come out of such an action.

PARA.TAB: What I regret about this motion is that it does not refer to media policy. I have a press release from Senator Alston with the headline `Labor's media ownership shambles'. It quite accurately chronicles the sort of ad hoc approach to media policy that has characterised—unfortunately, I think, because it is such an important policy area—the Labor government in recent years. The last paragraph states:

SPEECH.PARA: While Barry Jones is dead right I suspect that Paul Keating would not have it any other way. The current policy vacuum enables him to base media ownership decision on personalities and prejudices, rather than any clearly espoused policy principles.

I say that applies to the opposition as well: there is a huge policy vacuum. It may have been more appropriate, and I need to give some more thought to this, to have included a term of reference which said we should look at the changes that have happened in the last 10 years in particular which obviously necessitate a revisit to communications policy.

PARA.TAB: In saying that, I think I should clear up something that Senator Alston and others are saying. It seems to have gained currency the idea that the minister for communications is required to have a review of the entire area of communications policy in 1997. But in fact all he has to do—due to our previous debate I think this is because of a Democrat amendment—is have a review into a possible fourth TV licence and Australian drama content on pay TV. There is no absolute requirement for the minister to do anything more than that. It would be wise of him to broaden it, but I think we are all standing around in an expectation that he is required to do it when he is not. I think that is one factual point that needs to be made.

When we are talking about media policy, I join with the comments of Senator McMullan. When Mr Costello has made reference on AM to the role of the anti-monopoly provisions of the Trade Practices Act and the way in which the coalition would seek to protect media plurality using that mechanism, I need to make a couple of points. This would not prevent cross-media ownership because the Trade Practices Commission regards the commercial TV and print media markets as separate. Also, relying on that mechanism may or may not prevent further concentration within the commercial television market—for example, the acquisition of Channel 9 by Channel 10. There is so much that is open to misinterpretation and exploitation in this area of communications policy that I foreshadow that I certainly want to talk to Senator Alston.

If we meet with, if we write to, the Prime Minister and the Minister for Communications and the Arts, invite them to provide evidence and they provide nothing, then where does that get us? It probably says: politicians should not go around making serious allegations which they cannot back up, and that is a point worth making. Policy has been a focus of the previous committee. We talked a lot about foreign ownership policy. We talked about the history of media policy in this country. I feel very strongly that if Minister Lee does not conduct a review of the whole area, then somebody has to. Somebody has to draw all these threads together and say: `Let us have an end to the ad hockery. Let us get policy in place so that we cannot find ourselves revisiting the allegations of deals, because it will not be possible to make deals if we get the rules right.'

We are waiting on, I think, an ABA determination of Mr Packer's position. The ABA could decide that Mr Packer can go to a 24.8 per cent stake in Fairfax. It might conclude that; we do not know. But that draws attention to another huge defect in the policy—the whole notion of what constitutes control. We looked at that in our previous committee. It is an issue which has not been resolved. When Senator Faulkner and others raised the point about the committee not having met, as I recall it the reason that we have not presented a final report is that one of our terms of reference is to respond to the government's response to our initial report.

Mr Willis, the Treasurer, is on the record as saying that he believes changes have to be made in foreign investment, in the way the Foreign Investment Review Board operates, and that he is going to be making those changes. He said that at a time when our committee was making recommendations on that matter. It is one of the parts of the committee's report where we are in broad agreement—not detailed agreement but broad agreement. He has not done that yet. The government has not responded to our report. That is why, although we are not meeting, the committee has not concluded. So there are legitimate areas for the committee to either explore or revisit, but we should understand that we may do nothing more under this motion than send a strong message to those in public life who use the media to make strong allegations that this is unacceptable. That is worth doing.

I would like us to focus on the longer term issues of media policy in this country because they are in a mess, and we have an opportunity to do something about it. That requires the opposition to clearly state its attitude to media ownership and to cross-media concentration in so far as Mr Packer's position is concerned and what it is prepared to do in the case of a review if we could say to it that the trade practices mechanism simply does not work. There is so much opportunity there to draw those threads together and to use it constructively. This motion does not quite go that far. Senator Alston was out of the chamber. We might need to talk about whether that is a legitimate thing to pursue.

The government could pull the rug out either from under this committee or from under all the allegations of the Packer-Howard deal by saying, `We are going to legislate next session to tighten up the cross-media rules.' It is that simple. It is a little bit of the same from both major parties. You do not want to lock yourself in too much too soon.

TALK.START.PARA: —Retrospectively?

—That is another matter. But that is a remedy available to the government now in the same way as there is a remedy available to the opposition to quite clearly state: `This is our policy position.' When I was speaking to the motion for the suspension of standing orders earlier I foreshadowed an amendment. I now move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion add:

"(d)directs that, in the event that the Prime Minister and Minister for Communications and the Arts provide the committee with evidence, the Leader of the Opposition then be invited to refute such evidence."

As I said then, I think this amendment makes the motion less one-sided. I think that was the approach we brought to the previous hearings of the committee in asking Dr Hewson to appear, which he did. I just think the amendment makes the motion a little more balanced.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think, in view of the way the debate has gone, it might be an idea to restate exactly what this motion says. Senator Alston's motion states:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes that:

TAB.TAB: (i)the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has repeatedly alleged that there has been a secret deal—

SPEECH.PARA: he has never resiled from that position—
between the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and Mr Kerry Packer, and

TAB.TAB: (ii)the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee) has, in effect, reiterated this allegation by asserting that the Prime Minister has firm evidence that links Mr Howard to a secret deal;—

SPEECH.PARA: from which Mr Lee has at no stage resiled—

PARA.TAB: (b)expresses its grave concern that neither the Prime Minister nor the Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided any evidence to support their allegations of a secret deal; and

(c)calls on the Select Committee on Certain Aspects of Foreign Ownership Decisions in relation to the Print Media to invite the Prime Minister and the Minister for Communications and the Arts to provide it with any evidence that they have to support these allegations.

SPEECH.PARA: To that Senator Kernot has added the sensible amendment that:

PARA.TAB: (d)in the event that the Prime Minister and Minister for Communications and the Arts provide the committee with evidence, then the Leader of the Opposition be invited to refute such evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason I stated that is that, obviously, this motion has very little to do with the extraordinary remarks of Senator McMullan. Senator McMullan, among other things, decided to redefine the word `deal'. He redefined the word `deal' apparently to cover situations where if there is a mutuality of interest in an outcome therefore there must have, per se, been a deal. In other words, the fact that Senator McMullan and I, for example, might welcome the fact that the Australian Chamber Orchestra should be funded to go overseas and would be pleased to see the Australian Chamber Orchestra do so means we have come to some deal, according to Senator McMullan's eccentric definition of the word `deal' to bring about this outcome. We may well have in fact talked about it both in private conversations and in this chamber, but that does not mean we have come to a deal to deliver. Senator McMullan clearly is clutching at incredible straws and it establishes the absolute nonsense of the case.

PARA.TAB: What was even worse about Senator McMullan's attempt to defend the government's position was his nonsensical thuggery, in effect, whereby he said to the opposition, `Unless you agree with the government's policy, you have no integrity in this matter.' It is absolute nonsense. He says that we have to state that, in fact, we would not allow Mr Packer to acquire further holdings in the Fairfax group. We have to state that clearly we would not allow that to happen and that if we fail to do so it therefore means we have come to a deal.
