I must say, that is the most incredibly dishonest political thuggery I have heard from Senator McMullan, whom I generally regard as a person of innate decency.
What concerns me is that clearly in this situation Senator McMullan is being stood over by the compleat political thug, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating).

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that proper parliamentary language?
—The term `political thuggery' means standing over people.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I am not one to take great points of order on the way that people should or should not be described. However, Senator Baume has described the Prime Minister as a political thug.
—He would be proud of it.

—If they are going to be the new rules, I am quite happy to have them. But do not squeal when we start using them on you on a few occasions. I ask you to rule on that point, Mr Acting Deputy President.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McGauran)—I am not a rule setter, being only the Acting Deputy President. My first instinct is to think it is not out of order. However, I will consult the clerk, as I do not want to set a precedent or rule.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, to save you the trouble, I will certainly withdraw. If that delicate flower, the minister, feels that I have in any way criticised the Prime Minister, who is renowned for his gentleness and kindness in political debate—if the minister is so sensitive—I naturally withdraw. We do not want this sensitive minister to regard the Prime Minister as anything other than the generator of sweetness and light that he holds himself out to be. For the minister's sake, I will not describe him as a political thug. I will just describe him as a political standover man.
—I take that as a withdrawal. Nevertheless, I am consulting the clerk to get a proper and strict ruling. I will take that as a withdrawal, Senator Baume, and ask you to continue.

—It is a withdrawal. I substitute the term `political standover man'. This attempt by the government to try to force the opposition—I think the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Kernot) was sort of going down this track—to state its determined policy at the next election on a whole range of issues is something that the opposition simply will not wear. We tried it once before when coming out over a year before an election.

PARA.TAB: I remind the Senate that an election is not due until a year from now. We will come out with all our policies before the next election. We will not be stood over by political standover men like the Prime Minister or Senator McMullan and we will not be hassled by Senator Kernot to make our whole range of policies at the next election available before the people of Australia have the right to expect it, which is in the run-up to the next election.

Having said that, let me deal with the issues. During the debate on the procedural motion—on whether this matter should go ahead—the government stated that debating this motion would be a grubby political exercise. Once again, that is a fascinating redefinition of the word `grubby'. It is a grubby political exercise to require the Prime Minister of Australia to tell the truth for a change. This is about the fact that the Prime Minister of Australia has repeatedly told a lie and stood by it. He has sought to pressure the opposition into adopting his position in what is no more than a political standover tactic. If it is a grubby political exercise to require the Prime Minister to tell the truth, I plead guilty. It would be a pleasant change if the Prime Minister were to do so.
The fact is that senior Labor figures—if one regards Peter Barron and Graham Richardson as such—have confirmed that the Prime Minister lied. There is simply no evidence that there was a deal.

An article in the Australian today refers to the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee) who, under these extraordinary arrangements where the government arrogantly disregards the requirements of the parliament to appear properly at question time or at other times, did not appear in parliament yesterday. When Mr Lee was asked why he did not accept Mr Graham Richardson's denial of a deal, he said that he would not challenge what Mr Richardson had said. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister and I certainly were provided with a strong indication as to what the Liberals might have said to PBL and Mr Packer.

In other words, they have a mole. They will not say who it is. They will not say what he said. They will not say anything about it. They will not come clean. When Mr Keating was told what his former colleagues had said, he said, `They would, wouldn't they?' Mr Keating's assessment was that they would lie and cheat to protect Mr Packer. Maybe that is the normal conduct that Mr Keating expects of his colleagues and friends in the Labor Party, in which case I must say that I cannot necessarily disagree with him.

TALK.START.PARA: —Judging by his standards.

—He judges people by his standards. But the fact is that there is no evidence whatsoever. On the contrary, we have a simple situation. We have either the words of Labor apparatchiks, Mr Kerry Packer and Mr John Howard that there is no deal or the unsubstantiated rubbish of this Prime Minister and his acolyte, Mr Lee, that there was a deal. We can disregard Senator McMullan's redefinition of the word `deal', which is patently ludicrous. We have to determine whom we should believe—honest John Howard or Paul Keating. That is the simple issue here. The Australian public will have very little doubt about whom it should believe.

PARA.TAB: There is no deal. There was never any deal. There is no evidence of any deal. Certainly, in the House of Representatives yesterday, Labor ministers were running around trying to redefine the word `deal', as Senator McMullan did here today. Of course, there was a deal before the election, wasn't there? There was a deal between Mr Keating and Mr Black. The deal was that if Mr Keating was satisfied with the sort of cover that the Sydney Morning Herald group, under Mr Black, gave to the Labor Party in the election—I do not know how you define Mr Keating's satisfaction—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is in the eye of the beholder, and he delivered on the deal.

—It was in the eye of the beholder, as Senator Alston said, and Mr Black delivered on the deal, as one could tell by looking at the extraordinary volume of front-page news items in the run-up to the last election which damaged the federal seat of Lowe, a Liberal seat in New South Wales. It was an absolutely disgraceful non-stop collection of politically oriented articles. In any event, can I say that, unlike the present situation, Mr Keating has been involved in deals regarding the nature of the journalistic cover of his party in the run-up to an election. It was the most disgraceful sort of deal that one could possibly have.

PARA.TAB: As a result of that deal, we have seen Mr Black's holding in the Fairfax group, which had a maximum limit of 15 per cent, increase to 25 per cent, and there is a request that it go up further to 35 per cent. No doubt it depends on what sort of deal is done once again in respect of the sort of cover the Fairfax group might give the Labor government in the run-up to the next election.

I agree with Senator Kernot that there is a need to have a look at the whole aspect of media rules when you can have that kind of deal done to break down the whole system. As Mr Packer said, it is a farce. It has been made a farce by this government. It has been made a farce deliberately. It has been made a farce so that Mr Keating can do his secret deals with those proprietors where he believes there would be a benefit to him.
The problem is that Mr Keating genuinely believes he can do what he wants, that he is some kind of Fuhrer who must not be opposed or criticised. We now have `Fuhrer Keating'.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is an expert on the Goebbels technique.

—We understand at last why today's newspaper reports show that Mr Keating likes the German political model. The only thing about Mr Keating liking the German political model is that he is 60 years too late for his style of government. His model is the authoritarian one. Fancy having Keating as the Fuhrer. By the way, that is one of the problems you might face under the Keating republic proposals.

PARA.TAB: He is already, as my colleague from New South Wales Senator Tierney interjected, an expert on the Goebbels technique, so I suppose he is halfway back to that era. He repeats the lies so often that people begin to believe them. I had not realised, I might say, how prescient my notice of motion was yesterday, but I will come back to that in a minute. Mr McGuinness, in his column in today's Sydney Morning Herald, deals with this authoritarian approach by Mr Keating. He states:

SPEECH.PARA: By his recent treatment of the Governor-General, especially the studied insult of not inviting him to the 50th anniversary ceremony at the Canberra War Memorial, the Prime Minister has made it clear that he does not accept that the head of state comes first in order of precedence. He has of course also sponsored the establishment of a committee on rorting the honours system by taking it out of the Governor-General's office.

This Fuhrer approach—doing deals approach, repeating the lies approach, and now wanting to go down the German track, if you like—just fits a clear authoritarian pattern, a dictatorial style of government, that the Prime Minister continually carries on. He does not like to be opposed and Mr Packer's sin was that he dared to say that maybe John Howard mightn't make a bad Prime Minister.

PARA.TAB: We are simply asking the Prime Minister and the Minister for Communications and the Arts to provide the committee with any evidence they have to support those allegations of a deal. Senator McMullan has now admitted that they will not appear. Senator McMullan said that that demonstrated how ludicrous the committee was and how silly the proposal was. On the contrary, doesn't it demonstrate how arrogant this government is and how the Prime Minister and the minister certainly cannot appear before the committee because to do so they would have to admit on oath that they lied?

Isn't it intriguing? The real issue is that the Prime Minister and the minister's blatant dishonesty, their uncontested lies, would be revealed if they came before the committee. Senator McMullan has said they will not do so and reinterprets that as some kind of fault of this chamber for requiring the Prime Minister and Mr Lee to tell the truth—how dare we require the Prime Minister and Mr Lee to tell the truth!
I will just go back, as I said, to the prescient notice of motion I gave yesterday, which stated:

That the Senate notes that the unbalanced and unsubstantiated attacks by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on Mr Kerry Packer demonstrate that the Prime Minister is getting close to his banana republic, as he has already clearly gone bananas, and all he now needs is his republic.

SPEECH.PARA: Isn't it remarkable that in today's media he is restating the argument for a republic? I can say that neither his republic nor his bananas are terribly appealing to this chamber or to anyone else. I want to end on this note. This issue, if anything does, clearly demonstrates the difference between the two leaders of the major political parties in Australia. On the one hand, you have the deal doing, standover merchant, authoritarian, dictatorial Prime Minister who will tell lies—as he has in this case—in a disgraceful and dishonest way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on; fair go! You know it is unparliamentary.

—This is a substantive motion. He will tell lies, and he is given the opportunity in this motion to admit that he told lies—to make a confession, if you like. So, that is the sort of leader we have there. We have a leader—and even Mr Lee says this—who has said everything publicly that was claimed to have been said privately to Mr Packer. In other words, honest John Howard was honest in total in this issue. He was clearly up-front on all matters, and the Labor Party concedes it. The Labor Party says, `Yes, he has said everything publicly.' In fact, nothing which was said in private has deviated one bit from what was said in public, and the Labor Party acknowledges it.

PARA.TAB: On the one side, we have honest John; on the other side, we have Paul cheating. That is the issue and that is what is in front of the Australian people. That is what this issue, probably more than any other in simple terms, clearly encapsulates.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McGauran)—Before I call Senator Carr, I wish to clarify something. Senator Schacht raised a point of order in relation to the word `thug'. I have spoken to the clerk and referred to Odgers. I know these things are subject to the times, and the times do change as to what emphasis is placed on words. If Senator Schacht, although he has left the chamber, would like to refer to page 217 of Odgers, he will note that it gives a very extensive list of what has been ruled as unparliamentary. The word `thug', surprisingly, does not come into it. However, I rule that its tone is unparliamentary.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I want to make the simple point that what was actually said was `political thug', not `thug'. I would have thought there was a fair degree of difference between those. So, Mr Acting Deputy President, I ask you to take that into account and reflect on that before you make a final ruling.

—As I say, I am only an Acting Deputy President. I do not feel I should be in the position to set the rules, but merely follow the precedents. Senator Alston, I will pass that on to the President and get a proper ruling on `political thug'. Nevertheless, I still feel it is part of my duty to point out to Senator Baume, in all of his colourfulness—and he was one of the most colourful speakers in this debate—that he did weave around the word `lies' far too often and, by doing that, he did touch often on unparliamentary language.

PARA.TAB: Senator Baume, I know you know the rules. Tolerance was shown by the chair and the government in not taking the numerous points of order which could have been taken in your colourful speech. Senator Baume, I do not wish you to tone down your expressions or colourfulness, but I ask you to please read page 217 of Odgers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the way in which this debate has proceeded. If these are the new rules in terms of parliamentary procedures, so be it. I, for one, will be only too happy to join in a more robust, fulsome exchange that seems to be involved with these sorts of concepts.
—Fulsome? Do you know what it means?

—I know what you mean. I know precisely what you mean and what you are about. What those opposite are about here is quite clearly a policy designed to confuse, designed to obscure, what their policy position is. We will get to that because I am quite happy to engage in that policy debate. Quite clearly, what we have here though is a blatant political exercise, which is the nature of the political process. I am quite happy to concede that. But I say, `Don't come here in a sanctimonious way and claim that you are behaving with some degree of judicial objectivity, because that is clearly not the case.'

PARA.TAB: The motion before the Senate chamber says, quite clearly, that the Senate `expresses its grave concern'. For a start, once again, those opposite have prejudged the issues. They work from the presumption of fault. That is one of the standard operational procedures of the opposition in this place. That is the nature of opposition, I concede. But those opposite should not go on to the next point and say that they are behaving in an objective manner.

Quite clearly, this is not an objective Senate committee. This is a political committee, a political tribunal, which is out to produce a result. Quite clearly, it will produce a result in so far as those opposite are concerned because, as far as they have it, the decision has already been taken. It is all a question now of trying to drum up some basis for concluding the matters, as those opposite have already done.

There was a debate within this chamber just a few months ago about the nature of changes to the committee system. I recall the strong point was made that there was a need to reform the committee system, as it was put—to reform it, to double the workload, which is a really clever idea. But that was put in the form and on the basis that we would not need to have select committees. Already today we have seen two new ones being formed. When we get to the question of political integrity, I think those opposite are entitled to at least defend their position, because I say they have none—they have none when it comes to these matters.

I acknowledge that this committee will come forward to produce the results that those opposite are seeking. It will not necessarily convince anyone or change one opinion in this country. But I think we may as well get into it because those opposite have made it very clear what their attitudes are. We see in the papers just day by day, `Cross-media rules—Howard may let Packer have it all' as reported in the Sydney Morning Herald. Quite clearly those opposite have made their positions known. The article states:
The Federal Opposition Leader, Mr Howard, has refused to rule out allowing Mr Kerry Packer to acquire the Fairfax print media group while retaining ownership of the Nine Network.

SPEECH.PARA: I repeat, `has refused to rule out'. It continues:

PARA.TAB: Mr Howard was asked on Nine's A Current Affair program whether anyone should be allowed to own both print and television interests in the same market.

SPEECH.PARA: Those opposite have had the opportunity to spell out their position. But as Mr Howard has demonstrated on numerous occasions—and as those opposite have said—his attitude is that he is opposed to the cross-media laws as they currently exist. He is a market sort of person, as he says again and again and again. What he has is a position where he is committed to that policy—and he is committed on the basis that that is what he believes to be the way forward. That is fine. That is a political position he takes. I give him credit for making it clear what the Liberal Party position really is.

PARA.TAB: But what do we see from the opposition spokesman on this matter though? We see:

SPEECH.PARA: Coalition to look at toughening cross-media rules. The Federal Coalition has flagged a major overhaul—
says the Australian Financial Review today—
of the cross-media ownership rules, including extending the rules to telecommunications and multimedia and tightening up foreign investment guidelines.

What a farce, what an absolute farce! When the Fairfax committee brought down the majority report, we saw that it brought down all sorts of conclusions about foreign investment procedures, as were seen by the non-government members of that committee. What we saw then in the press conference immediately after the release of that report was Senator Alston saying, `Hang on a minute, this doesn't actually bind the coalition, it doesn't bind the shadow cabinet to any position.' Of course, that is the way it will always be, won't it. It will be a matter of taking the opportunistic position, stating a position publicly and implying that is what the attitude is of those opposite. But when it comes to the issue of actually determining a policy, we see a very different attitude emerging.

PARA.TAB: What Senator Alston has also said is that the current laws manifestly are not working. It happens to be very close to the position that Mr Packer has put that the cross-media rules are a joke. As far as I am concerned, if the cross-media rules are not working, why is Mr Packer so upset about them?

TALK.START.PARA: —Because they are stopping him buying a newspaper.

—Senator Collins is dead right. It operates in such a way as to protect diversity. It protects the Australian community and it provides a regulatory environment to ensure there is some competition, there is some diversity, and that broadcasters as well as print media owners operate in a responsible way in terms of the control of the media.

PARA.TAB: Given the nature of our society, I do not for a moment say that they are perfect. What I do say is that they are a damn side better than the proposition that you have been advancing: that the media barons take the lot; let Mr Packer take the lot.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order under standing order 194, which states that the speaker has to be relevant to the subject matter. We are quite happy to debate communications policy some day but if Senator Carr reads paragraphs (a), (b) and (c) he will see that this is not about media policy; it is about the Prime Minister's unsubstantiated allegation. Madam Acting Deputy President, I ask you to draw his attention to that and make his comments relevant to the matter of the debate.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator West)—Senator Tierney, from the times that I have been observing this debate it has been very wide ranging on both sides of the chamber. I rule Senator carr in order and remind him—

TALK.START.PARA: —He has not mentioned anything about the notice of motion.
—Senator Tierney, I am in the chair here.
—Don't be a political thug.
—Senator Collins, I do not need your help, either. I am sure Senator Carr is about to address the issues in the motion that has been moved and canvass other areas, like others have done.

—The motion shows the political concerns that you have about your position on media policy being exposed. Senator Alston raised the issue of the Liberal Party's policy in terms of 1987. The Democrats have raised their position on policy. It seems to be quite appropriate for everyone else to talk about their views of media policy but it is not appropriate for the government to do so. That is an irony in terms of the way in which this place works.

PARA.TAB: Quite clearly the Liberal Party is very concerned about the exposure that it has had to face on this matter. I put it to you very simply: why is it that members of the Liberal Party are so worried about standing up to the media barons in this country? Why is it that Mr Howard cannot manage to stand up to Mr Packer? Why is it that they cannot manage the tough decisions?

Why is it that they find it so difficult to come to a position on communications? With the cable regulations, the government made very clear its capacity to make the tough decisions to protect the public interests when it dealt with such matters as the Optus Vision consortium. Why is it that the coalition is so terrified of facing up to those issues?

We saw with Senator Alston today that the coalition is looking at toughening its attitude. It always looks. It gets the big mirror out and has a look into it. For the last eight years the coalition media policy has been under review. Why is it that there is a straight cover of their policy of abolition? That is their policy—abolition of any cross-media rules to protect the public interest, to protect diversity and to protect the cultural integrity of this country.

When this committee goes through its paces, as it inevitably will, I will pursue a few things as well. I want to know whether Mr Little Johnny Howard, Mr Honest Johnny Howard, as we heard before, or Senator Alston has given Mr Packer or any of his executives any understanding that a Howard government would weaken or abolish the cross-media laws. Why is it that Mr Howard was not even capable of giving a straight answer on whether or not he had had a conservation with Mr Packer on the cross-media rules after he became the leader?

Why was it that Senator Alston offered a different explanation, that there was indeed a conversation? Of course, the cross-media rules were not ever raised. Why is it that Mr Howard initially denied speaking to Mr Packer after resuming the leadership and then later admitted that he had spoken to him about these questions? Why is it that Mr Howard's position, as outlined in the petition of 1991, has changed from the position he has taken today? Why is it that the coalition policy has taken some eight years to review, and the coalition has not come up with any definitive answers other than to say that it is seeking to abolish the cross-media rules altogether?

If the coalition is so concerned to protect diversity, why is it that the coalition spokesman was the only significant player to support Mr Packer's claims about the cable network? Why is it that we have seen the coalition run from this very simple matter? Senator Baume today put the proposition that the coalition will not be hassled by making policies available to the Australian public. Why does it pursue such cynical and nakedly opportunistic policies in such a way as to avoid its responsibilities to come clean and to explain what its attitudes are to these important matters?

This committee will not produce any new material. It will not produce anything of value that will add to the question of policy debate that I think all of us wish to see. We may in fact wish to see a proper debate comparing in an objective way the coalition's policy with the government's policy. Let the public make that decision, as they undoubtedly will. Ultimately, that process will not be advanced by another one of these bogus, politically biased and prejudiced committees like this Fairfax committee. It has been discredited. It has not met for five months. It has no secretariat. One asks the question: what sorts of benefits have been picked up on the way through? It has not done any work for five months. Why do we go back to this committee? In terms of its original terms of reference it cannot be justified, other than that. Through this committee, the coalition is looking for a platform which it controls to advance its sordid political interests.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —It falls to me to sum up this debate for the opposition. I would like to remind the chamber and anyone else who is listening what this debate is really about. Having listened to the speakers on the other side, it seems as though they have not read this motion. I draw the Senate's attention to the most relevant paragraph, paragraph (b), which states:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—
(b) expresses its grave concern that neither the Prime Minister nor the Minister for Communications and the Arts has provided any evidence to support their allegations of a secret deal—

I think we could almost rest our case on the evidence supplied by the government here today. In essence, the government, Senator McMullan and Senator Carr got onto the policy debate for cross-media ownership rules. If there was one skerrick of evidence, anything they could really say, to substantiate the public claims of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), they would be in like a shot. They would be doing it here, publicly on the record now.

PARA.TAB: They are pretty silent on the real issue, the real substance of this motion. Not only are they silent today about this matter, but yesterday we saw the spectacle of Mr Justice Evans sitting opposite here ducking, weaving and not providing one shred of evidence. He is a candidate for the High Court. I hope that, if evidence like this were brought before him, he would toss it out straightaway. Not only has no evidence been produced, but the government has been totally irrelevant to the actual debate.

I wonder what the school children watching this debate think is happening about democracy in this country. I think it has been a very sad week or two for Australian politics when we have a Prime Minister acting as a bullyboy trying to intimidate people. I would like to take up Senator Baume's basic thesis. He said that the Prime Minister was operating in a very authoritarian manner. I note that John Howard called him Dr Goebbels and Senator Baume this morning promoted him to the Fuhrer. Although that is colourful, the real essence of the message is that there is no place in a democracy for this sort of authoritarian behaviour. There is no place in a democracy for the sort of political thuggery that we have seen in the last two weeks. There is no place in the Australian democracy for citizens who operate major businesses to be totally intimidated by the Prime Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Intimidate Packer! What a joke.

—You think it is a joke. Is anyone fair game? Even though they might be rich and powerful they are fair game, is that what you are saying? I put it to Senator Burns and Senator Collins that no-one is fair game in this sort of situation. In a democracy, prime ministers have an enormous amount of power and they should not use that power in this way. The Prime Minister has used this power across the full range from Kerry Packer to the humblest journalist. A journalist gets a phone call, `It is the Prime Minister on the line.' The Prime Minister then roars down the phone at that journalist. Senator Alston provided evidence of this. It involves distinguished journalists like Alan Ramsay and Laura Tingle. There is a range of evidence provided in this press release which shows how this Prime Minister time and time again has intimidated people with these sorts of bullyboy tactics.

PARA.TAB: One would think that if you are going to do that sort of thing—I already said that you should not—you want to make sure you are on safe ground. Let us look at the safe ground that this Prime Minister claims he is on. Where is his evidence? From the debate this morning, it is obvious that the government has absolutely no evidence on this matter. Why does it not have any evidence? It does not exist. It is as simple as that. Kerry Packer has denied it. John Howard has denied it. The senior journalists in Fairfax have denied it and even Richo has denied it. Yet again we have the full gamut. Why does the Prime Minister just not put up the evidence?

TALK.START.PARA: —He hasn't got any.

—As my colleague points out, he has not got any. I have discussed the effects on the Australian democracy of this truly appalling behaviour. It is very unfortunate that in the last two weeks this has taken on an international dimension and the Prime Minister is conducting domestic politics and bullying of citizens and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) from overseas. I find that absolutely appalling. What do these overseas leaders think of this Prime Minister and this country? He is supposed to be a diplomat when he is overseas. This would have to be the most undiplomatic behaviour since his attack on Dr Mahathir, the leader of Malaysia. He slips into the pattern of a bullyboy Prime Minister.

PARA.TAB: Let us put this into perspective and bring the Prime Minister to account in this country. We will be delighted when the Prime Minister returns. We will be delighted when he is back in question time. We will be delighted when the press has a chance to question him. As an opposition, we will be even more delighted to question him again. What he should do in regard to this particular matter is put up and shut up.

He has no evidence and the huge irony is that he is accusing the Leader of the Opposition of making deals. That has got to be the greatest joke coming from the prince of deals in this country. That is another pattern of behaviour of this Prime Minister. If we go back to his pre-selection at the age of 26 for the seat of Bankstown, we find that it is on the public record how he rorted his pre-selection. He should not be here. He did not get the vote until they changed it in a rather unusual way and he suddenly won.

We go through to the classic case in Australian political history of the secret deal at Kirribilli House—another deal maker. Coming closer to home and to this media issue, in Conrad Black's book we read about balanced coverage. That, of course, is code. Someone was using the word `code' earlier; I think it was Senator McMullan. It was stated, `We will increase your foreign stake if you provide balanced coverage.' In other words, `Give us a better run and we will give you more media ownership.' If that is not the classic deal in Australian political history, I do not know what is.

That matter was brought before the Senate print media inquiry. The Prime Minister was invited to appear. Of course, with his usual arrogance, he refused to do so. That is why, in this motion, we are asking for that committee to be reconvened. If the Prime Minister has any evidence—he is too arrogant to appear before a Senate committee—let us ask him to put his evidence in writing and then we will consider that evidence in an objective way.

What we must do in this country if democracy is to survive is get rid of these sorts of things that bring the whole process into disrepute. We have the sixth oldest democracy in the world. Democracy is a very fragile condition. In the whole sweep of human history it has been here for only a very short time and there is no guarantee that it will stay. The thing that will bring democracy down in the end will be cynicism in government—the sorts of deals that this Prime Minister has done and the sorts of silly, baseless accusations that he has made against innocent people. This sort of behaviour has to stop. If it does stop, it may raise the standard of politics in this country and democracy might have a better chance of surviving. I commend the motion to the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief. I would like to tell Senator Tierney the one thing we need in a democracy: some diversity in terms of the ownership of the media. John Howard has provided the proof that that is something he is not going to provide in government. People are concentrating on secret deals. John Howard has provided all the evidence that anyone would need that this deal has been done with the Packer organisation. He provided it last night on the Packer channel—Channel 9.

PARA.TAB: I do not know how anyone could watch John Howard's slippery-slidey performance delivered last night on Channel 9 and call him `Honest John'. For Senator Tierney's information, he might like to remember how Honest John got the nickname `Honest John'. It has been lost in the mists of time. It was not because he was honest. I think it was the Hobart Mercury that carried the headline, `Lies, lies, lies'. The word `honest' was put in quotation marks. It was ironically applied to Honest John because he had reneged, when he was Treasurer, on every single commitment he had made that would not appear in the budget.

Who could forget the most spectacular performance of all. As the outgoing Treasurer, knowing perfectly well that he was leaving behind what, in today's terms, was an enormous deficit of over $9 billion, John Howard looked straight down the barrel of a television camera in the election campaign and told everyone that it was going to be $6 billion. He knew that if he told the truth it would not only defeat his party but also blow it out of the water. So Honest John does not have a real good reputation.

But he excelled himself last night on the Packer-owned Channel 9 program by confirming again that what he told Mr Packer in private is what he has been saying publicly and the two things are exactly the same. I agree with him; they are the same. He said on Channel 9 last night that he does not believe in the cross-media rules. He said on Channel 9 last night that his public position is that he has no objection to one organisation—forget Kerry Packer, do not personalise this, do not put a name on it, you do not have to—controlling all of the major media, everything we see and read, in one region. That is exactly what he told Kerry Packer in private.

I confirm that, in public, John Howard has provided all the evidence and he will not do anything else. The Packer organisation knows that a Howard government will not stop it buying Fairfax, because Howard said it publicly. So it will control not only the major television channel in one market but also the major newspaper, and John Howard will not stop it. He confirmed it last night on the Packer-owned Channel 9 program.

Again, do not personalise this. I have nothing against Kerry Packer. Good luck to him if he is the richest man in Australia. I could not care less about that, but I do have an objection, like Senator Kernot has an objection, to one organisation owning all of the major media in one region. Our country has the most concentrated media ownership of any country. I deeply regret that. In a country like Great Britain, particular newspapers are known to have a Labour bias and others are known to have a Tory bias, and everyone in the country knows it. They know they get a diverse range of opinion from what they read in newspapers because newspapers are clearly identified as being middle of the road or having a right wing bias or a left wing bias.

In Australia, regrettably most of the major media is owned by a very small number of companies. They say these cross-media rules will not work. Why all the fuss if they do not work? Why all the screaming and yelling from the Packer organisation if they do not work? I will tell senators why: because they do work and because they effectively stop the Packer organisation controlling the major television channels in one region and the major newspapers in the same region. Those rules work, and that is why those companies are screaming about them.

What is the alternative government saying about that? The leader has said that he is opposed to those cross-media limitations. In other words, he does not need a private meeting with Mr Packer or anyone else—he has told Mr Packer on the public record as well as in private. John Howard has provided all the evidence anyone needs.

If you want to look at what use a media owner can make of his own media organisation, do not go past the A Current Affair interview with Mr Packer on Channel 9. I have great regard for Ray Martin; I have high regard for Ray Martin. I think Ray Martin has made a significant contribution in assisting the drought affected farmers of this country with the Farmhand appeal, but I have to tell you—it took a pretty strong stomach to watch the A Current Affair interview on this issue with Mr Packer on Mr Packer's own television program. When Ray asked Mr Packer what his thoughts were about becoming, first, Prime Minister of Australia and, second, to top that off, Australia's first president, I really had to reach for the sick bag. It was getting a bit strong. Everyone saw that interview. Everyone saw proof positive of the necessity to have at least a different opinion going in somewhere rather than having that sycophantic stuff. I mean, President Packer—fair crack of the whip!

It is a fact that one of the important things, Senator Tierney, about any democratic society is that there is some diversity in the ownership of the media. There is some diversity in what people can read and see. We say there should be. The Australian Democrats say there should be. You say there does not need to be. That is the big difference between the two approaches. John Howard, your leader, is on the public record as saying that he does not support the cross-media rules. In other words, not only has he told Mr Packer privately; he has told Mr Packer publicly that, as far as a Howard government is concerned, Mr Packer can own everything. He can have the newspapers in a region and the television channels in that region as well. More proof is not needed. John Howard once again provided it in spades on the Packer-owned Channel 9 program last night.

I do believe that, if the cross-media rules were not working, they would not be provoking the complaints we are getting right now. The fact is that they are provoking complaints, and where are those complaints coming from? From the organisation that wants to own everything in one region—something which is being prevented by these rules. I condemn the opposition as an Australian, not a Labor politician, for giving comfort to having those rules removed, for providing for a situation where we have an even greater concentration of media ownership in Australia than we have now and for giving Kerry Packer the green light publicly to be able to own all of the major newspapers and the major television channels in one area.

If you wanted a recent demonstration of the difficulty with allowing that, you do not need to look any further than the Packer organisation's own television channels and the run they have been giving their owner on this issue over the last few weeks. It has been sycophantic in the extreme. I do not think any Australian is better off for that. There are big differences between the two choices available to Australians at the next election on this issue of media ownership. This government has a view that it is undesirable for any of us in a democracy to have that situation, and you, Senator Tierney, are going to support it happening, and your leader has put the opposition's support for it on the record to his eternal shame.
Amendment agreed to.
Question put:
That the the motion (Senator Alston's), as amended, be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1994 [1995]

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report of Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee on Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1994 [1995], together with submissions and transcript of evidence.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion relating to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: The report I have just tabled is primarily concerned with rural adjustment and, in particular, the regional approach to adjustment. Senators will be aware that the references committee recently tabled a report on rural adjustment, recording unanimous support for a regional approach. During that inquiry, the committee was impressed with a pilot scheme in south-west Queensland.

PARA.TAB: The proposed amendments to the Rural Adjustment Act 1992 contained in this bill provide the mechanisms for a regional approach to rural adjustment. These mechanisms allow the Commonwealth to make grants or loans to persons other than states and territories; that is, individuals or groups.

I fully support a regional approach to RAS. I consider that there are circumstances where the Commonwealth can achieve important goals by being able to deal directly with individuals and groups in a particular region. Although the concept of regional RAS is supported by the committee, differences emerged as to how best this might be achieved and, in particular, what role the state and territory governments should play in this process.

As indicated in the report, the committee's task to review this legislation would have been considerably easier if the explanatory memorandum and the second reading speech had contained detailed information on the proposals. The report also records the committee's disappointment that state and territory RAS authorities were not fully consulted on specific amendments. The committee's report highlights a possible unintended consequence arising from the drafting process and calls on the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins) to clarify some important aspects of the bill before the Senate proceeds with the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with the comments made by Senator Burns. However, Senator Crane and I—Senator Crane will speak for himself in a moment—want to state our position a little differently from Senator Burns. The first thing that really disappointed me with this is the lack of consultation with the state authorities. Perhaps it was not intentional. It might have been done at a time that did not suit. That is a pity, because, since its inception, RAS has basically been done in a consultative way.
—It was this time, too, David. I talked to the ministers.

—The minister can tell us all this in a minute. The minister had not addressed the unintended consequences of the bill. It appears to us that the Commonwealth goes well beyond the RAS regional approach and goes to a more general RAS approach. That matter ought to be addressed in the legislation not merely by any formal or informal agreement that the minister might give to the Senate. It is all very well for him to say that this is his intent, but I believe it should be put in place much better. That came through in one consultation that Senator Burns had with one of the state authorities. That state authority was the Rural Finance Corporation in Victoria. It said of this unintended consequence:

SPEECH.PARA: The non-state component of the RAS is not confined to regional RAS. According to our reading of the bill, the proposed amendment will allow payments for any purpose under the scheme to be made by this mechanism. This would enable the Commonwealth to bypass states altogether and would cut across the general thrust of the scheme as it has operated for over 20 years; that is, that funding be handled by state authorities with the experience and knowledge to gain the best possible result for the funding available.

Perhaps there is a good explanation for that, but I do not think it has been properly explained to us. That is why Senator Crane and I agree that, in relation to the powers conferred, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins) should clarify the matter. The Senate, however, has considered that the bill must be amended to give effect to the stated intention. The rest of the committee has said that it would basically just like an explanation. We want it put into the legislation so that there is no further concern about it.

PARA.TAB: Another area that concerns me—we pointed it out in the report—is that it is imperative for regional adjustment to occur from the grassroots level up and not be imposed from above. Regional RAS will be successful only if it emanates from an area that wants to adjust all together in a similar way to south-west Queensland. Let us look at it as an example. It was done by the locals through the state government and then the Commonwealth. The Commonwealth came in and gave the funding.

I believe that there is nothing wrong with regional RAS or adjustment. We said that we commend it in our recent report. But I would not like to see the Commonwealth government imposing on an area the need to readjust. For example, it has been suggested that the Commonwealth would like to do some regional adjusting in the western division of New South Wales. I believe that it is up to the people there whether they want to adjust.

TALK.START.PARA: —Absolutely. We will not give them the money if they do not want it.

—Obviously, that will be explained, Minister. That was our other concern. I would also hope—we could get this explained or even put into the legislation—that the states would still be consulted and not just bypassed. Otherwise, we would most probably find that the Commonwealth would be annexing a part of a state because it would basically be the sole provider of money for that adjustment to the area. I say that a little bit tongue in cheek, although it has not hurt my tongue too much. We have to be careful that the explanations are right so that we do not put the wrong slant on the legislation.

PARA.TAB: When the bill came before our committee, our constitutional concerns were raised. For example, if the Commonwealth started to administer at the grassroots level, at the state level, then there could be a problem with constitutionality. Apparently, that has been fixed up. Even at this stage, the federal government gives money directly to individuals within states via farm household support and other welfare measures. But I believe this inquiry has achieved a fair bit. It has made the bill a little bit clearer to some people. I hope that, when the minister replies after Senator Crane has spoken, he will clarify some of these issues and tell us that he is going to amend the bill and fix the matter due to my concerns.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen A.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to make some comments about the motion moved by Senator Burns concerning the report of the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Committee on the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill. The first point I want to make is that I strongly favour in certain circumstances a regional approach to RAS. What concerns me—I understand we are getting amendments which we will have to make a judgment on when they come forward—is that, on examination, this was all-embracing legislation. On examination, what was in the second reading speech did not reflect what was proposed in the amendments to the legislation.

PARA.TAB: We have to point the finger at somebody for that happening. Was it the department which prepared the second reading speech and the amendments? Did the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins) deliberately come in here to deceive this chamber? I do not believe he did. Nonetheless, these questions have to be put on the public record because, when we examined this piece of legislation, we discovered that what was in the second reading speech and what was proposed in the amendments did not reflect each other. That is a well-known fact.

In my speech during the second reading debate, I deliberately put a series of questions on the public record to give the departmental officers the opportunity to prepare responses before they appeared before the committee. I appreciate the pressures placed upon them by us. But, for whatever reason, they chose not to deal with the questions I raised in my speech during the second reading debate. Before the committee they went into discussions on the legislation without an opening statement. I found that very disappointing. In fact, I could go so far as to say that it was a dereliction of their duty to this chamber. We came in here and asked those questions so that the departmental officers could look at them. We asked those questions in a genuine endeavour to improve the legislation and make it better understood, but the departmental officers ignored them.
I want to draw the attention of honourable senators to a couple of questions I asked in my speech. I asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Is it the intention, for example, to gradually phase them out?

I was talking about the various state rural adjustment arrangements or schemes. Certainly, under the legislation that was before us, that could have been done. I believe that I asked a valid and fair question at that time. But, for whatever reason, the departmental officers chose to ignore it. Further in my speech I said:
. . . and I give notice to the people from the department who are coming to that committee, that we need to have some very specific, precise answers to some of the things that have been raised here.

I want to put on the public record that the officers from the Department of Primary Industries and Energy chose not to address those issues in a formal manner when they appeared before the committee, and I find that very disappointing.

PARA.TAB: I would now like to go to the issue of consultation with the states. I note from what Senator Brownhill said that Senator Collins said that it would not work unless there was a grassroots approach to the whole matter. I think we all acknowledge that. But, once again, if that were really the intent, then I think some more homework should have been done.

I particularly wish to quote from a letter from the Rural Adjustment and Finance Corporation in Western Australia. That letter sums up, particularly for Western Australia and, I understand, some other states, that there was, at best, very little consultation. I do acknowledge that we were given information that there were discussions with Queensland—and there is a scheme in Queensland already—and also it would appear that there were more in-depth discussions with South Australia. The Rural Adjustment and Finance Corporation in Western Australia stated:

SPEECH.PARA: In practical terms, the involvement of RAS in rural area development will inevitably require in-depth consultation and support from the grassroots up.
That is a point that we have already made. It continued:

Whilst assurances about continued consultation with States over RAS initiatives has been given in evidence to the Senate Committee by Commonwealth officials, the Corporation questions the necessity for the Commonwealth to seek such open ended powers. The Western Australian Government would have serious reservations about conferring any such open ended powers on the Commonwealth which would enable it to intrude into matters that are seen to be of particular interest and responsibility of the State. It is a strong advocate of a co-operative approach to these issues.

In relation to the second matter of direct payments to organisations rather than farmers, the Corporation has sought amendments to the Commonwealth "policy guidelines", particularly in relation to the administration of RAS Skill Enhancement Program, to allow the Corporation to make direct payments to organisations delivering skill development or training courses to farmers. The current policy guidelines require the State administering bodies to provide financial support to farmers. The flexibility being sought will offer administration cost reductions for the reasons outlined to the Senate Committee by officers of the Commonwealth Department of Primary Industries and Energy . . . and ensure more of the limited moneys for normal RAS programs available to support farmers rather than unnecessary administrative costs.

The mechanics of achieving the flexibility have not been discussed in any detail by the Commonwealth with the State. The Corporation is unaware of whether amendments to the policy guidelines or the Act would be necessary to extend this flexibility to State administering bodies. It is not a matter on which the Corporation has sought legal advice, and has initially sought endorsement of the principle with the mechanics of how this would be achieved to be resolved subsequently.
I put to the minister this particular query about flexibility and what exists currently in the states and ask: does it actually extend to the programs that are being administered by the states?

PARA.TAB: In making those comments, I re-emphasise the particular points that I made about the necessity for a grassroots approach, the necessity to recognise the responsibilities of the states in terms of land management, and I put on the public record that, unless there are detailed discussions with the states about how this is going to operate, how the various processes for regional reconstruction are going to occur, then this legislation, the intent of which I believe is right, will be doomed to failure.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the following matters be referred to the Economics References Committee for inquiry and report on or before 11 May 1995:
(1)The proposed Eastlink high voltage powerline between Armidale, New South Wales, and Springdale, Queensland, with particular reference to:

TAB.TAB: (a)the possible impact of the powerline and the accompanying land resumptions on:
(i)the health of people and animals in surrounding areas, with particular reference to the likely effects of electromagnetic field radiation,
(ii)the vegetation and overall environment, and
(iii)the social fabric and local economic viability of surrounding communities, including the likely loss of agricultural land;
(b)the overall economic impact of the powerline;
(c)the likely impact of the powerline on overall levels of electricity consumption, with reference to Australia's obligations and commitment to reduce greenhouse gas emissions;
(d)the viability of renewable energy sources to provide electricity to Queensland consumers, instead of expanding the consumption of coal generated electricity; and
(e)the adequacy of the community consultation process undertaken by Government bodies with those people and local authorities in the areas which will be affected by the powerline.

PARA.TAB: (2)That the committee, in the context of the Eastlink powerline, review relevant Federal and State Government reports on electricity supply, including the 1992 report of the Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology into gas and electricity, to assess whether issues raised in these reports have been adequately addressed in the Eastlink proposal.

SPEECH.PARA: I initially gave notice of this reference on 9 February, exactly one month ago. I have postponed consideration of this matter twice to enable senators to have more time to consider the issues, but it is a pressing matter.

PARA.TAB: Those people who live in the area surrounding the proposed powerline are extremely concerned about Eastlink and have been pushing strongly for a Senate inquiry. They have been very unhappy with the lack of consultation with state governments and the apparent inadequate consideration of many aspects of Eastlink. The Senate has already received well over 2,000 signatures from people in the area asking for the Senate to inquire into the matter. As it is a matter that involves at least two states, it is appropriate that the Senate do so.

Coalition members from Queensland Mr Bruce Scott and Mr Bill Taylor have publicly expressed support for an inquiry, and the National Party at state level has expressed total opposition to Eastlink. I hope coalition and government senators will support my motion so that the Senate is able to fulfil its role as a chamber of review and a chamber which ensures that governments are accountable for the decisions they make.

I acknowledge a reply from Senator Ian Macdonald to my request to consider this matter. I understand that the coalition prefers to wait for a briefing to be given to the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport References Committee. I need to point out that that briefing itself has been delayed twice—firstly, because of the tragic death of Senator Zakharov and, secondly, because a briefing set to take place yesterday was cancelled.

I need to tell the Senate that, while all of this is going on, the state government in Queensland in particular has been simply sailing ahead. In media reports in Queensland in recent days, the Queensland government has made statements such as, `We do not care what the Senate says'—particularly referring to the 1992 report of the Senate—`We are simply going to go ahead.'

I believe that this wide ranging inquiry will look at all the issues, not just the ones which will be given in a briefing to the Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Referencdes Committee, and especially those which are of concern to the people who will be affected. In drawing the Senate's attention to the terms of reference, I need just to underline that they refer to concerns about the health of people and animals in the area; the vegetation and overall environment; the social fabric and local economic viability of surrounding communities, including the likely loss of agricultural land; and the adequacy of the consultation process undertaken by government bodies.

I will place on the record just a couple of examples of the concerns had by local farmers in the area. Judy Whistler, one of the people in the area, has written to me and said that she was approached by a local cattle property owner who has a stud farm. He has been advised that buyers are being scared off by the idea of having powerlines near his $30,000 stud bulls. He sells these bulls all over the world and exports their semen. Terry Larsen of TOTA has relayed information that some feedlot farmers have been told by Koreans and Japanese that they will not buy their stock if the powerline is built on properties near the stock. These situations indicate that there is great uncertainty amongst the communities being affected. This is not being alleviated by the state governments in either Queensland or New South Wales.

The Senate has a clear role to play. It should act now and not delay further, because this is simply dragging out the concerns of these people. I would point out that it is not simply a matter of being against something; there are many possibilities to be opened up for alternative energy. I would also point out that a recent press report spoke of a wind farm in Western Australia which has created $700,000 worth of savings in energy costs in the first year of operation, according to energy minister Colin Barnett. I would place on record that there are alternatives. People are opposed to the Eastlink powerline going ahead. The implications of Eastlink will mean higher greenhouse gas emissions because it will be using Hunter Valley stations rather than the new gas-fired plants in Queensland. The people in northern New South Wales, southern Queensland and increasingly in Brisbane see Eastlink as an environmental issue. The community sees itself being forced to pay in reduced land values, health risks, et cetera, for a project that will subsidise future power station owners. The unpopularity of the project is overwhelmingly clear. I seek the support of the Senate for the motion relating to this reference.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —As there are only two minutes left before the allocated time runs out, I will briefly indicate to Senator Woodley and the Senate that the government will be opposing this motion. The government does not believe that a Senate inquiry would be appropriate for a number of reasons—namely, many of the concerns that have been outlined by Senator Woodley in his motion revolve around environmental considerations. The formal environmental impact statement process is yet to commence, and we would expect that many of the problem areas would be resolved when the EIS goes on display in mid-November 1995.

PARA.TAB: From the Commonwealth government's viewpoint, the fact is that New South Wales and Queensland have prime jurisdictional responsibility for Eastlink, with state utilities having the required technical expertise and day to day management over the feasibility study, and the final decision to build Eastlink rests solely with the states. The Commonwealth has supported consideration being given to the construction of Eastlink as an early option in helping Queensland's future electricity supply needs and as a major component in the creation of a competitive multistate electricity market. The Commonwealth has certainly encouraged the assessment of the Eastlink proposal and agreed to contribute up to $7 million in the funding of a feasibility study over the period 1993-94 to 1995-96. The Commonwealth funding is to be matched by both the New South Wales and the Queensland governments.

In summary, we believe that it would be inappropriate for this inquiry to take place at a time when the environmental impact statement is yet to be completed and when the decisions regarding the proposal's ultimate future are for the states to decide rather than the Commonwealth.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is clearly a need for further information on this subject.

DEBATE.TITLE: PRAWN BOAT LEVY BILL 1994PRAWN EXPORT CHARGE BILL 1994PRAWN EXPORT PROMOTION BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 9 February, on motion by Senator Faulkner:
That these bills be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to commend Australia's prawn industry. The coalition welcomes and supports the Prawn Boat Levy Bill 1994, the Prawn Export Charge Bill 1994 and the Prawn Export Promotion Bill 1994, which are being debated cognately here today.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Prawn Promotion Association was formed four years ago to address the decline in Australia's market share and earnings. This decline, caused mainly by competition in overseas markets from aquacultured prawns, is a major concern for this industry, which earns some $197 million a year in export income. Given the importance of these earnings and the precarious state of our balance of trade, it is commendable that the prawn industry is taking matters into its own hands. The Australian Prawn Promotion Association began by seeking federal government assistance to increase the export value of sea-caught prawns, particularly in the important Asian markets. The association has now developed a self-help strategy that aims to promote its product in innovative ways as well as differentiate Australian sea-caught prawns from the overseas farmed product.

In turn, the federal government has agreed to collect funds for the scheme by means of a prawn boat levy and prawn export charge. The following groups have agreed to this levy: the National Fishing Industry Council; the Queensland Commercial Fishermen's Association; the Western Australian Northern Trawler Operators Association; the Western Australian Fishing Industry Council; the Australian Fisheries Management Authority; the Spencer Gulf Association of South Australia; the Shark Bay Association of Western Australia; and the Northern Prawn Fisheries Queensland Trawl Association. The money collected by the Commonwealth will be paid to the Fisheries Research and Development Corporation to promote sea-caught prawns or product of such prawns. All promotional activities will require approval from the Australian Prawn Promotion Association Ltd on behalf of its members.

The amount of levy will be determined by the Australian Prawn Promotion Association and prescribed by regulation. However, the maximum permissible amount of levy per boat is $75 for a ship less than 10 metres, $150 for a ship more than 10 metres but less than 15 metres, $300 for a ship more than 15 metres but less than 18 metres, and $750 in the case of a ship not less than 18 metres. The amount of export charge is not to exceed 10c a kilogram of the net weight of the sea-caught prawns. There will be an exemption for exporters who export less than 5,000 kilograms of sea-caught prawns or their product in a financial year.

As my colleague the shadow minister for primary industry, Mr John Anderson, noted in the other place recently, there is occasional debate about the appropriateness of industries imposing levies on themselves. In other words, there is concern that the industries effectively bind all their members, irrespective of differences in views. But the evidence is that, where these schemes are properly conducted and accountable, the benefits to industry participants and to Australia's economic performance represent a substantial improvement.

The nation has, in the coalition's view, benefited enormously from the research and development grant arrangements that now apply to virtually all of our primary industries. These approaches have enjoyed bipartisan support, and I hope that will continue to be the case. The coalition therefore supports this package of bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —My colleague Senator Tambling has clearly and concisely indicated the coalition's position on these bills. I do not need to reiterate what my colleague has said. However, I would like to do something that I do not often do, and that is to be just a fraction parochial in a couple of very brief comments. The prawn industry is very important to Queensland generally and particularly to north Queensland. It provides lots of jobs and a lot of export dollars for Australia and, importantly, for north and far north Queensland and the gulf areas.

PARA.TAB: Many communities rely on the prawn industry for their very existence and continuation. Certainly, the prawn industry is very important to the gulf area, and it is similarly the case right along the coast of far north Queensland. I think I can say without fear of challenge in this place that north Queensland prawns are amongst the tastiest in the world. They are really a magnificent product. I see that Senator Boswell is going to speak, and I am quite sure that he will elaborate on that.

I would like to briefly mention the viability of commercial fishing, including prawn trawlers, in Cooktown. That viability is being held back because the port at Cooktown is too shallow to allow larger boats in. Whilst recreational vessels can access the port using tides, commercial vessels running to schedules and deadlines cannot. On 7 July this year, the $17 million replica of the bark Endeavour, which will be touring the east coast of Australia on an historic journey marking the 225th anniversary of Captain Cook's voyage, will be unable to access the port of Cooktown. This is where the original Endeavour spent 47 days way back in the very early days of white settlement of Australia. The new Endeavour replica will be unable to access the port because it is too shallow.

Despite several representations from the people of Cooktown, the Queensland government has refused to dredge the area because of yet to be substantiated environmental concerns. The harbour has been dredged previously. Hydrographic surveys show that, while the low tide mark is presently 1.2 metres, in 1991 it was 1.4 metres and in 1949 it was 2.7 metres. The dredging of the harbour would involve removing approximately 200,000 cubic metres of silt from an area 700 metres long by 100 metres wide and three metres deep at a cost of around $500,000.

As senators would know, Cooktown is a viable port for maritime tourism and commercial fishing. However, these industries have not been able to expand. In fact, tourism visits will be reduced this year because of inadequate access to the port. A proposal has been made to enter the Endeavour off Grassy Hill in Cooktown and to ferry residents out to the ship to have a look at it. This is unacceptable as the transportation process would be unsafe; there would be unrealistic weather expectations; and the ship will, of necessity, be anchored one kilometre offshore in deep and exposed waters.

I hope that the federal government will get involved in this by undertaking immediate environmental assessments on the effect of dredging on the surrounding environment of the port of Cooktown to ensure that it occurs in an environmentally sound manner in time for the visit of the Endeavour. It would also open up the port of Cooktown to allow for the area's expansion of tourism and prawn fishing operating out of the port of Cooktown. With those few remarks, I again support what Senator Tambling has said and indicate that the coalition will be supporting these bills.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I support Senator Ian Macdonald's statement that the trawling and prawning industry is most important for the Torres Strait, the gulf and North Queensland. We are debating three bills—the Prawn Boat Levy Bill 1994, the Prawn Export Charge Bill 1994 and the Prawn Export Promotion Bill 1994. These bills will introduce research and development funding for the fishing industry—funding that will be used for the promotion of prawn exports.

PARA.TAB: The initiative for a promotion fund for the export of prawns came from the industry through the Australian Prawn Promotion Association. It will be an industry funded, self-help promotional fund. Its main benefit will be to promote the export and development of sea-caught Australian prawns, particularly into the Asian market. Promotion is seen by the industry as an essential tool to expanding its export markets. Australian sea-caught prawns will have the benefit in the international markets of being superior quality prawns that have been caught in pristine and very clean and green Australian seas. The industry is to be congratulated on its initiative in coming together to promote its excellent product and to expand its export markets to the ultimate benefit of the industry and Australian export earnings.

The levy consists of two parts. The first part is an annual levy imposed on the owners of commercial prawn boats, which increases with the size of the ship. The second part is a charge imposed on sea-caught prawns or their products which is paid by the exporter. At this point, I pay tribute to the fishermen of North Queensland for their commitment to the concept of promotion. Queensland boat owners will be making a large contribution to the $0.5 million promotion fund because of the larger proportion of boats in Queensland than in other states.

Of the 475 DPI registered boats, 370 come from Queensland ports. The contribution will no doubt be a double impost on the fishermen as the further contribution will inevitably fall on the fishermen through the levy imposed on the exporting processes being passed through to the producer, the fisherman. The industry will endeavour to use this new prawn promotion fund to promote sea-caught prawn exports in the most effective way. It is significant that, due to the foresight of the industry in setting up this fund, it will be in a position to compete in the near future when Taiwan and China work through their present problems with prawn farms.

I take this opportunity to address the Senate more generally on the issue of rural research and development and the concerns of rural industry at the suggested cuts to rural research and development contained in the draft report of the Industry Commission. The Industry Commission report suggests a scaling down of the government's rural research and development contribution from the present dollar for dollar contribution equally from the industry and the government to the industry being required to contribute $4 for every $1 from the government. I speak on behalf of all primary industries when I say that this is totally unacceptable.

Having established the highly productive regime of rural research and development over recent years and having seen the benefit it contributes, it would be ludicrous for the government to accept the recommendation of the Industry Commission. For the government to put its budget concerns ahead of the real financial returns that flow from rural research and development would be totally short-sighted. In a country like Australia, rural research and development should be treated like a sacred cow. The scientific advances and the opportunities for scientists to contribute within Australia to the rural industry development that has arisen from rural R&D funds have been enormous.

The government matching rural R&D funding schemes has helped all rural industries, ranging from large ones such as the grain industry through to small horticulture industries. It has further provided a vehicle for industries to increase their R&D funding to the scheme target of 0.05 per cent of gross value of production.

To cut any funding by three-quarters would bring an enormous amount of research to a standstill. The small banana industry, important to Queensland and northern New South Wales, says that a reduction of this magnitude would see their R&D programs come to an abrupt halt and many valuable projects would have to be shelved. The banana industry rightly sees the government contribution to R&D funding as an investment not as a support and, by observing their present R&D projects, it illustrates that many public benefits will flow from this R&D funding. I refer to projects such as specific disease control which prevents the use of chemicals which, in turn, do so much costly damage to our rivers and waterways. Research and development benefits the consumer through increased yield and it has to proceed in our rural industries.

In supporting these bills, and the initiative of the fishing industry in setting up their own prawn export promotion fund, I applaud the initiative and planning of the Australian fishing industry. Having regard to the benefits to both specific industries and the public, I also call on the government to listen to all other rural industries and continue the existing R&D funding arrangements.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank senators for their contributions. The government's wide support for this legislation, the Prawn Boat Levy Bill 1994, the Prawn Export Charge Bill 1994 and the Prawn Export Promotion Bill 1994, is clear in the second reading speech. I did note that a couple of senators strayed into other areas not directly related to the legislation. Senator Boswell's comments about the Industry Commission draft report are noted. However, he understands that all the industries now have an opportunity to comment on the draft report. Those agricultural research organisations and corporations that he mentions can certainly do that, and I am sure they will take that opportunity. The government will then respond in detail after the final report is tabled. It is a report that covers many areas of R&D. I am sure that, in the total picture, the government will be able to respond to what is a major review of R&D in Australia. I commend the bills to the Senate.
