TALK.START.PARA: —My question without notice is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. A survey of Australian hotels conducted by Arthur Anderson for the Australian Hotels Association reveals that 68 per cent of hoteliers believe a bed tax would reduce demand, resulting in job loses.
—Almost 80 per cent said that they would consider cancelling expansion, refurbishing and reinvestment plans, which means even more job losses.

—As the survey clearly confirms, a bed tax will cost thousands of jobs, which obviously those opposite are not interested in. You have destroyed the jobs. You are not interested in creating jobs. Why do you continue to refuse to state that a bed tax will not be a revenue item in the budget?

—The interjections speak for themselves and I hope Hansard was busily recording them. What a phoney you are. Where were you when Fightback was being written? What did you have to say about the 15 per cent proposal? What is your judgement about the tax implications of Fightback on the industry you purport to represent? You are a pack of phoneys and frauds.
—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. The question relates to the government's intended bed tax. It was a specific question on that subject and he should try to answer the question.
—He can rule it out. He can stand there and rule it out. You ruled out the carbon tax in the end, you can rule this one out.

—I rise on the point of order, Mr President. We now have a recasting of the question. Senator Hill describes it as the government's intended tax. There is no such proposal in which you can describe it as an intention, yet we have the question being proposed as a political slogan. In those terms, given that this is the adversarial form of politics we have in Australia and this is clearly a politically inspired question, surely the government can answer the question across the wide range of political debate that occurs in this country. To try to pretend that this is a question narrowly focused and seeking information about a specific thing is to be idle and wrong. The Leader of the Government in the Senate would be quite appropriate to canvass the whole issue in the full political context in which it arises.

—I believe that if a question loaded with invective is asked, it almost begs invective in return; but I do not think it helps, Senator Evans, to be attacking the opposition almost exclusively rather than answering the question. I ask you to answer the question.

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. I want to draw to your attention the fact that you can cast inferences on not only an individual but also a group. For example, Senator Evans on this occasion said, `You're a pack of phoneys and frauds.' Mr President, am I allowed to call you a fraud? Every time you elect to ignore something that happens on the other side, can I stand up and, in my point of order, say, `You're a fraud in that position because you're pretending to be independent'? Can I say that? I bet not. It seems, Mr President, that you sometimes let it pass you by that your obligation is not simply to rule on points of order made but also to keep order in this place, and that means to keep them to the standing orders.
—I thought I had already done that. I have already criticised Senator Evans for his answer.

—If I may say so, Mr President, two very statesman like rulings, particularly as directed to me. Well done. Of course it is the case that the Department of Tourism has commissioned a study to investigate the issue of a bed tax. I have acknowledged that; Mr Lee has frankly acknowledged that. But that certainly does not mean the government has decided to introduce any such tax. Naturally, we would consider the impact of such a tax on employment and investment in the hotel, the hospitality, industry were we minded to go down that particular path.
—Minister, isn't the real reason why you will not rule out a bed tax that it is in fact on the list of new taxes the government intends to introduce in the budget?

—The real reason is that this particular government is a responsible government that wants to weigh, balance and consider all revenue options available to us and is not going to give you any free kicks one way or another along the way, so eat your heart out.

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President's gallery of a parliamentary delegation from the Standing Committee on Communication of the House of Representatives of Thailand led by the Chairman, Mr Samak Sundarevej. On behalf of honourable senators, I have pleasure in welcoming you to the Senate and trust that your visit will be both enjoyable and productive.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. The minister is clearly aware of Geoffrey Blainey's re-emergence into the immigration debate yesterday with a speech in which he claims that our citizenship policies are a disgrace and that the fact that Australians speak more than one or two languages reduces us to the level of monkeys. Given that Australia is hosting the first global cultural diversity conference in Sydney next month, can the minister outline how Geoffrey Blainey's remarks sit with the current domestic and international thinking on migration and citizenship?

—I thank Senator McKiernan for his question. I must say that it was disappointing to see Geoffrey Blainey emerging once again from his Jurassic park yesterday with what has to be the most backward and offensive speech since 1984 when he got it so dramatically wrong on Asian immigration. I welcome this opportunity to reject unequivocally his discriminatory and divisive approach to immigration and citizenship policy. I call on all sides of parliament to do the same.

PARA.TAB: Blainey starts with a monocultural view and an isolationist view of Australia and our role in the world. He claims that we have thrown away citizenship because we have an inclusive approach which respects diversity. Nothing could be further from the truth. It is his approach, built on a supremacist view, which would erode the value of citizenship. Blainey claims democracy was healthier 40 to 60 years ago, yet this was the time when our indigenous people could not vote, when women had to leave the Public Service when they married, when the white Australia policy was flourishing and when only British subjects automatically had a say in how the country was run without Australian citizenship.

TALK.START.PARA: —Part of your platform.

—I do not know why Senator Vanstone is defending him. Just let me go on with the answer. Essentially, Blainey still believes that only migrants of English speaking background have the capacity to participate in our parliamentary democracy and to grasp the values and the fundamentals—
—Have you read the speech.

—I have indeed—of equality and tolerance. The government's view is different from this. We believe that all people, regardless of race or colour, have the capacity and the skills to participate fully. In fact, the history of Australian migration, no matter where our migrants have come from, is evidence of that.

PARA.TAB: All those who have come here for a better life or have fled persecution in their homeland know that migrants and refugees do not move to Australia just for the hell of it. They come here because of the values and principles that Senator McKiernan talked about and I have outlined and because they will not be condemned to a life of second-class citizens or, worst still, non-citizens. The discriminatory policy that Professor Blainey talks about does operate. It does exist in other countries. It has been directly responsible for the creation of underclasses and ugly racial division in those countries.

Senator McKiernan referred to the global cultural diversity conference to be held in Sydney in April. Australia's inclusive multicultural policies and its inclusive citizenship policies will be showcased at that conference as one of the fundamentals of our success. We do make citizenship available to people after two years permanent residence. Blainey of course is wrong to suggest they can be away for 12 months of that time. When people make that commitment, we do not ask them to assume a monocultural mantle and leave their religions or cultures behind.

For instance, the government's current citizenship promotion campaign makes it quite clear that citizenship is the common bond which unites all Australians. When people become citizens they make a commitment not only to Australia's people, our law, our democratic system, but also to a way of life which does respect that cultural diversity. It celebrates it as well.

Underpinning their pledge is a commitment to English as a common language. That commitment is explicit not only in our national agenda for multicultural Australia but also in the increased level of funding the federal government provides in each year for English language services. That is why migrants learn English and that is why the percentage of Australians who do not speak English was less than one per cent at the last census.

I repeat my call to all political parties to reject Blainey's divisive approach, his discriminatory approach, and to affirm their support for cultural diversity and non-discriminatory citizenship policies. His views are as wrong and irrelevant in 1995 as they were in 1984. Happily and gladly, his view is of the minority group and that group is shrinking most rapidly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer. The minister is obviously aware of the wide-ranging parliamentary inquiry that was conducted throughout last year and the report presented to the parliament in October entitled Australians all: Enhancing Australian citizenship. Is the minister aware if Geoffrey Blainey, with his deep interest in the question of Australian citizenship, put in a submission to that committee and had that committee test his views on the issue of Australian citizenship?

—It seems to be a characteristic of Professor Blainey to throw bombs but not to have them tested. My appreciation is that he did not put his views to the parliamentary committee to be tested. Were he to have done so he may have learned something out of them because that parliamentary inquiry took an international perspective, looked at the way Australian citizenship laws work and looked at the way citizenship laws work in other countries. It found that the inclusive approach that we have, an approach which embraces people and makes them full and equal partners in our society, is the most cohesive way to go. Unfortunately, Professor Blainey did not avail himself of that oppor tunity.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Royal Australian Air Force: Richmond Base

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. Yesterday the Chief of the Air Staff said on television that RAAF Richmond is to be closed because the new airport at Badgery's Creek will make it inoperable, although your colleague the Minister for Transport said that this was nonsense. Will you tell the Senate who is telling the truth—Air Marshal Fisher or minister Brereton? What is the time frame for the closure of the base? What is the estimated cost of the relocation of the base and where is it to be relocated? Will this additional cost be met by a special increase to the defence budget or will it have to be found out of the already diminishing forward estimates?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no intention by either Air Marshal Fisher or myself to close the Richmond air base. Air Marshal Fisher attended a function there yesterday and went out of his way to assure people that there was no threat to the closure of Richmond in the short or medium term, that is, through to the year 2010. The media spin that was put on that was reflected on the ABC news last night. They said in their lead:

ANSWER.PARA: It is official. The RAAF Richmond air base is to close.

Forty-five minutes before that they had rung my office to seek clarification, but still ran the story. As Air Marshal Fisher said to me this morning: `Minister, you did not warn me when I got the job the sort of media spin that could be put on any comments.' That is precisely what this story is about. The same sorts of stories emerged just before the last New South Wales election. I will not go to who promoted those particular views at the time.

PARA.TAB: I cannot guarantee the survival of any air base beyond 15 years. I cannot see that far into the future. There are some problems at Richmond with urban encroachment—and remember, we do a lot of touch and go landings there with the Hercules fleet. When Badgery's Creek becomes fully operational there will be some inhibitions on those activities. But it is very unlikely, even beyond the year 2000, that Richmond would close given the large sunk infrastructure costs that were put in. In summary, Air Marshal Fisher did not say that it was bound to close.

TALK.START.PARA: —Inoperable.
—He did not say that it was bound to close. He said at that particular function that it would not close in the short to medium term.
—The spin you put on it clean-bowled him.
—No, not at all.
—Didn't you see what he said?

—Yes, I did see what he said. I have a transcript of what he said. I do not know if you have a transcript of what he said. It is not to deflect from our long-term plan, stated on the public record as few as two weeks ago at Nowra by me, that Richmond airbase will be there in the short to medium term. If the word `inoperable' was used, Air Marshal Fisher has clarified that as not to mean that the base will close. He has done that on the phone this morning.

PARA.TAB: I should state for the record: I encourage the chiefs to speak to the press—that has not always been government policy—because I believe it is not only their duty but their right to be able to speak out on public issues. I have also been on the public record to the effect that if they make a mistake in that—there was no mistake made this time—or if the media put a particular spin on it, I just accept that because I would not want to see a situation where I ever direct the chiefs not to appear publicly or not to address the press.

This is just a furphy belted up for the New South Wales election, not by the opposition but by the media, looking for a cheap story, which appeared on the ABC. Having checked the story with my office, it still ran the story. It was not run on any other ABC news earlier due to daylight saving. It was run on the Sydney news 45 minutes after the ABC checked with my office to see whether the story was correct or not.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the minister deny that the coming of Badgery's Creek into full operation will make RAAF Richmond inoperable, as the air chief said on television last night?

—What I have already said in this answer is that if Badgery's Creek comes on full stream it may affect some operations, such as touch and go landings, at Richmond. Those aspects may have to be transferred elsewhere, but the actual situation of the planes, the maintenance of the planes, the loading of the planes—

PARA.TAB: Senator Newman interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are putting your interpretation. I would prefer to rely on the Chief of Air Staff's interpretation of what he said to me today rather than on the gloss that you put on it.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is the minister in a position to comment on media reports suggesting that the Australian government has abandoned the two Cambodians who helped to recover the remains of Kellie Wilkinson from the Khmer Rouge last year? Is there any truth to these reports? What are the actual circumstances?

—I am very disappointed at the immediate assumption by some media commentators of bad faith on the part of the government in this matter. There has been none at any stage and I hope the terms of my answer now will make that very clear. I will first give some background.

PARA.TAB: The operation to recover the remains of Kellie Wilkinson and her two British colleagues was one conceived and run by the Cambodian police. The two people whom the government is alleged to have abandoned were working as operatives for the Cambodian police, not for the Australian or British governments. Both Australia and the UK had police from the AFP and New Scotland Yard in Sihanoukville during the investigation into the abduction and murder of Kellie and her friends. Their role was to monitor Cambodian investigations first into what happened to the three and then, when it became unhappily clear that they had almost certainly been murdered, to recover evidence of their death.

During these operations, absolutely no commitment to provide moneys for the relocation or reward of the two Cambodian operatives was made by any Australian. I am certainly not aware, either, of any commitment being made by officers from New Scotland Yard. On 1 September, some two weeks after the remains had been recovered, the two operatives approached the British and Australian embassies in Phnom Penh for money to pay for relocation. This was followed up on 13 September by a formal request from the governor of Kampong Som. He sought $US60,000 for each operative for their relocation.

The request was then considered by the Australian and British governments. It was certainly considered very sympathetically. We were grateful for what the operatives had done in finding and returning the remains. We certainly acknowledged that they had undertaken some significant risks in order to do so. Our embassy accordingly recommended that a sum of money be provided for relocation. That recommendation was supported by the AFP and approved by the Department of Finance on 15 December last year as an act of grace payment.

It was agreed with the British government, taking into account local factors, such as the cost of living and so on—I will come to that in more detail in a moment—that the sum to be paid should be $US7,000. The monies were paid to each operative by governments on 19 January. Each operative thus received a total of $US7,000 for relocation costs. At the time, they were required to sign a waiver of further claims, which they did. They were reported at the time to seem satisfied and grateful for the payments.

It needs to be understood that $US7,000 is a lot of money in Cambodia. The average income in the country is only $US214 per annum. Many Cambodians in rural areas, where these chaps come from, would earn much less than this. Civil service and military salaries, for example, are between $15 and $20 per month. Again, as a further example, under the special assistance program, Cambodian refugees who are returned to Cambodia from Australia are paid $250 per family and then given $US30 per adult and $US15 per child per month for the next 12 months.

We checked this morning what we could find out in the short time available about housing relocation costs. Our post tells that us that in Takeo province, which is next to Kampot, a plot of land would cost between $US1,500 and $US4,000, depending on how close it is to a rice field and considerations of that kind. A peasant's house would cost in the order of $2,500. Obviously, land would cost considerably more in the cities and major towns, but clearly $7,000 is a lot of purchasing power in a Cambodian context.

I should finally point out that the publicity surrounding this affair will hardly contribute to the safety of the two operatives, if that indeed is their primary concern. The publicity has included their photographs and the addresses at which they now live, thereby destroying any chance of anonymity and undermining their security. The whole point of any relocation would have been to safeguard them, not expose them to the world. So those who are minded to assume bad faith on the part of the Australian and UK governments might perhaps now be prepared to ask some questions about the motivations of those who have gone public in this way.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Is it not true that the government could pull the rug from under this alleged Packer-Howard deal by legislating to make the cross-media rules watertight? Is the government planning to take legislative action after the Australian Broadcasting Authority concludes its inquiry into Mr Packer's Fairfax holdings? Above all, does not this latest political stoush, whether engineered or not, highlight the inadequacy of current media rules, particularly with respect to ownership and control?

—It ought to be understood the extent to which the cross-media rules are already embodied in legislation. The basic 15 per cent rule is contained in the Broadcasting Services Act. That means that newspaper proprietors, commercial television proprietors and commercial radio proprietors in each case cannot control the other media in question if they are associated with the licence area in question. Control is defined in the legislation as being an absence of proof to the contrary that a person who has company interests exceeding 15 per cent is regarded as being in a position to exercise control. It is not uncommon, as Senator Kernot should be better aware than most people, in commercially relevant legislation of this kind to not try to bring any more precision than that into the question of control, because it depends on a multitude of circumstances whether control is capable of being exercised with any given percentage. But all of that is pretty clearly laid out.

PARA.TAB: As far as the foreign ownership rules are concerned, it is the case that only general power is given to FIRB under the Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act. Thereafter, it is mainly a matter of discretion in accordance with guidelines laid down, but with the reference to maximum involvement by a single shareholder being 25 per cent and two or more foreign persons not being permitted to hold more than a 40 per cent aggregate controlling interest as far as newspaper proprietors are concerned. There are similar complex percentage rules so far as commercial television is concerned.

I am not sure that there has been any doubt about what the cross-media rules mean in practice, although there will always be room for argument about what constitutes control at the margin. The doubt has been how seriously committed to those rules the opposition is. There is no doubt about the government's commitment. We have made it clear. If there is a case for embodying some more of this in legislation, I will ask the Prime Minister and the Minister for Communications and the Arts if they have anything further to say in response to Senator Kernot's question. But I would not have thought the legislative clarity of the provisions at the moment is a matter in issue. I do not think we have made any plans to introduce further legislation in this respect, but, as I said, I will ask the relevant ministers.

What we will also be asking very publicly, as we have been asking over the last couple of days, is questions about where precisely the opposition stands on this issue. Since 1987 you have had a basic position of opposition to the crossmedia rules. You have had this extraordinary commitment to the Trade Practices Act, knowing perfectly well that they are all different markets for the purposes of the Trade Practices Act. You have fudged, you have ducked and you have weaved on whether or not you are prepared to allow a major proprietor to have interests in both a major paper and a television station in the same city. You have utterly failed to commit yourselves to coming out with some substantive and direct policy before the time of the next election so people can vote on your credentials. You are a mob without shame.

As for you, Senator Alston, who has ducked and weaved and jumped through more hoops backwards, sideways and frontwards than anyone else in the opposition on this matter, you ought to be ashamed of yourself in terms of your commitment to any kind of discernible principle in this matter. The truth of the matter is that you are a bunch of squalid deal makers. That is all you are—squalid deal makers. You reckon you can get away with it but you can't.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the government have any plans to revisit the discretionary nature of decisions like foreign ownership? That is how Mr Conrad Black got to 25 per cent. In light of Mr Packer's challenge to your existing legislation, is the government planning to revisit this, and promptly?

—As Mr Keating is fond of saying, we believe that those rules have worked very well in separating out the queens of the screen from the princes of print from the rajahs of radio. It has worked very well. There is a very clear and articulate policy objective that has been served by all this. We believe it has worked that way in practice. We believe that there is strong support in the Australian community for a maintenance of those walls of separation. It is only a great pity that that view is not shared apparently by those opposite, who are prepared to sacrifice any degree of credible principle in this matter in a will-o'-the-wisp pursuit of transient support from media proprietors which they will be very lucky to retain.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction. Through my contact with members of the small business sector, I am aware that one issue of ongoing concern is the level of paperwork that is required from the three levels of government—federal, state and local. I recall that one of the themes of Working Nation was to simplify and reduce the level of regulation on small business. Can the minister provide information on the measures taken by the federal government towards this aim, particularly as it relates to Tasmania? I have to say to some of my colleagues over there that the new-age mouth from the south has not asked anything.

—I thank Senator Murphy for his question. It is not the first question on small business he has asked in this place in the last two years. Yesterday the drought was broken for the opposition by Senator Calvert, but I notice he has not turned up today. He has disappeared completely. It was probably too much. It is true that one of the major themes of the Working Nation statement was to respond to industry concern—
—I raise a point of order. I was wondering whether the minister could indicate to the parliament where Senator John Coates, the Labor senator from Tasmania, is.
—There is no point of order. That is an abuse of question time. It was not helped by Senator Schacht's cheap shot.

—Thank you for your guidance, Mr President. As I was saying, the Working Nation statement did respond to a lot of industry concerns, particularly from small business, about issues of regulation. As a result, we have a number of initiatives in that statement, including the extension of the Business Licence Information Service, which is a Commonwealth, state and territory initiative on a national basis which provides information about licensing and other regulatory requirements. BLIS currently receives over 100,000 calls a year—in the case of Tasmania it receives over 2,500 calls a year—from small business seeking advice on licensing requirements.

PARA.TAB: I am also very pleased that last year, in a joint venture between the Commonwealth government and the Tasmanian government, there was a review of state and Commonwealth business licensing procedures in that state. That was launched last year by me in conjunction with the Tasmanian minister. One of the most interesting things about this report was that in the review it found that there appeared to be no significant overlap between state and Commonwealth licensing arrangements but there were likely to be problems at the local government level. That is where most of the complaints are directed, not at the Commonwealth. I think some opposition senators from Tasmania who tried to raise these issues in this place yesterday did not understand that and certainly were not aware of this report. As a result, there will be a further ongoing pilot project on BLIS implementation in Tasmania and it is certainly working with the other states.

Some of those areas that came out of Working Nation and the general government policies on reducing regulation have included the announcement by the Treasurer only two or three weeks ago of the FBT cost of compliance review, the Corporations Law simplification program established in October 1993 and the tax law improvement program. In all of those cases, the small business community in this country has made a significant contribution and has made submissions to the government about what it wants to remove those regulations.

Yesterday Senator Calvert and Senator Abetz quoted a report in the Hobart Mercury about complaints from small business about licences and permits. What they failed to mention is that in the very same story the longest list of small business regulations that were being complained about were from their own Liberal state government.

I would like to point out that we are happy to work with the Liberal state government in Tasmania in reducing those regulations, and I would hope Senator Calvert and Senator Abetz would encourage that work with the Tasmanian government, which so far has been productive. I would also hope that they would stop grandstanding in this place about the fact that the Commonwealth regulations are causing the problem when all the independent reports by us and by industry itself indicate that local and state government regulations are the ones that bedevil small business more than any other.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ALP: New South Wales Branch Debt

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is the minister aware that the New South Wales branch of the Labor Party is now $10 million in debt, much of it to the Commonwealth Bank, as a result of the Labor Party's inability, both at governmental and organisational levels, to handle money, and that industry analysts have assessed that the ALP is spending about $3 million on advertising alone in the present New South Wales state election—about twice as much as the Liberal Party? As the electoral funding the ALP will receive, about $2 million, will fail to cover this huge advertising budget, let alone other election costs, will the minister give an unequivocal assurance that the ALP officials who engineered the extraordinarily generous overdraft accommodation from the Commonwealth Bank did not include any members of the Keating government and that the government has not applied any overt or implied pressure on the board of the Commonwealth Bank to continue to provide this extraordinarily generous financial support?

—It is quite clear that there is obviously an election campaign in New South Wales and that Senator Baume, as a New South Wales senator, wants to try to wring some sleazy little point out of it. That is actually a sure sign of panic on his behalf that the Bob Carr opposition in New South Wales looks like becoming a government in that state after the election. This is a sleazy question. It is an indication that a party that engages in push polling is indeed able to clamber into the bottom of the gutter as quickly as it can. I am sure the voters of New South Wales see and note that and will consider the honesty and integrity of their parliamentary representatives when they come to cast their ballot.

PARA.TAB: This is a question that goes to the conduct of a commercial transaction with the Commonwealth Bank. There is every confidence in the Commonwealth Bank, a bank which is partly in public ownership and partly in private ownership and which conducts its affairs on a commercial basis. I do not have to hand the details that have been referred to in this question. In the normal courtesy of exchanges in this chamber, I would refer questions that I do not have the details on to the relevant minister to provide an answer. Given the nature of this question, I will break my normal tradition and I will not even bother on this occasion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it that the minister is not prepared to say whether there has been pressure or whether there has not been pressure; I do not know which. But if there has been no Labor Party pressure on the bank's board—in what is clearly not a commercial transaction; it is a very non-commercial transaction—why then does the Commonwealth Bank continue to fund the New South Wales ALP to an extent that goes far beyond the value of its assets at a time when the bank is foreclosing on so many other debtors in similar circumstances? If the Commonwealth Bank is not financing these huge ALP election bills, who is? Does the security against such loans diminish in any way the Commonwealth Bank's already inadequate security?

—This is a question which is not really a question; it is a series of accusations dressed up as a question to get this sleazy point of view on the public record. That is all it is. I do not know what support Senator Baume might have for making the allegations that he has but, if he has got any, he should present it to lend any credibility to what he says.

PARA.TAB: I will reverse my earlier statement. If there is anything here that the Treasurer may wish to comment on, I will ask the Treasurer to comment on it. Once again, I unequivocally assert what is the truth of the situation here. The Commonwealth Bank conducts its affairs on a commercial basis and deals with applications for financial loans on a commercial basis. There is no reason for anyone to believe that on this or any other occasion its conduct has been different from that. The government does not direct the Commonwealth Bank in the discharge of its responsibilities. It is under a board which carries on the supervision of the executive wing of the bank's responsibilities. Mr President, this question is total and utter sleaze and should be seen as just that. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is it true that the government has provided $6.6 million to North Korea to assist it in the construction of nuclear power stations? Is this the first instalment of a much larger commitment by Australia to the building of nuclear power stations in North Korea? Because Australia does not build nuclear reactors, is it a fact that this assistance is effectively assistance to multinational American companies whose nuclear power station building programs have been in the doldrums for many years? Did the government give any consideration to the provision to North Korea of `Made in Australia' solar domestic hot water units, which would have reduced the Korean demand for electricity by an amount similar to that provided by the reactors and would have been of direct benefit to indigenous Australian companies?

—I put out a press release on 28 February—11 days ago—announcing that we would be providing $US5 million, or $A6.6 million, to the Korean Peninsula Energy Development Organisation, KEDO, which is an international consortium being convened under the terms of the US-North Korea agreed framework to supply light water nuclear reactors and heavy oil to North Korea. The reason for doing so was, of course, to make an Australian contribution to that path breaking agreement between the US and North Korea which broke the impasse over, and the concern about, the future of nuclear weapons production in North Korea. Australia's contribution to the organisation will be used to fund supplies of heavy oil. The major share of the expected $4 billion cost of supplying and constructing light water reactors in North Korea will be borne by the Republic of Korea and Japan.

PARA.TAB: As to your second question, that contribution is a one-off payment and Australia has not given, nor has it been asked to make, an ongoing financial commitment to KEDO. As to your third question about all this benefiting American multinationals, the situation is that, given that our contribution will, as I said, be used for the purchase of heavy oil—which we do not produce and supply ourselves—to meet interim energy needs, given that the responsibility for the supply and construction of the reactors lies with KEDO and the ROK will bear the major part of the financial cost, and given that the reactors will be of South Korean origin, Australia's contribution can in no way be interpreted as direct assistance to multinational American companies.

As to your last question, before giving a commitment to contribute, a lot of effort was put into determining what commercial opportunities might be available for Australian energy expertise and technology. However, the final agreement between the US and North Korea specified precisely the kind of energy to be supplied; namely, nuclear plus interim annual supplies of heavy oil. It was a specific negotiated outcome arrived at after some 16 months of intense, very heavy negotiations, and there was not much room for manoeuvre.

As to whether solar powered hot-water units would be a viable alternative, let me say this: according to the information supplied by Solarhart Industries and DPIE, two 1,000 megawatt nuclear power plants would produce approximately 12,000 million kilowatt hours of electricity per annum. By way of comparison, one solar water heater would be expected to produce 2,000 kilowatts per annum. Thus, to replace the amount of electricity produced by these nuclear power plants would require approximately six million normal household sized solar hot-water heaters. At a cost of $2,500 per system, these would cost some $15 billion, which is 3 3/4 times the cost of the supply of the reactors themselves.

It also needs to be recognised that hot water demand would be a relatively small proportion of current DPRK electricity demands, so there is not direct substitutability. It also needs to be recalled that the hours of direct sunshine in Pyongyang are estimated to be about 5 1/2 per day maximum, which means that solar water heaters would typically require supplementary boosting from alternative energy sources during the winter months.

It is the case that it would be a big boost to Australian industry if we could sell six million hot-water systems to the North Koreans under this deal that you are proposing. That would, of course, amount to some 200 years of Australian present production, which is at the rate of 30,000 systems annually at the moment. It is nice to know that, in a world of constant change and inconstancy, some things do remain permanent: the Democrats really are the fairies at the bottom of the garden party.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Of course, the contribution by Australia is only 0.1 per cent of the total cost. So the figures which the minister gave us are really somewhat irrelevant. Is it not the case that the companies making the nuclear reactors in South Korea are indeed subsidiaries of Westinghouse and General Electric; what really has happened here is that Australia has been put over a barrel using security as the argument so that Australia provides a direct subsidy to American industry; and, even though we are not actually building part of the reactor, the supplies which we are providing do, in fact, go towards that nuclear program?

—Mr President, sometimes I really do wonder. Senator Coulter, don't you understand? There was a security problem. North Korea was in the business of building bombs. Democrats are against bombs; they like us, on the whole, to find solutions for getting rid of them. We got a solution that does get rid of them. That solution requires the production of two major light-water reactors. We are helping to contribute to that because we think it is a good thing for the security of the region and for all of us—it stops us getting blown up.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. I refer the minister to his unequivocal denial at the supplementary estimates hearing that the National Media Liaison Service is not used for party political purposes. Given the introduction to the ALP Communications Directory by the Federal Secretary, Gary Gray, which says:

QUESTION.PARA: The Communications Directory lists the names, phone numbers and addresses of the most influential people in the ALP . . .
We hope that the directory assists you in finding your way around the Labor Party . . .

and, given that page 46 of the directory lists the National Media Liaison Service and Mr Epstein, will you now admit that the National Media Liaison Service is, in fact, one of the `most influential bodies in the Labor Party', as stated by Mr Gray? And, with the government's deceit over the National Media Liaison Service now fully exposed, will you, on behalf of the government, apologise for misleading the Senate? (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —If members of the Liberal Party would like to list the NMLS in their directory, they are welcome.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. Last year the government committed a further $3 million over two years to the wet tropics tree planting scheme. Can the minister indicate what progress has been made to date?

—The wet tropics tree planting scheme has been operating with Commonwealth funding since 1989. It was originally established to provide employment for timber workers who were displaced by the cessation of logging in the wet tropics world heritage area. The scheme has been very successful and has a great track record in environmental repair through reducing soil erosion, improving water quality and replacing lost rainforest habitats.

PARA.TAB: Last year the government reconfirmed its commitment to the scheme, providing $3 million over two years to the North Queensland afforestation program joint board. The board, which represents 11 local councils, administered this scheme and a related program, the community rainforest reafforestation program. The government also took the opportunity to restructure the scheme to put it on a better footing by transferring the full responsibility to the board. This was to allow the board to further build on its strengths, such as effective infrastructure, the direct participation of local government and the considerable expertise of its workers.

One of the aims of the restructure was to position the board to take full advantage of labour market programs. I would like to briefly mention some of the board's achievements in relation to employment. The board has employed 565 people in the last three years. In the next 12 months about 1.2 million trees will be planted across nearly 1,000 hectares and will involve six-month job training places for 400 unemployed people in North Queensland. Many of those employed on the two programs have gone on to have permanent employment. The board is planning further changes to its management and advisory structures, which will better integrate the administration of the two schemes without compromising in any way the conservation and commercial forestry objectives.

In the current debates over the conservation and use of our native forest, the timber industry and regional employment, I believe that this model that is in place in North Queensland shows that there can be cooperation between the three levels of government to successfully achieve both environmental and industry objectives. This cooperative model shows that it is possible to generate benefits to regional economies by addressing in an integrated way the problems of environmental degradation, the future supply of timber and also, of course, the unemployment problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health. Minister, as you know children collect swap cards. Will you tell the Senate how much federal funding has gone towards the production of sexually explicit swap cards under the guise of AIDS education? Do you agree with Queensland authorities that the cards should be destroyed?

—I am unaware of the dollars the Commonwealth government or the AIDS campaign may have put into this program. I will certainly seek some information about that for you. I am advised that after extensive national publicity the Minister for Health in Queensland referred these cards to the state censorship authority, which has banned them.

PARA.TAB: This is a matter for the Queensland government and the censorship board. They have made their decision. There is a concern that the cards banned in Queensland may not be restricted from access to Queensland via other provisions, particularly through sales in the ACT. I know of nothing further that I could assist you with on this matter, but I will certainly raise it with Minister Carmen Lawrence.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question was quite clear: does the minister agree with their destruction? Nothing could be clearer.

—I think it is very important to distinguish between what is government policy and responsibility from a personal view. If I should entertain personal views, it might cloud the issue. This is a matter of considerable importance. The Queensland government has acted. I have said that I will see whether there is anything further that Minister Lawrence or another part of the government could provide on this matter.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to the terrible unemployment figures in Tasmania compared to the national average. For unemployed youth, the national average is 30.3 per cent compared with 40.2 per cent in Tasmania. The overall average unemployment rate for Australia is 8.9 per cent, compared to 11.6 per cent in Tasmania. That is the unemployment rate and it is rising. Is the minister aware that, after a fall, the rate has been rising since August of last year? Is the minister also aware that, since the same period, official interest rates have gone up by 20 per cent impacting upon small businesses in Tasmania? I understand that there are complex causes of unemployment, but why inflict upon Tasmania interest rate rises which were meant to dampen the economy? How would the Tasmanian tourist industry be protected from your proposed bed tax?

—I have already answered the question about bed tax. I am afraid I am not in a position to comment specifically on the Tasmanian employment figures because I do not have a brief about the regional variations, although I am perfectly prepared to accept Senator Harradine's statement that things there are worse than elsewhere. However, it does need to be appreciated how good the overall unemployment figures are. It needs to be remembered that, during the 1993 election campaign, the Prime Minister made a commitment to create 500,000 jobs over a period of three years. It will be remembered that `jobs, jobs, jobs' was the worthy issue on everyone's lips, including yours, Senator Harradine, and others in this place. We have not heard too much about that in recent times because those commitments have been overwhelmingly met. In just two years the government has exceeded that target, with February's employment growth taking total employment growth since the commitment was made to 560,000 people. That is a huge increase in employment and a huge reduction in unemployment.

PARA.TAB: Of course, the reduction has not flowed through to the percentage unemployment rate because of the very substantial increase in the participation rate. It is important that the participation rate is increasing, as Mr Crean said today, because that in itself operates as a moderating influence on wage pressures, which might otherwise take us into a renewed inflationary cycle. Of course, we are all anxious to avoid that, and all evidence suggests that it can be avoided.

It is important to appreciate the significance of that participation rate from another perspective. If you compare the rate that we have at the moment, 63.75 per cent, with the rate that we had in February 1983, which was just 60.9 per cent, and if you translate the actual unemployment figures now into what they would be if we had a 1983 participation rate, we would be sitting on unemployment of just 4.2 per cent. It does need to be appreciated that this phenomenon of increase in the participation rate has had a terribly dramatic impact on the actual unemployment figures. So, with that participation rate of 10 years ago, we would be sitting on just 4.2 per cent unemployment at the moment. That is another way of making clear the magnitude of the government's achievement.

Today's figure does not change our view about the pace of ongoing employment growth in 1994-95. We revised our forecast for employment growth a month ago from three per cent up to three and three quarters per cent. Nor does our view of where the economy is heading change as a result of these figures. When we released our revised economic forecasts, we announced that we would tighten fiscal policy in the budget. We hope that is the way that the emphasis can continue to be placed in the future.

You have mentioned the question of interest rates again. We have not ruled out the possibility of interest rate rises in the future. We will have to assess the stance of monetary policy on an ongoing basis. However, it certainly is our hope that, for the foreseeable future, no such further rise will be necessary. Certainly, that is the view so far as Tasmania is concerned, as with everywhere else in Australia. We are operating a single economy in that respect, even though the impact of unemployment can certainly vary region by region.

I think that is a question you should be asking in the first stance of Mr Groom and his government rather than our government. We have done everything we conceivably can, through the macro-economic strategy, through industry policy and through the employment white paper proposals, so far as the long-term unemployed and the young unemployed are concerned, to get people to work. If the regional economy in Tasmania is not looking in good shape, I think the blame has to be laid in the first instance at the door of that state government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister has not answered my question. I will debate the participation rate with him any time he likes. I asked: why inflict upon Tasmania a medicine which is meant to dampen down the economy? He did not answer that question. He certainly did not answer the question I asked relating to how the tourist industry, which is so important to Tasmania, could be protected from a proposed bed tax. You said that that question was asked before. I did not hear it asked so that is why I asked it. How are you going to protect Tasmania from that proposed tax?

—I do not know how Tasmania could possibly be insulated from the effect of interest rate rises which are applicable universally around the country. I think Senator Harradine understands that perfectly well. So far as the bed tax is concerned, I have just made the point that there is no grounds for any assumption that any such tax would be imposed. It is a matter of looking very carefully at the employment implications of that—and certainly the regional employment implications are part of any such equation—before we even contemplate going down any such path. There is no basis for making any assumptions about anything. The fact that we will not rule it out is simply a standard position we are adopting in relation to any particular proposal that is put in the public domain by way of a revenue raising measure. We are not in the business of ruling in, ruling out, confirming or denying any particular tax or revenue proposal of that kind at the moment for obvious good monetary and budgetary management reasons.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I ask the minister: why are you continuing to discriminate against Mrs Sue St Clair of Alice Springs in her bid for permanent residency in Australia—no doubt you have seen the record of the Today show—particularly as she was medically cleared before the injuries she and her Australian husband received in a horrific helicopter crash last year? Will you reject the accusation from an officer of your department that Mrs St Clair may be considered a burden to

QUESTION.PARA: the Australian taxpayer? Will you give an assurance that you will issue a medical waiver in respect of her application to guarantee natural justice and recognise that approval could have been given by your department within the time constraints?

TALK.START.PARA: —I will pick up the point made by Senator Ray. Not only is an abuse of an individual case in this place disgraceful but the performance of Senator Tambling on this particular matter has generally been disgraceful. What we have seen this week and last week is a callous abuse of this couple for Senator Tambling's own political ends. It is nothing more or nothing less than that. That is the way he has handled this case. Very rarely do we find cases brought into this place that involve individual people.

PARA.TAB: I am advised that no decision has been made in respect of this case, so it is the height of irresponsibility for Senator Tambling to speculate on the outcome as he has done both here and in the media. It is a contemptible way of approaching immigration cases. The only effect will be to prolong the decision making process and cause unnecessary stress for his constituents. That is precisely what has happened here.

I am advised that Mrs St Clair has been advised of the need to reassess her medical condition in relation to her application to remain permanently in Australia as a spouse of an Australian citizen. That is not an unusual thing to happen. I understand that the need to reassess her condition arose because of her involvement in a helicopter accident before a decision was reached on her residency application. The accident occurred during the time the health status of her dependants in the United States was being investigated.

So while she apparently satisfied the health requirement at the time of her accident, it is a requirement under migration regulations—regulations passed in this place, regulations which reflect the continuing work of committees in this place in respect of the health requirements and regulations which Senator Tambling put his hand up in support of when they came through here—that the applicant satisfy the health requirement at the time of the decision.

There is, however, flexibility under the migration regulations in this instance for the migration decision-maker to waive the health requirement. The decision-maker would have to take into account the full circumstances involved attaching to a spouse application. In the overwhelming majority of spouse cases where the health requirement has not been met, my department has exercised its powers of waiver.

It would really expedite this case, Senator Tambling, if you butted out and let Mrs St Clair respond to the department and to do what the department has asked her to do. If you had not butted in this way, her case probably would have been resolved by now. But you have been abusing this person.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why are you holding it up?

—Because he advises this particular person not to respond to the department's requests. That is precisely the hold-up. Without his callous intervention, if he butted out and let Mrs St Clair respond to the department's requests, this matter would be resolved. You are the one who is abusing this person and I am very much disgusted at your behaviour in this matter. You can ask whatever supplementary question you want, but I have given you the full answer.

—This minister has just made a mockery of the anti-discrimination and social rhetoric of the Labor Party. In response to a representation I made to him on 22 December, the minister wrote to me a letter dated 27 February. What a lot of bunkum. He obviously had not even read the file. He is showing the callousness—he picked that word up out of some of the media this week—in the way he has dealt with this particular matter. Mrs St Clair was medically cleared before the accident.
—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. Question time is for questions, but we are having a speech. We ought to have a question. If he has one, he should ask it, otherwise he should sit down.
—I am certainly waiting for the supplementary question to emerge, although there is limited time left.

—I ask the minister: is he proposing to deal with this matter sympathetically and to recognise that the 12-month rule was in fact fully met and it has only been by departmental bungling that it has now blown out to a matter of unnatural justice?

—I said that I would not add any more, but I have found some more information which is also relevant. As a result of the accident—and this is the current state—the applicant's medicals were referred to the Commonwealth Medical Officer for reassessment, as the medical requirement needs to be satisfied at the time of the decision, under the regulations. In regard to the spinal injury, the Commonwealth Medical Officer advised that the case would require referral to the migrant medical clearances unit in Sydney.

PARA.TAB: On 11 January 1995 I received a ministerial representation from Senator Tambling and responses were prepared accordingly encouraging Mrs St Clair to undergo the medical examination at the earliest opportunity. On 7 March 1995 the Commonwealth Medical Officer agreed to review the specialist medical reports provided by Mrs St Clair together with the formal medicals completed in 1993. Mrs St Clair and a treating practitioner have been contacted accordingly. Dr Schmidt has agreed to provide a current medical report; however, he would need to see Mrs St Clair again prior to providing the report. Senator Tambling, butt out and let the process satisfy itself and your constituent will be better served.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—During debate this morning on a motion by Senator Alston, the temporary chairman of committees, Senator McGauran, undertook to refer to me the question whether the expression `political thug', used of a member of parliament, is out of order under standing order 193. Such an expression is not different in principle from those ruled out of order in the past and is unacceptable under standing order 193. During the debate a great many unparliamentary expressions were used, including allegations of lying against members, which have constantly been ruled out of order. I again urge all senators to observe appropriate standards of language in debate. The increasing use of invective in debate in this chamber is both inappropriate and unproductive.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Minchin asked me a question earlier this week concerning a High Court case relating to section 329A of the Commonwealth Electoral Act. I have an answer. It is not a long answer, but to read it into the record would require going back into the context of the question to make the answer make sense. It is quite clear in the written word. I seek leave to have the answer incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: ADDITIONAL INFORMATION FOR QUESTION WITHOUT NOTICE ASKED BY SENATOR MINCHIN ON 6 MARCH 1995
Senator Minchin asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, without notice, on 6 March 1995:

I refer to the case being brought before the High Court seeking a declaration that section 329A of the Commonwealth Electoral Act, which makes it an offence to advocate an informal vote, is invalid. Is the government committed to defending the validity of section 329A? Is it the opinion of the government's legal advisers that the section is valid, despite the High Court's reasoning in throwing out the government's proposal to ban electronic political advertising? If so, are these the same advisers who led the government into its latest debacle before the High Court over the powers of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission? Is the government's restriction on freedom of speech, as embodied in section 329A, based on the same disregard for civil liberties being exhibited by the government in the Racial Hatred Bill and the political ad ban?
Senator McMullan—the answer to the honourable Senator's question is as follows:
1. Yes. The Solicitor General will be appearing for the Commonwealth in the Langer case to support the validity of section 329A. A decision has yet to be made on the Muldowney Case.

2. With regard to the question regarding the government's legal advice, I refer to Senate Standing Order 73(j) stating that questions shall not ask for legal opinion. Moreover, the Government will not be providing its legal advice in advance of court proceedings.
3. It is government policy to support the long established system of preferential voting.

TALK.START.PARA: —I gave Senator Coulter a few answers this afternoon, but I omitted to give him one in relation to his supplementary question about the South Korean contractors for the proposed nuclear reactors. I can add further information as follows: no decision has yet been taken on the primary contractor to build the NK, the North Korean, reactors but it is expected that that will be KEPCO, the Korean Electric Power Corporation, which is a Korean government instrumentality and not a subsidiary of US companies.

PARA.TAB: It is true that previous technology used in South Korea has been provided by Westinghouse, a Canadian company, and some French nuclear technology. But the South Koreans are now developing their own technology, and nuclear reactors now being constructed are of South Korean design with some imported components and technology but that is all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Trade (Senator McMullan), to a question without notice asked by Senator Abetz this day, relating to the National Media Liaison Service.

SPEECH.PARA: The National Media Liaison Service has now been the subject of a lot of criticism, especially by us on this side of the chamber because of what we say is the political agenda of that organisation. We have been seeking and pursuing truth in relation to the National Media Liaison Service for some considerable period now. Be it through questions in this chamber, be it through questions at estimates, be it through supporting the Auditor-General in taking a look at the National Media Liaison Service, at every step of the way the government stops any degree of accountability by the National Media Liaison Service. It obfuscates and it does not want to answer the questions that are asked of it.

PARA.TAB: Of course, today we bowled middle stump because the government was unable to deny what is so very plain in the document entitled Australian Labor Party Communications Directory. In the introduction to this paper Gary Gray, the national secretary of the Labor Party, tells us that the directory lists the names, phone numbers and addresses of the most influential people in the Australian Labor Party. We are also told that it is hoped the directory assists people in finding their way around the Labor Party. It is beholden on Senator McMullan, the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, to tell this house and the people of Australia how the National Media Liaison Service will assist the people of Australia in finding their way around the Labor Party. That is not the purpose of the National Media Liaison Service. The minister gave answers saying that, no, that definitely does not happen, yet we have it here—black on white.

One of the interesting exercises in my very short time here has been that, instead of having politicians leaking information to the media, we on this side of the house have had journalists leaking information to us. The reason that the journalists of this country are doing that is that they know first hand what the National Media Liaison Service gets up.

I canvass another point in relation to the way this minister answers questions about the National Media Liaison Service. We went through an outrageous exercise at Senate estimates hearings of trying to find out the correct title of Mr Epstein. Mr Epstein and the minister time and again denied that Mr Epstein was the director of the National Media Liaison Service and said that that was wrong. That was in spite of the fact that we had a letter from his employing minister, Kim Beazley, saying Mr Epstein was the director of the National Media Liaison Service, despite the fact that the phone directory called him such and despite the fact the communications directory called him such, and I think there were half a dozen entries which also called Mr Epstein the director of the National Media Liaison Service.

Faced with all those facts, the minister and Mr Epstein continue to deny that Mr Epstein was the director of the National Media Liaison Service. That was very early in February. Mr Epstein told the committee that he had done everything within his power by making telephone calls to correct this misinformation and that he had been doing so for quite some time.

We now have the February 1995 edition of the communications directory. We open it at page 127: `National Media Liaison Service, Director, Mr Epstein'—once again described as the director the National Media Liaison Service. But the most interesting aspect of all this is that when you look at questions on notice by Senator Richard Alston to Senator Graham Richardson you find that Senator Graham Richardson in 1991 stated that Mr Epstein was the director of the National Media Liaison Service. Senator Richardson admitted it. Why does this government try to now hide the fact that Mr Epstein is the director of the National Media Liaison service? A former minister admitted it. Every single document admits it. Kim Beazley admits it. Why deny it? It is because they have something to hide, and what they are trying to hide is the purely political nature of aNiMaLS, as is so directly highlighted in this ALP communications directory.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been many articles about the hypocrisy of the Liberal Party indignation on this and about people in glasshouses who should not throw stones. The most effective one was probably in the Bulletin on August 15, 1989. To anyone who is interested I refer them to that article. But with regard to the matter that Senator Abetz raised when he thought he had some sort of coup with regard to the ALP communications directory, in a previous ALP communications directory there was a reference to the National Media Liaison Service. As soon as the director of the ministerial media group became aware of that, he ensured that that was corrected and in the current communications directory there is no reference to the National Media Liaison Service and there will not be in the future.
