SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus), to a question without notice asked by Senator Tambling this day, relating to an immigration application.

SPEECH.PARA: Today during question time I referred to an immigration matter of vital importance. It is a matter of pure natural justice for people in Australia. This matter has been highlighted widely in the media but we need to look carefully at the minister's letter to me dated 27 February 1995 where he said:

Mrs St Clair underwent health checks on 28 July 1993 and was medically cleared as a result of those checks. Her dependent children, who were at the time living in the United States, were required to provide additional information with regard to their medical examinations prior to a clearance being granted. This clearance was not obtained until 29 June 1994. However, prior to this advice being received, both Mr and Mrs St Clair were involved in a helicopter accident on the 21st of June 1994.

It goes on to describe the hospitalisation, et cetera. Those key dates are: 21 June 1994 and 29 June 1994. Obviously all the processes were in place. Mrs St Clair had been approved and so had her dependent children. Given that the government could then have procedurally processed this matter, there is no need now for this 12-month rule of a reassessment which, if implemented unfairly on Mrs St Clair, would involve the breaking up of an entire family.

PARA.TAB: I am also appalled that the minister in his letter said that the further medical was to determine whether she was medically fit or whether her injuries were such that she would become a burden on the Australian taxpayer. What bunkum! Let us get down to the real issues. I have a letter from Mr St Clair's mother in Queensland, who wrote to me on 5 March. I quote part of that letter:

SPEECH.PARA: Sue is our daughter-in-law and Archie is our son. In due respects the amount of time, years, to receive your residency is deplorable. Sue should have obtained hers before the accident as she had been waiting patiently over the years for it. Why the present rush to have the second medical, as she was passed on the 28th of July 1993 and it is now the 5th of March 1995? After the accident she is now walking and in good health and mentally fit. Archie in the meantime needs her as she is his wife and she is also a trained nurse and can look after him. Their recovery rate so far is nothing short of a miracle considering the surgeon at the Royal Adelaide spinal unit told us that Sue may be able to walk but not so Arch. It is only the guts and determination that brought this miracle about and prayers from a lot of people, in particular the Sacred Heart nuns that taught Archie at school in Alice Springs.

I think this is an important case of sheer natural justice. Everything was in place, as were the times for approval. I am pleased that departmental officers in the media in the last week or so have acknowledged that there is a waiver principle available. But they supposedly need to ask for this second medical, which is only going to show, naturally, the extent of the damage to Mrs St Clair and the medical problem of her current condition. But she is up and about. She is assisting her husband. She is saving the Australian taxpayers money—not costing them. This couple are married. In the normal course of events this would have been by now a fully operational Australian family. I can only describe the answer of the minister today as absolutely disgusting and dismaying, given the social justice priorities the Labor Party espouses.

TALK.START.PARA: —All pretence.

—It is just a pretence. The minister takes offence that I raise a particular case. I assure him that I did not raise it in the media. The media was well aware of this case and actually activated the media interest in Mrs St Clair. I did not go to the media until well after Mr and Mrs St Clair were interviewed on the Today show.

PARA.TAB: Certainly, in the week since then I have called on the minister and the department to show some compassion and some commonsense. I would hope that as a result of the questioning today the minister will see that that 12-month, dogged, head-in-the-manger rule is something that is so damned stupid he ought to just get in there and sort it out.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer provided by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), to a question without notice asked by Senator Coulter this day, relating to the funding of nuclear power stations in North Korea.

SPEECH.PARA: I was absolutely amazed at the two aspects of the reply of the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Firstly, the minister claims that providing nuclear reactors to North Korea somehow guarantees our nuclear safety. Secondly, implied in the answer is that there is no alternative in terms of providing the energy to North Korea.

PARA.TAB: On the first point, it is abundantly clear—we have many examples of this; in fact, North Korea itself provides the example—that the civil nuclear program does provide a route for the development of nuclear weapons. We have seen just in recent days the objections made by America to the provision to Iran of Russian technology to build nuclear reactors in Iran on the grounds that the civil program was a way in which Iran could get access to nuclear weapons. There is no certainty whatsoever that, having got that technology, having got those reactors, the North Koreans could not at some future time ignore any provisions in relation to how they dealt with that reactor—the unloading of the fuel, the reprocessing of the fuel and the preparation of material for nuclear weapons.

The provision of civil nuclear power stations is a route by which nations can get access to nuclear weapons and international agreements are not worth the paper they are written on when a nation decides that it is going to ignore those provisions and go its own way.

I make a second point in relation to this. Sure, the North Koreans need energy. That was the reason, I suppose, they had these earlier graphite reactors. There are other, non-nuclear ways of providing that energy. I drew the minister's attention to solar hot water. The minister evidently is not aware of the fact that Australia has some excellent technology for commercial, high-temperature, solar hot water. While the minister talks about average hours of sunlight, I remind him that that figure on average hours of sunlight, which may be correct, disguises the fact that during the summertime the North Koreans have very long hours of sunlight and, in fact, could derive a great deal of energy from that source.

It is my belief that in this respect the Americans have been very clever in using this situation to advantage nuclear power development. We all know what a parlous state the nuclear industry in the US is in. I am not exactly sure how far the Americans are still involved—evidently the minister is not sure of this—with those South Korean operations. I suspect that they are still quite heavily involved. This is really a way of getting Australia to subsidise that development when alternatives could have been provided. It seems to me that Australia has not adequately researched these alternatives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I have already answered most of those questions. Senator Coulter must think the US negotiators are a bunch of geese in their approach to this whole issue. Their interest is exactly the same as the interest of us and everybody else in the region, which is to create an environment in which we can be as confident as we possibly can that there will not be any future nuclear weapon producing capacity in Korea and to find a mixture of incentives and safeguards to ensure that that will be the case.

PARA.TAB: The particular civil power producing reactor that is there at the moment is a plutonium producing graphite moderated research reactor. It is only quite small in scale, but nonetheless the technology, as Senator Coulter acknowledges, is capable of producing plutonium. The whole point of the exercise was to shut that one down or any other similarly constructed reactor and to put in place lightwater reactors, which do not have anything like the same capacity to produce fissile material.

Moreover, it is an inherent and integral part of the whole deal that the International Atomic Energy Agency, with its inspection and verification capacity, be an intimate part of the nuclear scene hereafter so far as North Korea is concerned. If one is going to challenge the utility of these kind of agreements, one is really calling in aid the whole nuclear non-proliferation treaty, the chemical weapons convention and all the rest of the international machinery and regimes that have been put in place.

Senator Coulter is entitled to his scepticism; nothing I say will take that away from him. But it is the scepticism of those who abandon all hope of rationality or the utility of any kind of international discourse. We may as well pick up our bags and go home, because they can always invent a conspiracy, a tragic scenario or catastrophe that undermines the effect of those agreements. One has to work on different assumptions if any progress is to be made. If the United States and those of us in the international community who are supporting it had not gone down this path, nothing is more certain than the fact that North Korea would be sitting there manufacturing nuclear weapons right now. I do not think the Democrats, or even Senator Coulter, would regard that as a good thing.

A few more of these points were made in this press release that I put out on 28 February. For the sake of completeness, I not only refer to my supplementary answer after question time, which addressed the concerns of Senator Coulter about US continuing commercial involvement, but also now seek leave to incorporate that statement of 28 February in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Press Release
Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Gareth Evans
28 February 1995
AUSTRALIAN CONTRIBUTION TO THE KOREAN PENINSULA ENERGY DEVELOPMENT ORGANISATION

Australia will make a one-off contribution of USD 5 million (or AUD 6.6 million) to the Korean Peninsula Energy Development Organisation (KEDO), the international consortium being formed to provide lightwater nuclear reactors and conventional energy assistance to North Korea (the Democratic People's Republic of Korea—DPRK).

KEDO is the centrepiece of the US-DPRK Agreed Framework which was concluded in October 1994, in response to concern about North Korea's possible development of a nuclear weapons capability. The Agreed Framework embodies commitments by the DPRK to freeze permanently the operation of its existing plutonium-producing graphite moderated research reactor, seal its plutonium reprocessing facility, provide for the safe storage and eventual shipment out of the DPRK of spent fuel rods unloaded from its nuclear reactor and halt the construction of two new graphite reactors. The International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) has verified that since the signing of the Agreed Framework, the DPRK is complying with these commitments.

In return for these commitments, the DPRK will receive assistance from KEDO to construct two new lightwater type nuclear-powered reactors to meet its energy needs. In addition, the Agreed Framework calls for KEDO to provide shipments of heavy oil to North Korea until the lightwater reactors come on stream.

The Agreed Framework, of which KEDO is an integral part, provides the foundation for a resolution to the nuclear issue on the Korean Peninsula. It will make an important contribution to global and regional security, and offers the best basis currently available of resolving an issue of the highest security significance for Australia.

Australia's decision to make this contribution, made in Cabinet last night, is a reflection of the immense importance we place on supporting practical means to improve security on the Korean Peninsula. It is also a reflection of Australia's strong commitment to nuclear non-proliferation and the prominent role we have played in working for a resolution of this issue in recent years.

KEDO will be a multilateral organisation with more than twenty countries invited to participate. The bulk of the financing for KEDO's proposed program will come from the Republic of Korea and Japan with total costs estimated to be a minimum of USD 4 billion over ten years. Australia will participate in the inaugural meting of KEDO which is scheduled to be held in New York from 6-9 March 1995.
CANBERRA

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Family Services (Senator Crowley), to a question without notice asked by Senator Herron this day, relating to swap cards issued by the Queensland Aids Council.

SPEECH.PARA: The question that I asked the minister concerned, firstly, federal government funding and, secondly, whether she agreed that those cards should be destroyed. The question is not applicable to just Queensland, because my understanding is that these cards are scheduled for distribution in Victoria, the ACT and perhaps other states. The defence is that these cards are educational.

PARA.TAB: By chance, when we were debating the classification of publications, films and television last week—Senator Harradine will remember—I brought up the matter of how one classifies or censors an official government publication. It was in relation to the Cleo safe sex guide published by the government and endorsed by the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence). I was scoffed at by members of the government for bringing that up, as I was scoffed when I asked that question in question time today. I believe that many members on the government side share my concerns about this matter, just as they did when I brought this matter up last week in relation to the so-called safe sex guide. We are seeing within our society advocacy of unsafe sexual practices by official government publications. That is reality. These publications are funded by government—either federal or state.

This issue has been brought to the public's attention due to the explicit nature of the cards that are being distributed. On the reverse side of the cards there is a sex guide. The same excuse was used in relation to the Cleo guide, which clearly advocates sodomy as acceptable heterosexual behaviour. There is outrage in the community. I cannot believe what has occurred as a result of the publicity of that other guide. My office in Queensland has been overwhelmed. I have had six people answering the telephones since that publicity occurred. Some 3,000 telephone calls have been recorded and, as you know, Mr Deputy President, we are already getting petitions in this house. There is an ailment in society when official government publications advocate deviant behaviour—whether it be sexual or otherwise.

Senator Harradine, Senator Reynolds and I are on a committee looking at the classification of television. We brought in a unanimous decision that R-rated television, particularly in relation to sexual violence with females, should be banned on pay television. It is all part of this spectrum.

I make an appeal to the government. I know there are just as many people on the government side that feel as strongly as I do because some of them have approached me. This is an issue that transcends politics. Initially, it was thought that this was an attack by me on the government. It is an attack by me on the government. I do not resile from that. But it is an issue to which serious thought must be given by the government because it controls the funds. It is an issue that affects the whole of our society. It is not something that will go away. A gradual desensitisation of society has occurred in my lifetime and the effect will be the loss of childhood for children.

These cards to which I am referring show explicit homosexual behaviour. Children collect cards. What chance does a child have if these cards get into the general community and destroy the ability of children to cope with their own sexuality, particularly at puberty? These cards will inevitably go into the schools. Children are particularly curious at that time of their life. Those cards will get into society, and there is no turning back once that has occurred. I appeal to decent-minded members of the government to take some action in this regard.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans), to a question without notice asked by Senator Harradine this day, relating to unemployment in Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: I do want to have a meeting of minds with Senator Evans because this is a very grave matter for consideration. It is no good just saying that it is only one thing. As I said in my question, the causes of unemployment are quite complex. One of the causes is that there are more people seeking paid work when jobs are not available and when at the same time jobs are destroyed because of technological change and innovation. That is why I was very surprised to hear the minister applaud the participation rate. Why do we applaud, and why should we applaud, the participation rate if the situation is simply as he said—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am just talking about the economic impact of it in moderating wage pressures.
—I was about to say that. If that is the only reason—
—That is the only reason.

—If that is the only reason then I deplore that. If the participation rate is to be praised because you are going to have wage moderation, whatever that might be—as I have seen wage moderation, it means going out the backdoor—then I do not think that is a desirable feature. You really have to look at why people are in the paid work force, whether people in the paid work force have better reasons to be out of the paid work force to engage in a socially constructive alternative. That is the issue.

PARA.TAB: The figures show that families are now working longer for less. The figures actually show that. This is a real problem. There has to be more than one person in a family out in the paid work force to make ends meet. This a problem. It does not give true freedom of choice.

I would like at some stage—I think we have talked about this before, Senator Evans—a really good examination of the participation rate. Why are people in the paid work force? Are there people in the paid work force who have better reasons to be out of the paid work force and want to come out of the paid work force to leave the way open for others? Let us please have a look at this because this is a very serious problem.

I was concerned about the blanket approach that governments take—I am not saying your government only; governments take this approach all the time—particularly in this area of interest rates. Yes, the unemployment rate has been crook in Tasmania for a long time. It was coming down in June, July and August of last year but since then it has been creeping up again. It just so happens that it is that same period of time in which the interest rates have increased by 20 per cent.

I am not suggesting that that is the sole cause or even the main cause necessarily, but it certainly does not help. I appeal to the government, in considering whether or not to dampen down the economy by this sort of fiscal measure, to consider some other measures or make some arrangements that outlying states like Tasmania can get some sort of compensation, some sort of cushion, if you like.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus), to a question without notice asked by Senator McKiernan this day, relating to Australian citizenship.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason I have moved this motion is that I am quite frankly astonished that Senator McKiernan would have the unmitigated gall to get up and ask the question he did. His question was about Mr Geoffrey Blainey's comments on immigration. I have not seen what Mr Blainey had to say and I do not—

TALK.START.PARA: —Read the Australian newspaper. It is fully set out.

—Some of us are busy, Senator Evans, and have work to do. You might not know about the concept. I am not sure that Senator McKiernan had any standing to ask that question given the despicable, disgusting, paranoid press release that he put out the other day. Senator McKiernan came into the chamber and sought leave to incorporate it last night. I gave him leave because I think it is good that bigoted statements like that do go on the record. Senator McKiernan, in his press release, clearly tried to whip up race hatred and paranoia. Senator McKiernan said in his press release:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . hundreds of thousands of people from China and some other Asian countries will shortly be making plans to get to Australia. They will hear, if they have not already heard, that the numbers are in the Senate to defeat the Bill".

That is, the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3). Of course, Senator McKiernan was made to look like an absolute idiot because his own government, a couple of days later, withdrew the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) to deal with some of the concerns that Senator McKiernan lampooned in his press release.

PARA.TAB: Senator McKiernan's press release is the most disgusting piece of paranoia that I have seen in a long time. It is inaccurate, and it is a slur on the Asian community in this country. I think Senator McKiernan ought to apologise before he gets up and asks any further questions on migration. Senator McKiernan does not have any standing in the ethnic community any more because of the despicable press release he put out. It was an embarrassment.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.

—I am sure Senator Burns, who is a reasonable man, would be embarrassed by that press release. Senator Burns and I have agreed on many issues on migration. I am sure that if Senator Burns read the press release he would be embarrassed at what Senator McKiernan had to say. It was disgusting; it was inaccurate; it was inflammatory; it was straight out of the days of the yellow peril.

PARA.TAB: The whole purpose of that press release was to make mainstream Australia think that we were going to be flooded with hundreds of thousands of boat people from China and other Asian countries. It is a matter of record that China is the only country in this region that has a one child policy, so I do not see why boat people would be flooding here because of the failure to pass this bill or anything else in relation to fertility control policies. It is a simple fact that, even if you added together all the boats in the Chinese navy and all the fishing vessels in China, you still could not get hundreds of thousands of people here.

This press release was an act of pure paranoia. It came from Senator McKiernan's twisted fantasies and his clear hatred of certain people in Western Australia. I think it is a disgrace that the immigration debate in this country should have been twisted and contorted as a result of that press release. I do not think Senator McKiernan ought to be asking these questions. I think Senator Bolkus should have told him to sit down and shut up.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to standing order 81, the Select Committee on Unresolved Whistleblower Cases, by letter dated 8 March 1995 signed by its chair, Senator Murphy, has raised with the President a matter of privilege. Senator Newman, the chair of the former Select Committee on Public Interest Whistleblowing, has also raised with him the same matter.

PARA.TAB: The select committee has received a letter from a person who made a submission to the earlier select committee alleging that statements made by another person in a letter to the earlier select committee were false or misleading. The Select Committee on Unresolved Whistleblower Cases suggests that, as the earlier select committee has reported, these allegations should be investigated by the Senate Committee of Privileges, and asks that the President give precedence to a motion in accordance with standing order 81.

The President is required to determine whether a motion to refer the matter to the Privileges Committee should have precedence, having regard to the criteria set out in the Senate's privilege resolution No. 4. Those criteria are:

INTERJECT.PARA: (a)the principle that the Senate's power to adjudge and deal with contempts should be used only where it is necessary to provide reasonable protection for the Senate and its committees and for senators against improper acts tending substantially to obstruct them in the performance of their functions, and should not be used in respect of matters which appear to be of a trivial nature or unworthy of the attention of the Senate; and
(b)the existence of any remedy other than that power for any act which may be held to be a contempt.

In past determinations it has been indicated that a motion relating to a matter will be given precedence if it is capable of being held by the Senate to meet criterion (a), and if there is no other readily available remedy. As past cases and reports by the Privileges Committee indicate, any suggestion that false or misleading evidence has been given to the Senate or one of its committees has always been taken very seriously and as a matter which should be investigated. The material placed before the President by the Select Committee on Unresolved Whistleblower Cases provides sufficient basis for the President to conclude that the matter is capable of being held to meet criterion (a) and there is no other readily available remedy. The President therefore determines that a motion to refer this matter to the Privileges Committee may have precedence in accordance with standing order 81. I table the correspondence and attachments provided to the President by the select committee and by Senator Newman.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the following matter be referred to the Committee of Privileges:

SPEECH.PARA: Whether false or misleading statements were made to the Select Committee on Public Interest Whistleblowing, and, if so, whether any contempt was committed in relation to these statements.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —The President has received a letter from Senator Short proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The actions of the Keating Government in putting short-term political objectives in the New South Wales State Election ahead of its national responsibilities to address Australia's looming economic crisis at a cost to all Australians, including the people of New South Wales.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.TAB: More than the number of senators required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia is facing a looming economic crisis. Inflationary pressures are on the increase. Turmoil on international financial markets is putting the Australian dollar under considerable pressure. Yesterday, the international value of the Australian dollar reached its lowest level since early January 1994. In the last two months, the value of the Australian dollar has fallen by more than eight per cent; in the past week alone, it has fallen three per cent. The falls have been much greater when measured against certain key currencies—notably, the Japanese yen.

PARA.TAB: The turmoil on the international currency markets will have a direct negative impact on economic growth in our major trading partners, particularly Japan and the United States. That will inevitably have a depressing impact on Australia's trade prospects and, therefore, worsen our already unsustainable crisis-ridden balance of payments deficit—the biggest deficit in the Western world, a deficit of true banana republic proportions. It is this deficit, having been a feature of Labor's disastrous economic performance year in and year out, that threatens our very sovereignty as a nation. It puts us into ever increasing debt to the rest of the world—a debt that is now eight times greater than it was when Labor came to office.

Our arrogant Prime Minister (Mr Keating)—who struts the world stage demeaning Australia's image by either petulantly carping on Australian domestic political issues or promoting his case for Australia to become a republic—talks about the need for Australia to become more independent. The President of Germany must have really wondered what he had struck when he met Mr Keating a couple of days ago and was subjected to Mr Keating's views on how a president should be chosen in any future Australian republic. I am sure he would have agreed with Alan Ramsey's description of Mr Keating in the Sydney Morning Herald this week as `a Prime Minister unhinged'. For heavens sake, what is the man about? The hypocrisy of going on about the need for Australia to be more independent, when his economic policies have done more to weaken our sovereign independence than any other person or event in our history, is quite breathtakingly sickening.

Interest rates have risen savagely in Australia in recent months. Market rates since mid-1994 are now up by some 60 per cent. There is further market pressure on rates. The increase to date risks forcing economic growth to run into a brick wall. Already there are worrying signs of damage in important sections of the economy. The housing and construction industries are starting to look as though they are in for a decline. The job advertisement columns of the papers are showing that the job market is tightening considerably; in fact, the figures show that today there has been an increase in unemployed Australians to a figure of more than 800,000.

Further rate increases will greatly accelerate the slowdown and put us back on the down slide as a result of this government's policies, this government whose economic performance throughout its 12 years in office has been characterised by boom-bust. We are now heading ominously towards another bust when we have had precious little gain over the past year or more—a brief five minutes of sunlight, as John Howard has so eloquently described it—after all of the years of pain resulting from Mr Keating's deliberate creation in 1990 of the worst recession in 60 years, the aftermath of which is still being felt in full brutal force, as I say, in particular by the more than 800,000 Australians who are still out of work as a result of it.

It is no wonder members of the Labor Party in New South Wales breathed a huge sigh of relief when the Prime Minister boarded his personal Boeing to jet off to foreign lands a few days ago. They could not wait for him to go. They wish he would stay away until after the 25 March state election. He will not; he will be back by then. So they have done the next best thing and have said to him, `Paul, when you get back to Australia, please stay out of New South Wales until after 25 March.'

But therein, of course, lies both a bitter and a sweet irony. Whilst Mr Carr and his Labor cronies in New South Wales do not want Mr Keating anywhere near the electorate until after the state election is out of the way because of the Keating government's dreadful policy failures in the areas of the economy, interest rates, the third Sydney runway, pay TV, the timber industry, jobs, and so on—the list is endless—at the same time they are relying on him to put off until after the election the announcement of further decisions this government in Canberra will take which will increase the hardship that the people of New South Wales will have to bear on top of the hardship already caused by federal government policies. I refer, in particular, to the further hike in interest rates that will inevitably occur because of the Keating government's incapacity, lack of will and lack of intelligence, quite frankly, to produce a budget that will enable further savage tax rises to be resisted.

We heard stark evidence of that inability to understand the real situation in question time today, when Senator Gareth Evans said in response to a question that the Keating government has done virtually everything it can in macro-economic terms. What irresponsible nonsense that is. The government's books are in worse shape than they were five years ago.

What Senator Evans said today completely ignores the advice that the Reserve Bank Governor, Bernie Fraser, gave to members of the caucus earlier this week, when he said that if there was not a fiscally responsible budget, particularly in spending terms, and a restraint in spending, the bank would have no option but to opt for further significant interest rate rises. That is what is going to happen. There is no doubt at all about that. As a result of that, housing affordability in New South Wales as well as other areas of Australia is set to crash when these interest rates hit.

Despite Senator Evans's weasel words in the Senate yesterday about not expecting interest rates to increase, he knows and the markets know that rates will rise. Access Economics yesterday predicted home loan mortgage rates will hit 13 per cent. Syntec says official interest rates are on their way to a further two per cent hike. Virtually all reputable economists agree with that, and yet the Keating government, which has already done so much to damage New South Wales finances, is about to go and do the same. Each one per cent increase in interest rates costs the New South Wales government $75 million in revenue lost.

This is a compounding of an existing problem. It is a problem that the government is desperately trying to sweep under the carpet until 25 March. I know that the electors of New South Wales are much more sensible than to be fooled by this irresponsible behaviour on the part of the Keating government.

TALK.START.PARA: —The electors of New South Wales are sensible enough to elect a Carr Labor government on 25 March.

PARA.TAB: It is extraordinary that a Victorian Liberal would put the proposition before us. It speaks volumes about the arid nature of the New South Wales Liberal Party that a Victorian has to be called upon to put forward a proposition which relates to the nature of federal politics and the state election. That is where I am going to confine my remarks.

It is a tradition within the New South Wales Labor Party at the beginning of a state election campaign to say, as Neville Wran said in 1976, the welcome mat is not out for federal politicians. We have always tended to do that. We have always tended to focus upon the state issues and to campaign on our own merits and strengths and to highlight the weaknesses and flaws and absurdities of our opponents.

Coming to the absurdities of our opponents, I will read a brief list of names for the interest of the Senate: Singleton, Greiner, Moore, Metherell, Smiles, Packard, Pickard, Pickering, Griffiths, Morris. What do all of those people have in common? All of them served during the term of the coalition government in New South Wales. All of them got into almighty trouble. Most of those cases involved resignations. Many of them involved scandals. Two in particular disgraced their office. I am talking about the people who refused to pay their taxes.

So, if we want to talk about federal issues that have an impact upon New South Wales politics, we ought to start by looking at the Liberal MPs who refused to meet their obligations to the Commonwealth, to the tax office and to the rest of the taxpayers of Australia. They cheated on their taxes and set a very fine example to the rest of the community, to the rest of the political process and to all those honest Australians who do meet their obligations on a PAYE basis. These matters were accompanied by the usual round of ICAC hearings and the season tickets that some of Mr Fahey's ministers have to the ICAC. They were put to good use once again. They were down to the witness box at Redfern and so on and so forth. Frankly, the New South Wales government should have resigned.

In dealing with taxes, let us focus just for a moment on the issue of state taxes. Let us look at the amount of state tax money that has been abused over recent months in a concerted state government advertising campaign extolling virtues that do not exist and covering up massive problems. Over the past 12 months, $36.7 million worth of state tax revenue was spent on state government advertising. That is a $14 million increase on the previous year. If I remember correctly, Michael Egan, the shadow minister for finance, calculated that sum would buy 28 school buses, provide an additional 230 police officers or 280 teachers for the state schools. Instead, all of that money was squandered by the state government feeling the pressure of an imminent general election.

Let us look at some of the federal issues which will have an impact on 25 March. I am referring to the creation of 560,000 new jobs by the Keating government. Many of them are in New South Wales and many of them are in the areas of economic expansion and the high technology sector. That is a record of which any government ought to be very proud; and we on this side of the chamber are proud. It reflects the highest rate of economic growth anywhere in the Western industrial world, anywhere in the OECD. These are facts, not suppositions and allegations as we hear opposite. We have a confident approach to matters of economic policy and an Asian-Pacific perspective. We are focused on the regions of New South Wales and beyond the rest of Australia. The federal government is involved in infrastructure projects and the like.

Let us look to the other side. What do we see? In the Australian Financial Review today we read about Senator Alston committing an incoming conservative government to privatising Telecom. If you want to fight at the next federal election, we will fight that issue very gladly, quite willingly. That will prove as devastating to you in many of the rural and provincial areas, as I suspect Senator Sandy Macdonald knows, as the GST and other foolish and absurd measures proved to be in 1993. It is not necessary to go into the pattern of deception that has emerged opposite in recent times: the push polling; the commitment to no cuts and then the commitment to some cuts; did Mr Howard's office know what the federal Liberal secretariat was doing; did Mr Howard's people go through the federal press gallery hawking documents and saying, `Please print them but do not attribute them to us'? There is no need to go into all those matters of deception. The public record will have an impact on 25 March. It will have an impact beyond.

In 1991 we had the scenario whereby everyone wrote New South Wales Labor off—the pollsters did, the pundits did, all the commentators did. From memory, one Sydney Morning Herald commentator characterised our campaign at that time as heading for a car crash. That was very clever, but it proved not to be the case. Exactly the same circumstances will be repeated on 25 March. The Labor Party will come home very strongly for the simple reason that we have focused on real issues of concern—health, law enforcement and education. Again the pundits will be proved wrong.

The New South Wales state opposition leader, Mr Carr, demonstrated in the last 24 hours what painstaking policy making in an area of public obligation can do. I am referring to the landmark agreement struck with the timber unions and certain conservation groups relating to the future of forests and national parks and the logging industry in our state. There is no question that a detailed, comprehensive approach bears fruit in terms of public policy and electoral estimation.

Some of the polls appear to neglect the fact that vast tracts of conservative votes are locked up in the upper North Shore of Sydney. This election is not going to be decided on the basis of a statewide vote; it is going to be decided on the basis of the votes in six or seven key marginal seats. In that sense, it is the most particular election in the state's history. It may be the most particular election in the country's history. There is no question that the political demography favours Labor in a number of those seats, be they on the mid-north coast, the outer western suburbs of Sydney, Maitland, or the Blue Mountains.

It is also the case that the Labor campaign, which carefully focuses on issues of real concern, tends to develop political momentum as the poll approaches. People are not fooled by extravagant promises. The circumstances surrounding the Parramatta by-election were such that the conservative government in New South Wales, as senators may recall, promised $1,400 million of public expenditure on various projects within the electorate.

TALK.START.PARA: —And they haven't implemented any of them.

—Senator Neal is right that none of them have been implemented. Some $1,400 million of public money was promised to Parramatta or the adjoining seats. None of it has been expended. What was the consequence in terms of the election result? The people of Parramatta were not fooled for one moment. Gabrielle Harrison came home in a landslide. That is the interesting point about New South Wales politics since 1991. Whenever there has been a by-election—whatever the climate, whatever the area, whatever the nature of the seat—New South Wales Labor has performed extremely strongly.
—Maitland.
—The focus is very sharp for the seat of Maitland, which is on the edge. I think Tony Keating will come home.
—A good candidate.

—He is a very good candidate. We could talk about Cabramatta as well where Reba Meagher came home in a very strong campaign. That is a tribute to our campaign people, particularly John Della Bosca and his team, but it is also a tribute to Bob Carr and his focus.
—Bob Kemp.

—Bob Kemp is an extremely determined individual and a man of real ability, which Senator Ray has recognised by having him working for him of recent times. We could look at the actual record of the Fahey government of recent times or even look a little further back. In the last seven years, in relation to law enforcement we have seen the highest rate of break and enters in the country. Home invasions are on the rise. There have been 300 in the last two years. That is a vicious new crime that is particularly prevalent in Sydney. There has been a rise in anti-social activity which Labor has promised to crack down on. There is understaffing in police stations, particularly in western Sydney.

PARA.TAB: Senator Herron interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I will mention health since Senator Herron, the honourable surgeon general, has interjected. The waiting lists have doubled under your government in New South Wales to 45,000 people. That is astonishing. This government has seen 30 hospitals closed down or privatised and $70 million per year taken out of the health budget. This is at the state level. Do not be like John Fahey and make excuses. We hear nothing but excuses from John Fahey. Labor is the only party that makes a difference on issues like this. Rural waiting lists now have over 9,000 people on them.

PARA.TAB: In relation to education, seven years under the coalition has seen New South Wales with the highest class sizes of any state and a significant rise in composite classes in the cities in particular. The system has been struggling ever since the unlamented Dr Metherell turfed out 2,500 school teachers in 1989-90. Less than half of them have been replaced despite—as Senator Neal will probably observe—a promise to the contrary by Premier Fahey. Yet another promise gone begging.

By all means let us talk about federal issues that are relevant to the New South Wales general election campaign. We are prepared to campaign on our strengths. There is no question about that. As I said, we have heard nothing but excuses from John Fahey. He wants to run on federal issues because he has virtually nothing to say about the seven years of neglect by the New South Wales conservative government. The Labor Party will make a difference on those issues and that is why Labor will come home on 25 March.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —In 16 days the people of New South Wales will face a stark choice. On the one hand they have a competent Liberal-National coalition and on the other hand they have Labor—Mr Carr's one-man band of political non-entities. The re-election of John Fahey as Premier will see the continuation of comprehensive, principled and sensible government. State government is about the delivery of services and the New South Wales government is competent, experienced and above all able to deliver the services in education, transport, health and law enforcement.

PARA.TAB: The federal ALP is doing everything to prop up this New South Wales opposition. The disruption of the timber industry in the deal this week is the latest example. Appeasing sectional interests is what this ALP is all about. You are desperate to help Mr Carr. Firstly, a loss in New South Wales will make the ALP a rump of a political party. You have a union movement that is voting with its feet and you have a debt in New South Wales that shows you are hopeless managers. Secondly, Labor is hanging on by a gossamer thread federally and in Queensland. Thirdly, you have the debacle that occurred in Victoria with Tricontinental debt, Pyramid problems and a complete crisis in confidence that my colleague Senator McGauran reminds us all of. That is only now being restored by Premier Kennett. Fourthly—and you do not like being reminded of this—there are the problems in South Australia with the biggest debt that a state government has ever built up of over $3 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —More than WA Inc.—I hardly believe it.

—I will get to WA Inc. The question is: who is New South Wales Labor? The only ones we have seen over the last four years are Bob Carr and Andrew Refshauge. The rest of the team are a bunch of seat warmers incapable of debating or formulating policies and inept when it comes to performing in the parliament. Why would the people of New South Wales elect this phantom government—a government of shadows? If elected, it will be a government that deals with sectional interests. The election of Bob Carr as Premier in New South Wales will see New South Wales fall into an economic, social and environmental paralysis. Labor shadow ministers have the economic and management skills of a P-76. I will remind the Senate a little about these people who claim to be the possible ministers in a New South Wales Labor government. In an article in Tuesday's Telegraph Mirror the headline was, `Labor battles team's profile problem'. The article said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . his team—
referring to Bob Carr—
has been criticised for its low profile and male bias.

PARA.TAB: On a head-to-head basis, the Government appears to have it over the Labor Party in the areas of public profile and parliamentary performance.

SPEECH.PARA: It goes on to state:

PARA.TAB: The ALP also suffers in comparison with the Liberal-National Government when it comes to the number of women on the frontbench.
The Coalition can boast four (Kerry Chikarovski, Virginia Chadwick, Anne Cohen and Wendy Machin) while the ALP has only two (Pam Allan and Faye Lo Po).

TALK.START.PARA: —They had to sack the other one.

—They did. We might start at the top. The opposition leader is Mr Bob Carr—he of the quivering lip. Mr Bob Carr is described in this article as `an intellectual carnivore surrounded by vegetarians. His bid for the top job is largely a one-man show.' I think we would all agree that this man has no leadership skills and no personal skills. In the Sydney Morning Herald this week he was described in an article headed, `Getting votes is not child's play'. It stated:

SPEECH.PARA: MIGRATION LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 4) 1995
This bill is substantially the same as the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No 3) 1995 which was introduced into the Senate on 31 January 1995.

That bill was considered by the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee which reported to the Senate on 1 March 1995. A majority of the Committee recommended that the bill be adopted but a number of the Opposition Senators who sat on the Committee dissented and called for a delay in the passage of the bill and for non-specified amendments to it.

This dissenting report of Senators Ellison, O'Chee and Abetz is based upon an inaccurate interpretation of the bill's provisions relating to the scope of the Refugee Convention ground of particular social group.

The Coalition Senators remarked that the bill "seeks to disqualify those who have a well founded fear of persecution just because they are the unfortunate victims of China's fertility control policy". This has never been the intention nor the effect of the bill.

As was made clear in the second reading speech and Explanatory Memorandum to the No 3 bill, the bill will not deny access to our protection to a person who seeks it as a member of a pre-existing social group, or on any of the other Convention grounds, who has a well founded fear of persecution because of fertility control policies.

During the course of the Senate Committee's deliberations some submissions raised doubt about the operation of proposed sections 36(3) and 36(4). Amongst these submissions were those of the President of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, Sir Ronald Wilson. The acting Solicitor-General's advice was obtained by the Government. Following consideration of this advice and the totality of the evidence received by the Committee the Government has drafted amendments which incorporate the abovementioned statements from the second reading speech and the Explanatory Memorandum in the text of the bill.

These amendments will clarify the operation of the bill. Whilst many of the criticisms of the bill have been based on a misunderstanding of its purpose and effect, the Government acknowledges the depth of concern held by many people on the sensitive issue of fertility control policies.

However the bill is not about the merits or otherwise of such policies. It is about the need to protect the integrity and effectiveness of Australia's refugee determination system whilst at all times vigilantly observing our obligations under the Refugees Convention to provide protection to genuine refugees.
The bill has two purposes, both of which relate to the need to protect the integrity and effectiveness of Australia's refugee determination system.

The bill's first purpose is to ensure that the fertility control policies of the government of a foreign country are disregarded in determining if a non-citizen is a member of a particular social group within the meaning of the Refugees Convention as amended by the Refugees Protocol for the purposes of considering an application for a protection visa.

Australia was among the first to sign the Refugees Convention, and the Migration Act and our refugee determination system reflect the seriousness with which we take our obligations under the Convention. The Convention states that a refugee is a person who has a well-founded fear of being persecuted for reasons of race, religion, nationality, political opinion or membership of a particular social group.

Useful though the ground of particular social group undoubtedly is, it is also the most difficult to define in practice. Assessment of whether a claimant is a member of a particular social group is usually left to those who administer and review our refugee determination system. However, the implication of the recent Federal Court judgement that a person may be recognised as a member of a particular social group simply because he or she is a person to whom the fertility control policies of a foreign government apply, or who objects to such policies, has such potentially serious consequences that the Government has decided to introduce the current bill.

The Government considers that the recent judgement dilutes the meaning of the Convention ground of particular social group. The judgement has considerably expanded those who need to be considered by the refugee determination system. Many of the people who would now have to be considered as a result of the judgement are not normally regarded as refugees by other countries. Consequently, the integrity and effectiveness of Australia's refugee determination system is being threatened which will in turn undermine public support for the discharge of Australia's international obligations.

To regard a large proportion of the population of China, or any country, as a social group and therefore as potential refugees simply on the basis of their government's fertility control policies is inconsistent with the intention of the Convention to provide protection to refugees with a well founded fear of persecution. One consequence of the inclusive nature of the Federal Court's decision is likely to be that those refugees who historically have been regarded as in genuine need of protection by Australia, and whose status should be determined quickly, will be disadvantaged as the system will have to deal with an increased number of applicants to whom the Convention was not intended to apply.

In introducing this legislation I emphasise that the Government is not questioning that the Convention ground of particular social group is a useful and necessary concept. Indeed the Government is seeking to bring the application of this concept into line with our international obligations following the recent Federal Court decision.

As I stated earlier this bill will not deny access to our protection to a person who seeks it as a member of a particular pre-existing social group, or on any of the other Convention grounds, who has a well founded fear of persecution because of fertility control policies. What this means is that a person from a particular social group such as a village or workplace who is subjected to the rogue application of a fertility control policy in a manner which amounts to persecution could still have a claim accepted under the legislation introduced today. Nor will a person who is a member of a particular religious, political or racial group subject to the persecutory application of fertility control policies be denied consideration of their claims under this legislation.

The Government is concerned to address issues which might arise from gender based persecution and has been working actively in this area for some time. For instance our Humanitarian Program contains a specific women at risk component which targets resettlement assistance to refugee women in particularly vulnerable situations.

However, the Government is concerned to ensure that the Convention is interpreted correctly. This will ensure the retention of public commitment to our refugee determination system and the integrity and effectiveness of that system. Incorrectly diluting the meaning of particular social group under the Convention has the potential to undermine that public confidence and the ability of our determination system to do the job it was set up to do—to afford protection to genuine refugees.

The legislation introduced today will help provide a common sense approach to the definition of a particular social group under the Convention by precluding the possibility of very large numbers of people with nothing in common but that they may be affected in some way by the fertility control policies of their government being caught within the definition of a social group under the Convention.

The second purpose of the bill introduced today is to prevent a non citizen from making further applications for a protection visa when they have already made an application, whether or not the prior application has been finally determined.

Australia operates one of the most thorough, efficient and equitable refugee determination systems in the world. A person's claim is assessed against the Convention definition of a refugee, and if it is not accepted at the primary stage, the person may appeal to the independent Refugee Review Tribunal which may reverse the primary decision. If a person's claim is still not accepted at the RRT stage, it is open to that person to seek review on administrative law grounds from the Federal Court.

Under current legislation, when a person has exhausted this process, it is not difficult for them to lodge another application for a protection visa and start the whole process again. The fact that repeat applications serve to delay the removal from Australia of the applicant has led to their increased use. The processing of these repeat applications, which like the initial application are free of charge to the applicant, is both expensive and time consuming.

When a system is fair, open and contains the right to appeal the primary decision, claimants will generally have no need to repeat the whole process to get a fair hearing. That fair hearing is amply provided by the system as it exists already. The bill introduced today therefore will have the effect of barring repeat applications in the majority of cases. Its intention in doing so is to protect the integrity of, and support for Australia's refugee determination system and to ensure that available resources are expended on claims for protection which have not yet been exhaustively assessed.

In introducing this bar on repeat applications, the Government is aware that there will remain circumstances in which particular repeat applications may merit consideration. These cases are likely to include repeat applications which contain information which was not available to the claimant during the course of the first application, and which is of a nature that is likely to have a real bearing on the assessment of the need for protection. Events in the country of origin of the claimant that have occurred since the first claim may also mean that a second consideration is warranted. The Government has therefore decided that the Minister will retain a discretion to allow particular repeat applications to be assessed by the full refugee determination process.

Although the Minister's non-compellable discretion may only be exercised by the Minister personally, measures will be taken to ensure that all cases in which the Minister might wish to exercise his or her discretion are identified and brought to the Minister's attention. In such cases the Minister will present to Parliament the reasons for the exercise of his or her discretion.

Both aspects of the bill introduced today demonstrate the Government's resolve to maintain a refugee determination system that is targeted towards those with a claim to Australia's protection under our Refugee Convention obligations. The United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees has estimated that there are some twenty million refugees in the world today. Australia has an obligation to help these people through the most effective means at our disposal. We meet this obligation through our overseas aid program, our assistance to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, our significant contribution to UN peacekeeping initiatives, our Humanitarian Program, which this year will bring 13,000 people in need of resettlement to Australia to begin a new life, and through our on-shore refugee determination system.
When the need arises to defend these efforts and to maintain their credibility, public support and effectiveness, as in the present case, the Government will do so.
I commend this bill to the Senate.
LAND FUND AND INDIGENOUS LAND CORPORATION (ATSIC AMENDMENT) BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: I will come shortly to the events that explain why the Senate is today considering this particular bill, and not the version of the land fund legislation which left this chamber for the other place last week. First, however, I want to remind the Senate briefly of what the bill is about. The central purpose of the bill, put simply, is to restore land to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders who have been dispossessed of their land at various times and in various ways over the 207 years of European settlement of this continent. To do so, the bill establishes a very substantial perpetual fund, and an indigenous land corporation to use and administer that fund.

SPEECH.PARA: The role of the Indigenous Land Corporation (ILC) is to assist indigenous people to acquire and/or manage land "so as to provide economic, environmental, social or cultural benefits for Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders". To pursue those objectives, the ILC will have at its disposal 45 million dollars a year, indexed to preserve current values, as a draw down from the perpetual land fund.

The corporation, which will be under the majority control of indigenous representatives on its board, will develop regional and national strategies to carry out its tasks in a way which will maximise the benefits of the land fund to Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islanders.
The legislation therefore establishes the means by which a substantial portion of the once-complete land base of Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islanders can be restored.
The parliament is now, finally, on the threshold of enacting this measure of pivotal importance to the indigenous people of Australia.

Beyond that, the measure will be a lasting part of the definition of this nation as a polity which is comfortable with its diverse racial and cultural heritage, and will deal justly with all its citizens.

We have reached this point with the Land Fund and Indigenous Land Corporation (ATSIC Amendment) Bill by a somewhat circuitous parliamentary route. The Senate is well aware of the detours upon which it sent the legislation, but for the record I should briefly go through what has happened in both houses of the parliament over the last month of this very long debate.

On 9 February this year, a select committee appointed by this chamber reported its findings on a large number of amendments proposed to a bill which had been extensively debated in both houses through the second half of 1994.

The select committee was unable to reach agreement. A majority, consisting of coalition and green senators, believed that the amendments proposed in this place last November should be pursued, despite acknowledging quite widespread opposition to some of those amendments among indigenous organisations and individuals who appeared before the committee.

The minority, consisting of government and Australian Democrat senators, presented dissenting reports which essentially argued that the committee majority had failed to respond to the messages delivered by witnesses to the inquiry. It was clear to the minority senators on the committee that the best course was to proceed with the government's original legislation, as altered by a number of amendments we on this side had already accepted during the committee stage.

Given the fact that there was no prospect of the Senate agreeing to the bill before it, on 28 February, the Prime Minister introduced a new bill into the House of Representatives. The new bill incorporated 28 amendments to the original legislation—amendments to which the government was prepared to agree—but otherwise followed the form of the original bill.

Our opponents on the issue in this chamber responded by using their numbers to bring on debate on the original bill. The result was that the original legislation, with some 70 amendments made here, was returned to the other place. Many of those amendments were totally unacceptable to the government.

The impasse was resolved two days later when the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) informed the House of Representatives that the coalition parties would support the Prime Minister's new bill. The coalition's undertaking was given grudgingly, and for reasons totally unrelated to any genuine support for the principles or content of the bill: indeed, the Leader of the Opposition has made it clear that if the coalition parties ever get the chance, they will amend it to incorporate all those amendments which the government argues make the bill either unworkable in practice, indefensible in principle, or both.

Nevertheless the undertaking was given. The bill we now have before us is the government's new bill, with one further amendment to which the House of Representatives agreed. That amendment to section 191d(4) will require the Indigenous Land Corporation to search the registers of the National Native Title Tribunal in relation to land being considered for acquisition. Since the Senate agreed last week to insert an identical amendment into the original bill, I assume it will be approved as part of the present bill.

The original bill, with all the Senate's amendments, has been laid aside in the House of Representatives, and will expire when that house is prorogued for an election. So, the decks have finally been cleared for the parliament to approve this great measure of social justice.

I hope the record will ultimately show that the bill was approved unanimously in this chamber as well as in the other place. It's regrettable that the record will not reflect a genuine agreement in principle between all parties, but the passage of the legislation is paramount for the government and for indigenous Australians.

The government had intended that the land fund, and the Indigenous Land Corporation, would be operating on 1 January this year, a starting date which was put out of the question by the parliamentary tactics of coalition and green senators.

Given passage of the bill, the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs will now act as quickly as possible to make appointments to the board of the ILC, so that it can get on with the role assigned to it in the legislation.

All honourable senators are by now very familiar with the scheme of the legislation, so I will not canvass the detail here. Suffice it to say that the government is very pleased that the ILC will now be able to pursue the bill's objectives largely unfettered by the prescriptive constraints and bureaucratic baggage that coalition and green amendments had threatened to impose on it. We can now look forward to a sustained effort to restore to Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islanders something the Prime Minister has described as `that which is most precious to their sense of history and spirituality, that most essential component of their heritage—their land'.

Before concluding, I want to make some reference to the role of the large number of indigenous organisations who took part in the negotiations leading up to, and succeeding, the introduction of the original land fund legislation in June last year.
First, I want to place on record the government's appreciation of the generally helpful and constructive manner in which those organisations contributed to the framing of the bill.
It was obviously going to be a measure of great importance to all indigenous Australians, and the input of those organisations was both necessary and welcome.

Secondly, I want to say specifically that our appreciation extends to indigenous organisations who disagreed—sometimes quite strongly—with aspects of the approach adopted by the government after those consultations.

It is neither a surprising nor a bad thing that there should be differences of opinion between organisations representing such a large range of indigenous people, in terms of their modern lifestyles and priorities as well as the inherent cultural diversity among Aboriginal peoples and Torres Strait Islanders.

At the end of the day, on this as on any other issue, it is the government that must decide, in the national interest, between competing priorities. This we did in the belief, which we still hold, that there is broad support among indigenous Australians for the approach adopted. A significant factor in this belief was the unanimous endorsement of the government's approach by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. Given the propensity of some of those opposite to discount the views of ATSIC, I should state that the government makes no apology whatsoever for giving weight to those views.

ATSIC is, after all, the most broadly representative and most nationally focused indigenous organisation. At the practical level, it has had some years of experience in the type of activity which the ILC will carry out as a result of this bill. Therefore the government did take notice of ATSIC's position on the land fund, as well as carefully considering—and adopting some of—the views put forward by many other organisations.

The result of this process, now that the coalition has abandoned its long campaign to undermine it, is good legislation. It is legislation which carries forward the major commitment of this government which began with the Native Title Act of 1993. It reinforces the Native Title Act by creating the means to return land, and to continue returning land into the indefinite future, to indigenous people who have been dispossessed.

The bill therefore will partially restore the foundation of the traditions and identity of Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islanders. The government trusts that it will be a key to the revitalisation of the culture and heritage of indigenous communities throughout Australia.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
