Debate resumed from 2 March, on motion by Senator O'Chee:
That the Senate take note of the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week at this time I made a number of points about the egg industry. Many of these are also relevant to the pig industry, which this report deals with. One of those matters is the effect of GATT on the importation of products from countries which have health standards far below those of Australia. The Australian Democrats have had concerns expressed to us on this matter by representatives of the chicken meat industry and the egg industry. These concerns are just as valid for pig meat.

PARA.TAB: I know the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Collins, has given assurances that Australia's quarantine inspection procedures are among the best in the world, and I am sure he is doing all he can to ensure that this is the case. I certainly hope he is correct in his belief. I also hope the stringency of these procedures is not affected by any action through GATT to have them seen as a non-tariff barrier. It is certainly a concern to many people in food industries and it is for that reason that I put it on the record here.

This report contains some details of research being funded into a number of projects relating to animal behaviour and animal welfare. There are certainly a number of serious animal welfare problems that are present in piggeries. Unfortunately, attempts by the pig industry, the egg industry and many other animal based industries to address animal welfare concerns such as those which the Democrats and others often raise may also be thwarted by GATT.

Any improvements in conditions for animals in Australia can affect the ability of the industry to compete with products from other countries which have less regard for animal welfare. Attempts to regulate conditions to enhance animal welfare may be seen under GATT as a non-tariff barrier, which would threaten any potential gains in the conditions which animals face. I understand that GATT exemptions currently can apply if an animal is endangered as a species but do not extend to the welfare of animals.

This report details some research into alternative housing systems for pigs. This is welcome. Intensive pig farming is a growth industry and in many ways can be considered similar to battery hens—animals are crowded into very small spaces, allowing little room for pigs to engage in natural behaviour.

Another issue of some importance to the pig industry is the growth in practices such as genetic engineering, which the Australian Democrats have repeatedly expressed concern about in the Senate. It recently came to light that some pork producers are using an injectible, genetically engineered synthetic pig growth hormone. Many people expressed concern that they might be eating pork containing these hormones.

Unfortunately, pork from pigs with these unnatural hormones is not labelled in this way, so there is no way of telling. I know that many pork producers are equally unhappy that those who have not been using hormones on their pigs are not able to indicate this to those consumers who are concerned and suspicious about what might be in their pork.

This is one of those issues where there has been agreement between animal welfare and food producer organisations. The Queensland Pork Producers Organisation, Animal Liberation Queensland, and the Australian Association of Pig Veterinarians all expressed their opposition to the use of this hormone. It highlights the importance of ensuring that consumers have enough information to enable them to make informed choices and to choose products with confidence. Governments must not shirk their responsibilities in this area. The role of regulation should not be discarded due to economic rationalist ideology.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Board of Employment, Education and Training

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 2 March, on motion by Senator Brownhill:
That the Senate take note of the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —I spoke last week on this document—Cultivating the human factor: Employment and skills in Australia's rural industries—and noted that the emphasis in it is entirely on creating jobs in the traditional agri-pastoral industries and creating internationally competitive enterprises. Not unexpectedly, the consequence of this is a declining number of jobs, reduced job security for those who will be employed on a casual basis, lower wages and the further decline of family agri-pastoral businesses and rural towns that support and are supported by these businesses.

PARA.TAB: If the council had any real vision or feel for rural areas, it would know that, while the agri-pastoral enterprise will continue to be important, the towns that are doing well—the ones that are not becoming more beleaguered and dying—are either those which are regional centres, those which have a more diverse economy, often based on tourism and hospitality or are agricultural value added, or those that are attracting a new breed of rural dwellers: those people who specifically move to rural areas as an alternative to city living. These people could be providing services that would otherwise not be available in the rural areas.

Rural centres are those towns which have become or chosen to be administrative and service centres for the inhabitants of a large area. They are usually the locale for rural and administrative services. They are basically rural cities rather than rural towns, with a large portion of the population working in government, legal, financial and other services. They are the sites of rural radio and news services, medical services and higher education, with TAFEs and university extensions. They also provide cultural training—dancing, music, sports and so on—at a level above that of small towns. They are the centre of heavy construction in the region and usually include some light industry. They are the rural `big city', where one can buy from a greater diversity of goods than is available in small towns.

While they can be seen as providing many of the job opportunities available in urban areas and a diversity of employment, there are problems in these areas that are not the same as those in the massive conurbations that are state capitals. Niche marketing may not work in the country, since the niches are not big enough to survive. While many jobs and services may be available, training and experience are often only or primarily available in capital cities. The nature of the job may be subtly, or unsubtly, different from the equivalent job in the city. Jobs may require a far greater amount of out of office work, less specialisation, more general knowledge and better skills at relating to diverse and independent people.

What is needed in these areas is not only ensuring that there is training in all sectors of employment but training that is tailored for work in so-called urban jobs within a rural environment. Also special attention should be given to training and support in so-called non-rural industries that are suited to rural communities, such as electronics repair. Communications systems, including TV and radio antenna work in remote locations, and skills like fabrication of special design antennas for remote receivers and transceivers for both industrial and domestic use, are the sorts of industries ideally suited as light industry in rural communities.

Another area that is overlooked is specifically science based services relating to land based industry. This includes environmental services, biological pest control services, entomology services, and so on. Farmers are not scientifically backward. Australian farmers, especially sheep farmers, are in the forefront in use of science-related breeding technologies. Many farmers understand the value of science. A greater availability of special science services could improve both productivity and sustainability of the land. These areas should also be target areas for regional centres.

While regional centres have a viability of their own, in spite of rural decline, they are too big and too much like cities to attract a great deal of tourism, unless there are major natural attractions close by. But many smaller towns attract tourists precisely because they are small and less like everything else in the ubiquitous, increasingly global `cityscape'. They have character, and this is attractive, as was noted even in the Kelty report. Towns that can capitalise on this are doing much better than those which cannot or do not.

Tourism and hospitality industries are not competitors with traditional rural industry, although smaller, more diverse agrarian operations are more likely to be compatible than mechanised monoculture agribusiness. Local fruit and vegetable sales can supplement more traditional cash crops. Wine, yabbies and more exotic fruits and vegetables feed directly into the hospitality trade, helping to establish a unique cuisine based on local products and seasonal dishes.

In addition, while much maligned, art and artisan based activities result in a range of products that enhance the interests of tourists and travellers, working synergistically with tourism. While the image of country craft shops may be called up, there is significant scope for people wishing to make use of availability of material and lower rental overheads and land and house prices to engage in self-employment. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Agriculture and Resource Management Council of Australia and New Zealand: Third Meeting

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 2 March, on motion by Senator Margetts:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I speak today on the Agriculture and Resource Management Council of Australia and New Zealand report—Third Meeting—Records and Resolutions. The third meeting of the Agriculture and Resource Management Council mainly addressed the drought problem. The report highlights the devastating impact of drought on Australia, on farmers and our economy. There is one mention on page 5, paragraph 6, that some drought relates to the El Nino southern oscillation, or ENSO, which in turn relates to warming. What is not mentioned anywhere is that, therefore, drought may become more common as the planet warms. Even where drought is not more common, CSIRO estimates other problems as the climate becomes less stable and regional climate changes.

PARA.TAB: Although not mentioned in this report, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has made statements accepting this relationship, and the government in this place has also supported motions and made statements accepting this. It is in this light that we should look at the report and the national drought policy, or NDP. Under resolution No. 1, paragraph 4, we see it noted:

SPEECH.PARA: The NDP encourages primary producers to adopt self-reliant approaches in managing risk.

In other words, basically farmers can expect to be left on their own in the case of drought. In practice, we have seen drought relief, but it was not something that came easily. Quite a lot of very strong calling on government had to occur, both in this place and by the public. Even then the government delayed until the extent of the drought and its likely major impact on the economy became apparent.

PARA.TAB: This is consistent with the Prime Minister's public statement on climate change and drought, which put the view that drought and hardship would result from climate change and so were not exceptional. The view was further put that farmers would have to adjust with minimal assistance, because farms that were viable when drought was occasional would no longer be viable and, therefore, should not get emergency support since it was not an emergency but a new reality.

So when government talks about farmers adopting a self-reliant approach, what it means is something equivalent to the economic adjustment we hear of in relation to the citrus and other industries. In other words, it is just a euphemism for allowing those whose farms become marginal to go broke and for their farms to be abandoned. Those who are in a good location in relation to a changed climate will do well, and if land currently unused becomes usable new farms will start.

Before I go on, I would like to make the point strongly that in relation to climate change it is not going to be a change from this to that. It will be continuing change as the planet warms, icecaps melt, vegetative cover alters, and so on. It will involve not only rainfall but also average temperature, growing seasons, distribution of insects, fungi and other fauna, with changes in both pest and disease populations and populations of biological control agents. We have no idea what will be viable where or for how long.

In that context, self-reliance is a problematic idea. Farmers do not have easy access to capital at reasonable rates of interest to pay for change. Banks do not look at risk management as a good thing. They do not require landcare practices. They tend to see a loan for equipment for a big monoculture farm as a better risk than a loan for a farm to diversify into a wide range of products, including agroforestry. They will see possible climate change as making a loan less certain and therefore less attractive. Farmers suffering the first impacts of climate change are those most likely to want to change crops and farming practices, but these are the people in the worst position to do so precisely because they have suffered impacts of climate change.

The Senate in its resolution on drought of 21 September last year noted the need for not only drought relief but also a policy and comprehensive package to assist farmers to adapt to a change in climate. I see no evidence of that here. It was apparently not discussed. Certainly the Agricultural and Resource Management Council can see the need for this. If not, we should definitely inform the council of it and the motion of the Senate on the subject.

I have more to say on this report. Particularly, I am concerned about the failure to give drought relief to some farmers because they slip through the net. This net has very large holes. I mentioned earlier that paragraph 4 says farmers should be self-reliant and welfare issues should be addressed through social security. If this is the policy of government, there are real problems with the application of social security regulations, especially the assets test and unemployment regulations to farmers. I seek leave to continue my remarks.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Agriculture and Resource Management Council of Australia and New Zealand: Fourth Meeting

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 2 March, on motion by Senator Margetts:
That the Senate take note of the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Agriculture and Resource Management Council of Australia and New Zealand report—Fourth Meeting—Records and Resolutions is a report of a meeting following the one I have just spoken on. At this meeting they dealt with many more issues than drought, but I would like to revisit drought briefly. Resolution 1A, paragraph 6, emphasises the principle that drought assistance packages must be targeted only to people in exceptional circumstances. This clearly excludes people where climate is changed and ignores the need for adjustment to long-term climate change. I understand that drought assistance is not supposed to cover these areas, but this would be easier to accept if there were some other package of assistance that addressed these other issues.

PARA.TAB: The council seems to have looked at some of these issues, and conclusions are presented in relation to resolution 1B on pages 9 through 12 which deal with sustainable resource management. The Greens strongly support many of the resolutions, especially paragraph 19f, which calls for an integration of various policies into a dominant approach over a wide range of areas and issues. We do note, however, that there does not seem to be any integration of climate change issues and how they will affect the diverse range of areas; that is, landcare, algal blooms, water quality, rangeland management, desertification, and so on. Surely this integration is needed if things like on-farm risk management, drought preparedness, and so on, are to be other than short-term, ad hoc measures.

I do have some strong reservations about the idea seemingly embraced by the council, seen in resolution 1B paragraphs 2f, 3a, 6a, 6b, 6e and 19e. The idea is that sustainability measures, especially in relation to landcare, should have `performance indicators' relating to an outcome focus. I would have very little problem with this as long as I knew that a farm or station would have the ability to continue without degrading the resource base and to positively rehabilitate damaged areas and improve sustainability. I know that is the sort of outcome farmers talk about when they talk about knowing that their life comes from the land. They have to care for the land. My worry is that outcomes will be couched in pure economic terms at least demanding that the solutions belong to that pervasive set of measures called win-win solutions.

We have nothing against win-win solutions; we often advocate them. We do have problems where the demand for an economic win to be included in every measure means that measures get short shrift when it is thought that they only make a farm more sustainable or they only improve a degraded area without generating a direct and immediate economic return. We strongly support paragraph 9, which says that it is time to shift landcare efforts from awareness raising to implementation and time to examine tax changes in support of this. I have already spoken in here at various times in support of tax changes to eliminate incentives to land clearing, and to not only recognise landcare measures as valid expenses, and therefore tax deductible, but also to provide positive tax incentives to landcare and rehabilitation. This is not only for farmers. Contributions should be made by others as legitimate donations to land and water care, and for uncleared land for preservation as natural heritage.

The Greens favour regional approaches but have some difficulty with many of the programs running under that flag. `Regional approach' for us means getting the community together to look at the potential, and the problems, the area has. It is working out an integrated approach for people to create the sort of life the people want. It does not mean bureaucratic, top-down regional development in the interests of international or other large export-oriented business interests.

We are glad that increasingly, as seen in resolutions 1D and 1E, environmental cleanness is seen as an important economic advantage. I hope this will flow through to tighter regulation of chemical pollutants, especially ogano-halides.

I was distressed that delivery of quarantine and export inspection services was raised as an issue. This often means that somebody is thinking of privatising them. That would be a huge mistake for quarantine services. It appears that the council has rejected any move to take these services out of Commonwealth hands.

As a final comment on this report, I ask senators to notice resolution 2J on page 45. This concerns the ability of Australia, or its constituent states, under GATT or the World Trade Organisation rules to pass sanitary and phyto-sanitary measures, that is, measures to ensure that meat and plants are clean and disease and pest free. Phyto-sanitary refers to plants and sanitary to meat and animal products. It is something that was alluded to by the Democrats today. It is important that, in trying to abide by an international regime, we make sure that we do not actually destroy our own industry.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—

(a)condemns the Government for cutting road funding to Western Australia, especially to national highways, where Western Australia has 25 per cent of the national highway system and yet only receives 7 per cent of the funding;
(b)notes that:

TAB.TAB: (i)Western Australia contributes 10 per cent of federal fuel levies, or $780 million annually, but receives only $150 million from the Commonwealth in return, and
(ii)this lack of funding over the past few years has led to the Eyre Highway being cut for almost a week; and

PARA.TAB: (c)calls on the Government to increase road funding in Western Australia to a figure commensurate with what Western Australia pays in levies and its contribution to national export income.

SPEECH.PARA: Highway 1, the national highway that stretches from Norseman to the South Australian border, is a national disgrace. When Cyclone Bobby crossed that region some fortnight ago, the resultant flood cut off the road from Western Australia to South Australia—indeed, all of the eastern states. Furthermore, it cut the railway line.

PARA.TAB: It took at least eight or nine days for the traffic flow to be restored and that was only for cars. After a few more days it had dried off enough and some trucks were able to get through. Upwards of 300 to 400 trucks, let alone cars, were held up at that point, which is only 20 kilometres east of Norseman.

The Eyre Highway is not a back road of Western Australia, or anywhere for that matter; it is highway one. It is supposedly the only all weather connection between east and west, unless you think an alterative route is through the top end through Kununurra, Katherine and Alice Springs. Anyone who has studied geography at all would know that at this time of the year that road can be flooded. The same cyclone that cut the roads in Western Australia cut the Great Northern Highway. Hopefully, that highway was better prepared for the floods.

The fact that this road was cut off did not raise a whimper in this place whatsoever and it did not raise a whimper in the other place either. That is because it is in Western Australia and away from the eye and anything that this government thinks is important. The government has done nothing about it. The fact that the railway line was cut for two weeks did not rate a mention with members of the government in this place or the other place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!
—Senator McKiernan can point out when.
—A question to Minister Schacht.

—You will get your chance. The railway line has been cut off for nearly a fortnight. The engineers have told us that it will be off for another 10 days. That was of no concern to the government either. If it has been mentioned in this or the other place no concerns have been raised.

PARA.TAB: What has Mr Brereton had to say in relation to this fiasco? He has said absolutely nothing. He did not have the decency to ring the Minister for Transport in Western Australia to find out what was going on, let alone offer any help. We are talking about a national highway. He did not ring the minister in Western Australia and he did not ring his department. If he does not want to talk to the National Party minister in Western Australia, he could have rung his department to get it to offer some help. Nothing like that has been done. That is the situation in Western Australia. That is the importance Mr Brereton places on that national highway. That is the importance he places on trade between east and west. Western Australia produces 25 per cent of Australia's export income. We know where Mr Brereton's feelings lie.

In the last two weeks Senator Schacht has been having a run on small business. With all the talk this week about small business he has failed to tell us what experience he has had in small business. He has not told us anything whatsoever. With his workings in the Labor Party of South Australia over the years he has helped large businesses become small businesses.

This government has not attached any importance to the cutting of the link to Western Australia. The trucks were held up and they had supplies that were needed in the west. Commerce flows both ways on that link. Livestock was amongst those supplies that were held up. There were a few medical problems. One pregnant woman had to be airlifted out. This government sat on its hands and did nothing at all.

Thirty per cent of freight east-west goes by road and a certain amount goes by sea. The rest goes by rail, which, of course, is already out. I suppose you could ask me why I blame this government for an act of God, or an act of nature or whatever when Cyclone Bobby cut that road off. But, in relation to this national highway, the blame lies squarely on this government, which has not provided the suitable funds for that.

We were supposed to have had a top highway that was town free and dust free by 1992, if I remember rightly. I suppose you can forget its being town free because the bypasses do not seem to be quite as popular anymore. In other words, the dust-free road was wide enough so that trucks and cars could pass without ever having to go off the gravel and therefore creating dust which could lead to accidents. That was how the situation was supposed to be by 1992 when I was in local government.

There is still 400 kilometres to be done to the Eyre Highway, needing another $100 million to bring it up to an all-weather road. At present, where the trouble occurred, the Main Roads Department is working on constructing 16 kilometres of road. Sixteen kilometres goes into 400 kilometres a lot of times. That 16 kilometres is costing $4.6 million. So that is the basis on which that $100 million is required to get that all-important road up to scratch.

The other day in taking note of an answer—and now I remember when it was that Senator Schacht mentioned this—I said that blame has been on the WA Main Roads Department for ripping up the road and so much of a section altogether. The blame is on it, but the point is that it has been so short of funds. It is not able to use the good engineering factor, especially with those roads where there is plenty of land for constructing a new highway approximate to the other one and, when it is finished, just cutting the two ends over, as they used to do on the highway when I used to travel on it. Senator Foreman no doubt has travelled a lot on that highway on the South Australian side, and he would know. It costs 30 per cent more to construct the road along the side and then to cut it in. But the old one is not wasted altogether because parts of it become tourist bays and truck bays for drivers of trucks and cars to pull off and have a rest. So that is why the WA Main Roads Department had to rip up the whole section and try to work on the whole section.

You might blame the department for doing 16 kilometres at the time, but 20 metres is enough when you cut a highway and have no alternate road. If the Hume Highway had received the same treatment from a cyclone, I bet there would not have been such a lack of action by Minister Brereton in providing some relief, especially in trying to trump the New South Wales state government or something like that. But the Hume Highway has an alternate highway, whereas the Eyre Highway does not. So that is the reason those 16 kilometres were being done. An extra $1.5 million on that project alone could have had the bypass road in. As I pointed out the other day, that is the standard practice of doing pipelines—constructing a new one alongside and then cutting them in at each end. You may blame the cyclone, but the lack of funding over the years to Western Australia and the government neglecting its own national highway have led to the whole state of the road being down.

You must also remember, Mr Deputy President, that the Western Australian side of the Eyre Highway, as a whole, was constructed by the state government of Western Australia through its Main Roads Department before the national highway system came into being. The South Australian side was constructed later. I think we had a Premier named Playford at that time. We, from Western Australia, were telling him to get on with his side of the highway so that we would have an all-bitumen road through, but he took it upon himself to wait until the federal government paid for it. That is why it is far better, as those who have travelled along it would know. In that way alone, the federal government owes plenty. For that reason, Western Australia did not get it. We need the funds to do that.

Let us now look at rail. Rail has been cut for a fortnight already. Today's newspapers tell us that it will be at least another 10 days before rail will be moving again. But what has not been taken account of is the fact that studies have shown that the main floods further up due to Cyclone Bobby have not reached where the railway line is cut. When they hit in 10 days time, even if the line is fixed it will go out of action again. So the state government has to make up its mind whether it will wait till the floods go down to fix it up or try to hop in quickly and lift it above the flood level. My good friend the Western Australian Minister for Transport, Eric Charlton, told me this morning that the government is sending a lot of equipment to that area hopefully to do something before it is flooded.

There is also national railway line across there. Where is the National Rail Corporation? It was supposed to upgrade this line under the One Nation statement of quite a few years ago. What has the government been doing in relation to that? It should have at least been keeping the line up and running. If both of the lines cannot be kept open, we should ensure that at least one avenue to Western Australia remains open all the time.

There is no alternative route, as I said. That is the only way from east to west. You have the road and rail fairly close together. This government must stand condemned for not doing something far before now. It may say these types of floods occur every 50 to 100 years, but Australia must consider its defence. If something untoward were happening in Western Australia, land transport of forces would be completely locked out as an option. As I said, if a cyclone cuts the Eyre Highway, the other one further up is likely to be cut also.

The cut in funding to Western Australia has been immense. Western Australia has 25 per cent of national roads. I am talking about national highways—nothing else. We have 25 per cent, yet we get only seven per cent of this government's funding. That is all we get. Senator McKiernan can grin as much as he likes but can he explain why the federal government and Mr Brereton have neglected Western Australia for so many years? All this government is interested in is allocating funds for national highways on the basis of vehicle movement. It does not allow for the heavy volume of traffic as far as the big rigs are concerned. The government does not look at that. It simply looks at traffic movement. Although that highway has plenty of trucks running backwards and forwards, it is down on car volume compared with Sydney and Melbourne and that is why Western Australia's funds are down. That is all the government is interested in.

I move on to some other material I have with me. To the shame of the federal government, at the latest count it collects $10 billion annually in fuel excise and, of this, only $780 million goes to Western Australia. With the six per cent increase in the fuel levy in the last 12 months, Western Australia's contribution will now be $1 billion. What goes back west? A miserable $150 million. That is all Western Australia will get. That figure was stretched to $160 million a couple of years ago, but it has certainly been brought back. We have 4,650 kilometres of national highway in Western Australia, or 25 per cent of that network, yet we get back only seven per cent of the funds collected from fuel excise. When we compare that seven per cent we currently get with the 11.7 per cent we got in 1985-86, we see that this Labor government has been cutting back immensely on Western Australia's funds.

I would like to compare the funding the federal government gives to Western Australia with what it gives to the rest of Australia. In total, $150-odd million goes to the west. Looking at the national highway allocation—it does not go on anything else—and at the federal dollars per kilometre figure, in all of Australia $44,400 per kilometre goes on roads. Western Australia allocates $12,500 per kilometre—one quarter of the sum allocated to Australia. You might say that the Western Australian government is not doing the right thing. It is. All over Australia the states spend an average of $2,300 per kilometre and Western Australia—vast state as it is—spends $2,210. Overall, Western Australia is up with everything the state governments do but in federal government funding we are miles behind anyone else. I could read out figures for all the other states that are far greater than Western Australia's but I would only be wasting the Senate's time.
When it comes to federal highways, in Western Australia

SPEECH.PARA: we are getting a quarter of the money per kilometre that we should have. The Eyre Highway is the only connection between east and west. This government should stand condemned for holding up the 1,500 people who were stranded, the thousands of tonnes of rotting produce that was travelling either way, the livestock and all the people who were inconvenienced. I look forward to a big increase in road funding for Western Australia in the coming budget. Western Australian senators will stand condemned if they do not back me up.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened with great interest to Senator Panizza—and I was not smiling, incidentally, Senator Panizza; I was grimacing—
—I was smiling.
—Senator Panizza has a tendency to do that to people, Senator Faulkner. I listened with great interest to Senator Panizza's arguments this afternoon as to why the government ought to be con

SPEECH.PARA: demned for cutting road funds to Western Australia. I was never given the evidence as to why. Where has it been cut and what has it been cut from? What base years does a person use to measure road funding in Australia or to any given state? I have seen some figures that were issued in Western Australia pretty recently which took into account some special funding programs and which were mentioned in Senator Panizza's motion to take note last Monday when this issue was raised in the Senate. I am glad that Senator Panizza acknowledges that I was again correct in my interjections.

PARA.TAB: I refer to the black spots special funding. Special funding on top of the normal funding does not mean that, when that special funding is not continued later on, it is a cut. We are fudging things if we are using figures like that. I am not saying Senator Panizza was fudging things, because he did not use the figures. Other figures that I have seen back in my own state of Western Australia relate to different years and different road funding programs. One that comes to mind particularly is the Bicentennial projects funding that led up to 1988, Australia's Bicentenary. Additional special funding was given in the years leading up to 1988 but they are taken into account in some sectors of the community in order to compare funding between a given year—fudging the figures. Why do you want to fudge the figures? I would join with Senator Panizza and any other Western Australian senator from anywhere in the chamber in calling for additional funding for roads. There is a need for it in certain sections. But at the same time I would want additional funding for public transport, to take the pressures off the roads.

I refer again to my own state of Western Australia. One of the things the state Labor administration did when it came to office in 1983 was open up, again, the Fremantle to Perth railway to take pressure off the roads. Not only did it open up the railway, it also extended the railway into the northern suburbs. I do not know whether Senator Panizza has ever been into the northern suburbs of Perth, perhaps the most beautiful part of Perth, but if he has he would have seen for himself how efficient that system is. It is actually, to the best of my knowledge, making money for the current government. Not only did the state administration do that, but it also electrified the railway system within central Perth.

TALK.START.PARA: —And he's never been there to see it.

—I am not making that assertion. I am not aware of whether or not he has been. I have never seen him in Wanneroo or the northern suburbs. I have never even seen it reported in the media that he has been to Wanneroo and the northern suburbs.
—Were you at the Anzac Day service last year in Wanneroo? I was.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—Order!

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I perhaps provoked some of those interjections myself and I apologise. I come back to the motion before the chamber. Senator Panizza is clearly wrong when he asserts that the Eyre Highway was closed last week because of a lack of federal road funding. The reason the Eyre Highway was closed last week was that we had a cyclone cross the coast of Western Australia and cross it at a point much lower down than it normally does. Subsequently, as it was dying out the cyclone went further inland and dropped more water on the inland, which in turn then ran out. On its way to the sea it ran over the railway line and ran over the coast.
—An unusual climatic event.

—It is not the first time it has happened. In my question to Senator Schacht on Monday of this week I made the point that it was the second time I am aware of that the Eyre Highway had been closed because of floods in the 25 years I have been in Australia. It has been cut before for exactly the same reason—a cyclone which, as it was blowing itself out, dumped huge volumes of water into inland Australia. That water sought to get away somewhere and it went across the Eyre Highway and stopped use of the road.

PARA.TAB: Another unfortunate event occurred last week. The Main Roads Department of Western Australia was actually spending some Commonwealth funds on the upgrading of the Eyre Highway. I am not going to criticise the Main Roads Department of Western Australia for doing that because the funds were allocated for that job. Others have criticised it in the media, but I am not going to because the department was doing the right thing. It was unfortunate for the department that its upgrading of the Eyre Highway occurred at a point in time when this water from Cyclone Bobby was heading down the coast—down to your part of the world, Senator Crane—to exit into the sea.

What amounts of Commonwealth funds are spent on the Eyre Highway? Since 1989, just six years ago, $60 million of Commonwealth funds have gone towards the reconstruction work being undertaken to improve the geometry, the width and the pavement condition of the road, much of which is up to 30 years old, as Senator Panizza quite graphically explained in his contribution, which preceded mine. The unseasonable and unpredictable weather conditions that resulted in the closure of road and rail links are very unfortunate. They were, as Senator Panizza has described, a natural phenomenon or—he might want to believe it more than me—an act of God. Whatever it was, it was unfortunate and some trucks carrying foodstuffs were delayed on that road.

It is not the first time this has happened in Australia on the Eyre Highway. I suggest that it will not be the last time. It will not be the last time it will happen on the Eyre Highway and it will not be the last time it will happen in other parts of Australia.

We can build and plan for events such as these. I recall in the mid-1980s the Hon. Peter Morris opening a bridge in the Kimberley region of Western Australia when he was the Minister for Transport in the Hawke government. In opening the bridge, he commented that the bridge was built to take the 100-year flood. One week after the minister opened the bridge to take the 100-year flood, the 100-year flood came. It was bigger than was predicted. The bridge that was built to withstand the 100-year flood was not there when the flood disappeared.

How does one plan for these things? That planning was with the Main Roads Department of Western Australia, which has a reputation surpassed by none of the other road authorities throughout Australia. It has a very good reputation for building and maintaining the road system in Western Australia. It participated in that planning for the 100-year flood in the Kimberley region. The flood turned out to be perhaps a 200-year flood. We did not have a bridge that was built to withstand a 200-year flood. Perhaps we could spend the allocation of funds that are now going to the Eyre Highway on building bridges all the way across it. We will then make sure that when the flood comes, which will inevitably come at some time in the future, water will go under the road rather than do what it did last week and the week before, which was cut road links.

I want to develop my argument about the road system generally. I notice that the motion we are debating talks about road funding. It does not mention anywhere funding for rail, which Senator Panizza mentioned. My preparation for my contribution to the debate did not take into account that perhaps the Senate might be discussing rail funding throughout Australia as well. I apologise if I am letting Senator Panizza down and not responding to his comments in that respect.

The Western Australian government and the Minister for Transport in Western Australia were mentioned during Senator Panizza's contribution to the debate. It is worth while putting on the record that, to the best of my knowledge, no specific request has been made to the Commonwealth for major improvements to the Eyre Highway in recent years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, come on! They're in there all the time.
—If Senator Panizza has the evidence, he should lay it down.
—That would be consistent with their behaviour.

—That is pretty consistent, particularly for Mr Charlton. Last year, the Commonwealth allocated $5.5 million for work on the Eyre Highway, adding to the $60 million, which I mentioned previously, that had been allocated over the previous five years. The only reason the road is being improved at this point of the year is that Commonwealth funds were available. I am happy to record that I have been informed that the Eyre Highway, that major land link between Western Australia and the east of Australia, is now open and there is little or no delay to vehicles travelling in either direction.

PARA.TAB: The damage which occurred to the road is being assessed. Because it is part of the national highway system, funds to meet any additional work will be provided immediately they are requested by Western Australia. As Senator Cook said a moment ago, we might have to wait a number of years before that request for assistance filters through. I hope that the minister in Western Australia and Senator Panizza make the minister aware of the fact that funds will be made available if a request is made. Do not allow him to sit on his hands and not ask for help in this situation.

The federal government has already demonstrated in WA that it is prepared to respond to any of the needs that develop on the national highway by its rapid action to fund the installation of arrester beds and other safety improvements on Greenmount Hill. Greenmount Hill is a vital link to the national road system. It is the link within the environs of Perth. When strangers who come to Perth look at the beautiful hills, they can see the road winding through them. It was the scene of a tragic accident—it could have been devastating—a couple of years ago.

The Commonwealth gave the state government $2.64 million to install those new arrester beds in order to avoid tragedies such as that which we saw at the beginning of last year, I think it was. A truck on its way down the hill—

TALK.START.PARA: —Lost control.

—It lost control. The brakes failed. It wiped out cars. Unfortunately, some people were killed in that accident. Those arrester beds were installed yesterday and are in use. Hopefully, tragic circumstances such as that which I just mentioned will be avoided in the future.

PARA.TAB: As I commented at the beginning of my speech, how do you spend the money? It is worth making the point that, after that tragic accident and after the promise of funding from the Commonwealth to assist in making that road safer not only for the road travellers but also for those people in the shopping centres at the bottom of the hill, the state government in its wisdom went to Britain seeking expert advice on what we in Australia should do with our roads. That advice was available in Australia. There was no need for the state government to go overseas and spend big amounts of money. I do not think the exact cost of the consultant who advised the state government on those arrester beds has been revealed. In my opinion, that was a waste of money. I am certain that that expertise could have been found amongst those very professional people who are employed in the Main Roads Department of Western Australia. Money is precious; taxpayers' dollars are precious. It should not be wasted by going overseas to bring in consultants to do work like this.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like junkets for public servants.

—It was probably was a junket for a public servant or public servants. It was more likely the plural rather than the singular. It really surprised me at the time, considering that those beds had to match Australian conditions. I do not know how a person living on the other side of the world could advise us in that respect. But I am pleased that those arrester beds have been installed and that road is now safer.

PARA.TAB: Another enormous waste of money has been proposed in Western Australia. The state government has proposed to redirect traffic in the central area of Perth, but not by putting a new road in. It wants to cut a huge swathe through the Northbridge region of Perth. The state government wants to sink the road and leave a huge gap on top. It does not want to put a tunnel in; it does not want to put an overpass in. It wants to cut the city in half—even more than it is at the moment—much to the opposition of the local residents and the local business people. I do not believe that the proposal will go ahead in the end.

People complain about the allocation of national funds to states and roads, but that funding is based on an assessment of the relative needs. People can come up with statistics as to how big a state is, how many people are in a state and what different conditions apply from time to time. Obviously, they will seek to use the best arguments and the best statistical reasons they can to try to maximise the funding that is allocated to each individual road system or between the states of Australia.

The system of funding to states maintains and enhances the national highway system. It is not in any way related to the road length or the level of contribution to fuel excise. Suitability of the road for given traffic levels is more fundamentally determinant of road investment needs. This will change substantially over time as major enhancements are completed. For example, in the late 1980s, the expensive sealing of the national highway in WA and other states was undertaken, making the national highway funds for WA higher in those years. It was higher at that time. At that time we were not complaining about the formulas because, under the sharing arrangements, we were probably getting more than we deserved, whatever the formula one used.

There is a campaign going on back in my home state on this very subject called `Fix Australia—fix the roads'. The campaign combines a number of bodies, in particular, the WA government, led by Mr Eric Charlton, the Minister for Transport, who wants to allow, and indeed is allowing in parts of Perth, road trains to go through the metropolitan area. Perth is the only state capital where road trains are allowed or will be allowed to go through. That is a waste of money because metropolitan road systems are not built to carry the length and width of road trains.
Senator Cook interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —We should probably do that. It certainly would be worth looking at.

PARA.TAB: Senator Cook interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. I'll ignore the scurrilousness from that scurrilous minister. If Senator McKiernan wants to talk about road trains in Western Australia, he can tell the truth about them. Eric Charlton is allowing them to go into Kewdale from the major highways and Senator McKiernan knows it.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—Order! There is no point of order, Senator Panizza, and you know that very well.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the point about road trains has been made. It is on the record. The simplistic campaign that is being run in Western Australia `Fix Australia—fix the roads' sends a message that if you were to allocate more money to roads all the problems of Australia would be resolved. Of course that is not going to be the case. It cannot be case. There are many other things that have to be done. It is suggested in a pamphlet that was released prior to a seminar in Subiaco on Friday, 29 April 1994 that by fixing the roads we would not only fix Australia but also cut unemployment, stop the carnage on our road system, cut the cost of living and cut pollution. As I said at the beginning of my contribution this afternoon, I have consistently argued with various ministers for transport for additional road funding for Western Australia.
—You haven't been very successful.

—It is something that I hold dear; it is something I believe in and I have been very successful, as the funding to the Eyre Highway over the last five years will testify. Because of my interest in this subject, I went along to this seminar in Subiaco on 29 April 1994. I was the only Western Australian federal politician at that seminar—the only one.
—I tendered my apologies.

—I know my colleague Senator Christopher Evans tendered his apologies as he was otherwise very busy in other parts of Australia on behalf of his constituents. I put it to you and the chamber that I put my money where my mouth is by attending that seminar. I have shown where I come from on this issue.

PARA.TAB: I have written letters on behalf of many local authorities around Australia—Senator Crane probably has copies because I know some of them have been put around in other places—about the need for additional funds for roads, but they cannot go exclusively to roads. If additional money is found, it has to go into other systems of transport as well. It has to go into public transport not only in the cities but also intra cities, as we did with the One Nation statement last year. Enormous amounts of money—I don't have the figure in my head—went into the rail system right across Australia. That is where we will get value for taxpayers' dollars in the allocation of scarce taxpayers' funds for Australians.

It is not exclusively for roads, and it cannot be exclusively for roads. I am pleased in that respect because, although Senator Panizza's motion talks only about roads, when he made his contribution today he did not talk exclusively about roads; he brought up that very important point of the real link that links eastern Australia and Western Australia. I think the motion before the chamber is pretty appalling and ought to be defeated because it deserves to be defeated.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Panizza presents us today with an interesting motion, but, before I start on the substantive arguments in it, I would like to say that the Greens (WA) believe that we need to plan for the time when there is less petroleum. I have said this on a number of occasions, but the reality is that we are reaching the peak of world petroleum supplies—we are reaching the halfway point. That does not mean that we have not got petroleum left in the world; it means that the petroleum from now on becomes more and more marginal and more and more expensive. We are going to reach a crunch. The longer Australia waits to change and to become less car dependent, the harder the crunch is going to be.

PARA.TAB: Senator Panizza suggests that highway funding should have a more direct relation to the amounts of roads a state has. The more roads, the more funding regardless of use. He then suggests that all funds from fuel should come back as dedicated road funding and/or state export income. One of the first issues here is to notice that since 1990 there has been an agreement to untie funding so that road funding no longer comes through as dedicated road funding. The same amount of money is to be paid to the states, but it is left increasingly to the discretion of the states whether to spend that money or not.

The amount of tied grants going to Western Australia is 7.1 per cent, about $58.1 million. The amount of untied identified arterial road grants for Western Australia is $43.3 million, which actually brings us to 12.5 per cent—slightly less than we would get if money was divided equally between states, and substantially more than we would get if we got a share based on proportion of population. The amount of untied identified local road grants Western Australia receives is $51.5 million, or 15.8 per cent. The total road funding is therefore $153 million, or 10.2 per cent.

It is true that Western Australia is larger than other states. It also has one of the most concentrated populations of any state. Most people live in the Perth metropolitan area and, of those who do not, most live in the south-west corner of the state. There are vast tracts with basically little industry and very few people. There may be roads of great length, but what is the basis for this claim for road funding?

I notice that Senator Panizza mentions the importance of exports. Okay, let us look at exports. As Senator Panizza admitted in another debate, about 90 per cent of Western Australia's wheat travels by rail. Virtually all of its iron ore travels by rail. Woodchips travel by rail. Bauxite and alumina travel by rail. That is the bulk of our primary exports travelling by rail. The land transport development fund put only 4.6 per cent of its funding into rail, yet I do not hear Senator Panizza calling for a greater percentage of rail funding, in spite of the fact that rail funding is more important to our exports than road.

Let us look at roads for a moment. We have got trucks still taking bricks from Perth to Darwin. We have got town after town—Bridgetown, Busselton and Northam—trying to get funding for bypasses, even though bypasses are somewhat of a technofix because they are associated with some of their own problems, especially for smaller towns reliant on people stopping off, and bypasses may siphon off some of that business from them. Bridgetown, Busselton and Northam are trying to get funding for bypasses. Why? Because they are sick to death of all the trucks hooning through their towns. Most of these trucks do not stop, do not give them business and are making their towns dangerous.

When other Greens or I have gone to bypass meetings, everyone expresses distress at the impact truck traffic is having on their town. The two big parties argue about whose fault it is that funding is not available. Northam has been trying to get a bypass for almost 30 years. Someone will say, `Actually, the trucks shouldn't be here at all; the goods should be going by rail' and everyone agrees with that.

What traffic is rural WA mainly getting? We have a steady stream of road trains pouring through towns like Northam, Merredin and Southern Cross—and the Court government is talking about bringing them all the way into Midland. We hear about the needs of country people, but they do not want this volume of trucks running through their town. There is no reason why all this freight does not go by rail. It would be far safer, use a lot less energy, use a lot less space and cost less to maintain. In the south-east towns like Bridgetown, which only have woodchips coming through on rail, ask why other goods, mineral sands and so on, cannot go through on rail instead of driving up the narrow main streets in big trucks.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a reason for that.
—We have been talking recently here about greenhouse policy and a greenhouse response strategy. Rail is a big part of this. So is coastal marine transport.

PARA.TAB: Senator Panizza interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I was wondering perhaps if Senator Panizza wants to hear my contribution or is just wanting to be rude and overspeak it.
—I can hear you.

—Thank you very much. If we do not believe that rail is efficient, consider this: when industries have to decide for themselves where, as with the iron ore industry, they will bear the costs, we see them building rail. They do not build roads and buy a fleet of trucks; they build rail down to the nearest seashore and put their ore on ships.

PARA.TAB: Let us look a bit further at roads. Most people in WA live in Perth. Perth is one of the most car intensive cities on earth. It is worse than Los Angeles in that respect. It has been built as a sprawl—a huge strip of suburb extending along the coast virtually from Two Rocks to Safety Bay. Its public transport is entirely inadequate and the infrastructure costs, including road costs, are huge. So why is there no urban planning to look at this? Why are there no measures to ensure that people are not stuck in situations where they have to drive half an hour to get to work, which becomes an hour or more during rush time?

There is nothing particularly equitable about car use, not in cities, not in the country. In cities, it just locks people into situations where the poorest are pushed to urban fringes, with longer transport lines and poorer services; where they have to depend on older inefficient cars. This is bad ecology, bad economy and bad social justice. If there were a rational transport strategy based on minimising road use, we would all be better off.

I have a few other issues to raise in relation to this motion. Senator Panizza specifically refers to the Eyre Highway and its problems. He makes use of the `fix Australia, fix the roads' propaganda, yet he does not mention the disputes over the way the state government has handled roads, road maintenance and road funding.

I must mention also the funding that the state government is calling for—which I will further mention later—with its 4c per litre levy on fuel. In the particular plan for the use of that, it will not go to regional roads which have been run down; it is planned to go to increasing traffic on urban roads, road widening and more freeways. That is the large part of where this plan for the four per cent levy is going. So the reality is: you pull the heartstrings of the regional centres to get support for this particular levy, but in reality the money is largely going to increase the traffic problem in the urban areas.

The Commonwealth says that, in the 1993-94 financial year, it gave an extra $69.2 million in untied grants for road maintenance and will put in an extra $72.2 million this year. Yet it appears that the state government has not used this money for roads. The state government has also levied, as I have mentioned, its own tax of 4c per litre on fuel. Both the opposition and environment groups note that the fix the roads campaign is funded basically as a political tool to attack federal government and by the road lobby to pursue their vested interests. Environmentalists are less concerned about this than the push to further road funding feeding greater and greater car and long-haul truck use, both of which are major greenhouse culprits, at a time when other options should be and must be pursued.

Senator Panizza calls for more of the consumption tax on fuel to be paid into road funding. Would he like that to be dedicated road funding? Would he be happy to see untied funding tied back to roads? I also wonder whether Senator Panizza would like to see cuts in the federal budget to pay for roads, or whether he would care to propose alternative taxation to replace the petrol taxes in general revenue.

The Greens would like to see more of the petrol tax tied to outlay programs. We have said so and tried to do so in the 1993 budget when the tax fuel hikes were put onto the Senate. We differ from Senator Panizza in that we wanted to see them tied to funding a more rational transport and urban design program to reduce fuel use. This would have supported rail, which is the real form of transport used by WA exporters. It would have supported urban design. It would have reduced state expenses and freed up some of the money spent maintaining urban roads and road infrastructure. Yet we received no support from the coalition on that.

No, the Greens will not support this motion. It is purely regressive. It is a political ploy and it does not recognise the state's role in transport under untied funding arrangements. It ignores the social and environmental costs of our current mode of transport, and is part of the problem—an approach that should have died years ago.

Yes, more money needs to be spent on the transport area, and it would make sense to assure funding through an arrangement like that of the Land Transport Development Trust. But the money should not go into expanding the sorts of things we are doing now. There are urgent needs in relation to transport to change the structure of transport radically and allow us to move people and things with considerably less energy, less pollution and less cost. We can do that while improving the lives of many people, and we should do so, are obliged to do so, under our greenhouse commitment because transport generates a huge portion of the anthropogenic greenhouse emissions.

It will cost money, but will ultimately save money, reduce our dependence on imports and make us far less vulnerable to increases in oil prices that are inevitable, as I said earlier. A crucial and relatively easy project would be to try to eliminate long-haul road transport across the Nullarbor, where it is not necessary, and replace it with rail. Yes, something must be done urgently about transport, but that is something that has little to do with Senator Panizza's motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen A.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion of my colleague Senator Panizza and to congratulate him for bringing it into this place for debate. I am absolutely amazed that any Western Australian, whether it be Senator McKiernan or Senator Margetts, could come in and criticise this motion. Paragraph (b) of the motion states:

SPEECH.PARA: Western Australia contributes 10 per cent of federal fuel levies, or $780 million annually, but receives only $150 million from the Commonwealth in return

We can argue until we are blue in the face about what that money should be spent on, but when we have such a huge discrepancy in terms of the contribution which is collected from that tax, and a tax it is, going back into the state we have to ask ourselves why anybody from the state of Western Australia, where of course Senator Panizza and I come from, would argue against that proposition. I can understand why somebody on this side of the country might say, `Well, that is good for us' and argue that it not be changed, but I am darned if I can understand the proposition that we have just heard from Senator McKiernan and Senator Margetts.

PARA.TAB: As usual, they skirted all around the motion. They talked about a whole range of things. I would welcome a debate on rail, I would welcome a debate on greenhouse gas emissions, and no doubt from time to time they will put up motions and we will debate those particular things. But this motion before the chamber today relates to road funding. I can understand somebody expanding that to how it impacts on their state, and I think that is quite reasonable, but senators in their contributions have wandered all over the place.

I welcome Senator McKiernan's comments about advising our transport minister in Western Australia, Eric Charlton, that there is an offer in terms of the Eyre Highway, but I can assure members of this chamber that one of the very hyperactive members of the current coalition government in Western Australia is Eric Charlton. You can bet your boots that the Hon. Eric Charlton will receive those comments; I will make sure that they are sent to him.

I want to make a comment about the fuel excise. It is a tax on the tyranny of distance. It is a tax on the exporters of this country; in other words, it is a tax on the producers. It is a tax on those people who produce the wealth. It seriously impacts on Australia's ability to compete as a nation. As such, I believe it is a tax that really needs to be revisited, relooked at and redefined. One can understand if the tax was being totally utilised for roads or for the infrastructure of a number of areas, but currently it is not. It has become a milking cow for the federal government. The largest proportion of it—something like 80 per cent—is spent on programs particularly in Melbourne and Sydney. As such, I think that it is very unfair to the wealth producers and those people who live in rural and regional Australia.

I have spoken to Senator Faulkner about incorporating tables in Hansard. The first deals with figures for road funding and the petroleum products excise as they have occurred over the years. The second gives constant 1993-94 figures in dollars. The relevant fact in this incorporation is that, back in 1980-81, 87.9 per cent of the fuel excise that was collected went back into roads. In 1993-94, 12.1 per cent went into roads. The estimate for 1994-95 is 8.7 per cent. In other words, over 90 per cent of funding is being spent on things other than roads. The estimate for 1995-96 is 8.8 per cent, and for 1996-97 it is 8.7 per cent. Those forward estimates are fairly constant.

An interesting figure came about at the time of the 1992-93 election when the federal government decided to use the funds as a political handout. In 1991-92 the funding increased from 17.9 per cent to 22.6 per cent. That is an increase of 4.7 per cent. In my view, the expenditure was totally misused. I seek leave to incorporate the four pages relating to road funding and the petroleum products excise in Hansard. I have previously cleared these documents with Senator Faulkner.
Leave granted.
