TALK.START.PARA: —Now I want to deal with some facts which Senator McKiernan laid on the table. A massive $7.3 billion is collected annually across Australia through federal fuel excise. WA contributes more than 10 per cent to that $780 million, but receives just $150 million from the Commonwealth for road works. Another fact worth noting is that, in the 13 months to August, the federal fuel excise rose by 7c a litre to 33c a litre. The Commonwealth has increased revenue collection by $1.5 billion as a result of the increases, with Western Australia paying an additional $160 million a year. Not one cent of that collection has been returned to the roads.

PARA.TAB: National highway funding is a disgrace. WA is responsible for maintaining 25 per cent of the nation's highway systems. The Commonwealth is responsible for providing the funds. However, WA was allocated a meagre $58 million, or seven per cent of the total national funding pool of $820 million provided by the Commonwealth for highways. WA needs at least an extra $40 million a year in funding to rebuild poor sections of the national highway system to meet the standards set down by the Commonwealth. Yet the government is refusing to put that money back into the roads.

In real terms, Western Australia is receiving $50 million less per annum in Commonwealth funding than the average funding levels of the previous 10 years, yet Western Australia's road assets, which would cost $14 billion to replace, are declining at the alarming rate of $80 million a year. I submit that that is a disgrace when we look at the total funds collected from the fuel excise. I also point out that it is a coincidence that Western Australia provides 25 per cent of the national highway system and 25 per cent of the export income of this nation. That probably fits.

I have no argument with what Senator Margetts said in terms of bulk commodities, such as iron ore and woodchips. What she forgets is that, in terms of smallgoods, livestock, wool and a host of other things, it is far cheaper, more efficient and quicker to transport them by road. Senator Panizza gave us a figure on this in his contribution. He said that 30 per cent of the freight between the east and west is carried by road and 70 per cent is carried by ship or rail. I suggest that that would be the situation in Western Australia. The figure for road freight in Western Australia may be 40 per cent because a lot of areas in Western Australia do not have rail services.

I think someone mentioned shifting bricks from Perth to Darwin. It might surprise some senators—but certainly not the Western Australian senators, except for Senator Margetts—that there does not happen to be a railway line between Perth and Darwin. It would not be economical to build a railway line between Perth and Darwin. When we have to put up with that sort of contribution which is absolute and total nonsense, it makes one wonder why we raise these matters at all.

I will now deal with what I see as a major crisis in Western Australia. I have no doubt that other senators will make a contribution about how it affects their particular states. We have to be careful when people try to delineate between city and country. I will give an example of a city figure. The average daily figure for traffic across the causeway has risen by 20,000 vehicles over the last 15 years to 103,000 vehicles per day. In three decades, traffic over the route is expected to top 130,000 vehicles per day. However, less money is being put back into the system to cope with that increase.

We can criticise the situation as much as we like. Senator McKiernan criticised the proposal through Northbridge, Western Australia. Something has to be worked out. Senator McKiernan did not come up with a better proposal. That situation has been looked at by top engineers in Western Australia. I acknowledge and agree with one thing that Senator McKiernan said. He said that our main roads administration and its application to its task has no peer in Australia. I do not accept his criticism about those people, good as they might be, seeking overseas expertise to be even better. That seems fairly logical to me when you look at the funds that are spent on the road system.

I totally reject the comment of Senator Cook that it was a junket. The members of the Labor Party in Western Australia are the last ones on this earth to talk about junkets. We had 10 years of that before the Court government came to power. At least we now have a state government in Western Australia that has set about reducing the debt of the state.

Let me look at the decline in federal funding to Western Australia in respect of national highways, untied funds and local government allocations. In 1992-93, it was $212.69 million. In 1993-94, it had dropped to $150.74 million, which is a drop of $62 million. In 1994, it stayed about the same at $153.78 million. In fact, it went up by about $3 million. So, in effect, we have seen in the two years following 1992-93 a drop of over $100 million in funding, yet there is an increased task.

Senator Margetts, in her contribution, talked about the funding relative to where the money was going to be spent. But let us tell the whole story. It is true that there is going to be about half the money spent roughly in the region of the metropolitan area of Perth, or in the metropolitan area of Perth if you include the Kwinana Freeway down to Bunbury. There is the Kwinana Freeway, the Fremantle eastern bypass—which has long been called out for by many people—the Burswood road and bridge, Jerretus Street, the completion of the ring-road and the duplication of the Great Eastern Highway from the city to Guildford.

Let us look at the other part of it. None of this is remotely near the city, as was suggested. There is the Derby to Wyndham road. I do not know how many miles that is from Perth, but it would certainly be a couple of thousand miles. There is the Nanutarra-Munjina road, the Bunbury ring-road, the Albany-Lake Grace road, the South Western Highway, the Geraldton bypass and the Perth-Bunbury highway. So when we look at the allocation and the requirement in what is required in Western Australia, we find that there is a balance of approximately the same dollars between the requirements of the metropolitan area and the requirements of Western Australia.

There are a number of other roads—in particular, the national highway system, the Orange route to the Great Eastern Highway, the Great Northern Highway, the Southern Cross-Norseman road—which Senator Panizza would be very interested in—the Newman-Meekatharra road, the Broome-Fitzroy Crossing road and the Halls Creek-Kununurra road. The list goes on. There is Yampire Gorge, Karijini Park, Point Gregory, Kalbarri, et cetera.

So, in dealing with these particular aspects, it is important that, if you come in here to debate these particular things, you actually debate the facts and the figures. We have not seen that from either Senator McKiernan or Senator Margetts in terms of the situation which exists in Western Australia. I acknowledge that Senator McKiernan—and I do have some of his letters, as he said, from some of the shire councils, and I have no doubt that he has some of mine—has sought to get more funding for Western Australia.

I will put another perspective on this in terms of figures. From 1920 to 1960 Western Australia used to receive about 19 per cent of the share in terms of road funding from the Commonwealth. From 1960 to 1970 it dropped to 17.7 per cent. From 1970 to 1995 there has been a steady decline to where it now is under 10 per cent. So whatever way one looks at it and however one analyses these particular figures, one can only come to the conclusion that steadily and very systematically the Commonwealth—particularly this government in the last 10 years, as I quoted the particular figures earlier from the sheet that I incorporated and the documents I tabled—has in the last 10 or 11 years reduced very significantly the contribution to the road systems in Western Australia.

Senator Panizza's motion has an enormous amount of merit. The words set down in this motion have allowed us to debate the way this government has set about, as I said earlier in my contribution, taxing the tyranny of distance, taxing the exporters of this country and taxing their ability to become competitive in international markets. One could go on with these points and put more figures down in relation to this. But, at the end of the day, one can only say that, unless this government—and it will not be here for much longer—starts addressing some of the enormous cost impediments it has put on industry in this county, we will continue to see the sorts of problems we have had with our current account. We will see our gross national product shrink in real terms. We will not have much impact on unemployment, if any. We will see, as was predicted in the papers today, interest rates head up in the housing sector, for example, towards 13 per cent and the flow-on impact that will come onto small business.

I congratulate Senator Panizza for introducing this motion and I condemn the federal government for the way it has treated Western Australia, and probably most states—although I do not have the figures for them. I will listen with interest to other contributions on that. I certainly condemn the government with regard to its funding contribution to the national highway system in Western Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Panizza's motion undoubtedly was triggered by the floods on the Nullarbor. Had those floods not occurred, it is quite possible that we would not be debating this matter this afternoon. I was pleased that, although the motion which we are debating did not mention the cutting of the rail link, Senator Panizza did bring rail into the debate. He indicated that he was concerned about the cutting of the rail link as well as the road link. Both these links to Western Australia have been cut. That, undoubtedly, is a significant problem for people wanting to move between the eastern states and Western Australia.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Democrats have very consistently supported the development of a national transport policy. In that policy there must be, in our view, very heavy emphasis on rail. That is why I was pleased to hear Senator Panizza pick that point up when he spoke to this motion. As well as the emphasis on rail, a national transport policy has to take into account such things as the availability of fuel to drive the transport system over time. It must take into account the externalities of that transport system. I think that most people in this place would believe that there should be a full user pays policy.

It is only by putting the right price signals into the costs of things that one has a proper distribution of resources, including the resource of transport. When one looks at those externalities, one sees the problem of greenhouse gas emissions. That point has already been picked up. One also sees the externalities in relation to deaths and injuries which occur in various transport modes; and the damage to property which occurs through the use of transport of various sorts. That varies considerably between the different modes. I will return to that point in a moment. One must also take into account the longer term consequences of the national transport policy, whatever that policy is. We would certainly be critical of the government for not developing a comprehensive national transport policy. That is the point at which we would share some of Senator Panizza's concerns—although certainly not all.

In listening particularly to Senator Panizza, and later to Senator McKiernan, God came in for quite a beating because the floods were put down to an act of God. I would like to briefly pick up the real possibility that these floods may not be an act of God, but may be very much an act of man. As I have said many times in this place, many of the climatic changes which we have seen in recent years cannot scientifically be put down to greenhouse changes, changes in the composition of the atmosphere leading to greenhouse warming. Nonetheless, many scientists are of the view that the changes we are seeing are at least consistent with what we would expect under a greenhouse phenomenon.

When one looks at the floods in this connection, one observes that there have been very significant increases in the sea temperatures in the Timor Sea. Not just over the last one year but over the last four years one has seen a change in the weather patterns which has led to floods not only on the Nullarbor but down into South Australia during summertime. Typical summertime weather patterns are going right across the continent, from the Kimberleys and down into the eastern part of Western Australia and into South Australia and, at times, including Adelaide. I think some senators in this place will recall that Lake Torrens just north of Port Augusta only a few years ago filled for the first time since European settlement. It filled for the first time in the last 200 years.

The point I want to bring home here to the opposition is that when one raises the issue of greenhouse one finds from the opposition a very consistent opposition to any programs which would effectively tackle greenhouse. Yet we have inherent in this motion from Senator Panizza a suggestion that we need to spend more on addressing perhaps the consequences of greenhouse, namely the flooding of the Nullarbor and the cutting of both the road and the rail link, while ignoring the very thing that he is proposing: an increase in road transport with its consequent increase in the use of fossil fuel—an unnecessary increase in fossil fuel because there are other alternatives. That may indeed exacerbate the very conditions, which will increase the possibility of floods and will make the solutions which he is suggesting untenable.

Returning to the comparison between rail and road, there is no doubt, and I think Senator Margetts mentioned this earlier, that per tonne and per kilometre travelled rail is a great deal more efficient than road transport. A number of examples have already been given of rail transport. In terms of human safety and safety to property, there is abundant evidence that rail is a great deal more gentle in relation to human life and limb and protection of property than road transport. Again, it seems to me and certainly to the Democrats that this emphasis on a linking of the amount of tax raised on fuel to spending on roads is perhaps the wrong way to go. If one sees that rather as something that should be spent more broadly in addressing a broad transport policy, one would have a great deal more sympathy for it.

Indeed, one might observe in passing that the tax paid on the diesel fuel used by the rail system actually finishes up being spent not on the rail system but on subsidising the road system. One might observe also in passing that the way in which rail and road are funded militates very much against the effective and efficient running of the rail system. While roads are paid for out of grants, whether those grants come from general revenue or whether they come from general revenue by way of a moiety from the fuel tax, does not matter. The roads are paid for, and the cost of those roads does not have to be refunded by the road users.

In the case of rail, it must raise revenue by borrowing and the interest on those borrowings has to be repaid. When one looks at the apparent economic costs of rail compared with road, one is forced to the conclusion that the comparison is very difficult to do and the comparison appears to show that rail is much less economically efficient than road, whereas in fact a great deal of that difference relates quite simply to the way in which the two systems are funded.

When one looks broadly at transport, one can find a great number of other areas in which Australia should be spending a lot more than it does at the moment. Somebody earlier—it might have been Senator Crane—talked about taking bricks from Perth to Darwin. Of course, there is no rail link. More importantly, one could observe that there is no rail link between Alice Springs and Darwin. Roughly 1,700 kilometres of roadway must be traversed by heavy road transport because there is no rail link. From the point of view of a national transport system, from the point of view of national security, it would seem to us to make a great deal of sense to spend money to at least complete a rail system which was fast and efficient and which connected all the major centres of population.

I recently travelled by rail between Adelaide and Tailem Bend, which is just the other side of Murray Bridge, because the rail unions in South Australia were absolutely appalled at the conditions under which that main line, which is part of the main line between Adelaide and Melbourne, was operated. I was told—and I have confirmed since—that the last time that track was significantly upgraded in terms of alignment was in 1927. It is a single line which winds its way up through the Adelaide Hills, passes over a point which is almost the highest point in the range, goes from sea level up to the top of the range, and by the time it gets to Murray Bridge it is almost down to sea level again. It is incredibly inefficient and terribly time consuming. Of course, it is an enormous impediment to transport between Adelaide and Melbourne. So that is another area in which we believe a very significant improvement could be made which would go a great deal further to improve the transport system than simply spending more money on roads.

Being in Canberra at the moment, one could reflect on the Sydney-Canberra-Melbourne line and the inefficiencies with respect to both the position of the track—the tortuous nature of that right of way through much of its course—and the slowness of the links.

I mentioned in passing the internalisation of externalities. In relation to road transport, of course, one of the major externalities is the much, much higher rate of accidents, causing both deaths and injuries, on the roads, compared with rail. I have in front of me a summary of the total costs of road accidents in 1988. The figures happen to be very similar to the costs for 1994. They show that the overall cost of road accidents was over $6.1 billion. Unfortunately, I do not have the figures for Western Australia, or figures which are disaggregated by state, but if one were to take into account the population of Western Australia compared with other states, one would have to assume that the cost of road accidents in Western Australia would be about $700 million per year.

It would seem to me eminently sensible for that sort of cost to be borne by those who cause members of the society to expose themselves to that cost—that is, the road users. That is an externality which should be internalised. Again, I come back to the point that to claim that all the money from fuel taxes should be spent on roads is to ignore this major cost which the use of that fuel and the use of the vehicles makes necessary.

It is quite reasonable that that $6.1 billion, which comes out of general revenue but which is imposed on the general revenue by the use of road transport, should also be borne by the users of the road. Why should children, age pensioners who do not drive, those who do not cause the society to have that cost imposed on them, have to pay that out of their general taxes? It should, of course, be paid by the road users. It is an externality and it should be internalised.

I return to the point that we would support a national transport policy. We believe that we do not have a national transport policy. It must be built around rail. It must be a great deal more energy efficient because of the incipient greenhouse effect. Therefore, it needs to look to these more efficient forms of transporting both goods and people. We need to bear in mind in this transport policy the costs of the importation of fossil fuels as long as we are using fossil fuels. That also runs into several billions of dollars. That is an impost on our foreign exchange. All those factors would lead one to adopt a policy rather different from that implied by the motion before us this afternoon from Senator Panizza.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to join my colleagues in supporting Senator Panizza's motion. I do it as an eastern stater. The motion condemns the government for the poor treatment Western Australia has received into relation to road funding. I support the motion because I think the Western Australians are correct, because the same sort of situation applies in my own state of Queensland and because I have responsibility for regional development and infrastructure on behalf of the coalition. This motion, although related to Western Australia, typifies the poor deal that regional Australia has received from this government in relation to the funding of highways and the tax rip-off this government achieves from people who are forced, in many cases because of where they live, to use their vehicles and to use fuel. Therefore, they find themselves contributing far more to the general revenue than people who are fortunate enough to live in the cities.

PARA.TAB: I congratulate Senator Panizza and Senator Crane for raising this matter. It is a matter of very great interest to their state. I also congratulate the Local Government Association of Western Australia and the Western Australian Municipal Association on their campaign to get some justice and equity to road users in their state. They are extending that campaign with the help of local government peak bodies in every other state across the nation. It is a very worthwhile campaign. I congratulate them for it.

The statistics Senator Panizza includes in his motion are both interesting and telling. I have some different sets of statistics which are also interesting. Although the figures do not line up exactly in all instances, because they are for different years and are from different bases, they are interesting. In Western Australia, for example, 143,143 kilometres of roads are open for general traffic: 43,134 of those are sealed; 45,955 are unsealed; some 36,000-odd are formed and another 17,000 are cleared. In the total of Australia, there are 816,369 kilometres of roads open for general traffic. Of that total, only 291,031 kilometres are sealed roads.

The amount paid, according to figures provided to me by the research service, by the various states in the whole of the Commonwealth for petrol and diesel excise is $8,408,800,000 per annum. Western Australia has contributed $1.2 billion towards that total petrol and diesel excise bill. So $1.2 billion comes from Western Australia.

The same set of figures shows that in 1993-94—which was the year I quoted for those receipts—Western Australia received a measly $77.3 million in Commonwealth road funding. In the whole of Australia, Australians paid $8.4 billion in petrol and diesel excise and the Commonwealth paid out $1.014 billion in road funding. So $7 billion out of that petrol and diesel excise just went to the general revenue.

That is unfair to those Australians who, simply because of where they live, have got to use their vehicles more often than others. Those people who have to use their vehicles more and, because they live distant from the capital cities or distant from the ports, require the necessities of life to be transported to them by road have to pay that extra fuel tax which goes straight to the general revenue. It is debilitating to those of us who live in regional Australia. We all pay income tax, the same as everybody else. But, in addition, because we are required to rely on road transport more often, we pay an extra amount to the general revenue. That is simply unfair.

I note in passing that, when this government came to office, fuel excise was about 7c a litre and it is now 33c a litre. When this government came to office most of the excise, or a good percentage of it, was spent on roads. But now under this government the fuel excise is simply just another revenue collector. It is an absolute disgrace for a government which criticised our consumption tax—the GST—so much and told so many lies about it to simply rip off the Australian public with this indirect consumption tax which falls most heavily on those less able to afford it.

I am always distressed to find the Australian Democrats urging the Labor Party on when it comes to taxing those who can least afford to pay. The Democrats want to help the Labor Party all the time to rip more and more taxes off those who live in regional Australia, those who live in the areas which contribute a major proportion of Australia's wealth. The Democrats are on record as proposing that, on top of the 33c a litre fuel tax that the Labor Party has already imposed, there should be put another 17c a litre to make a total fuel tax of about 50c a litre or more. If we could take that off, imagine a boon it would be for people in regional Australia, for people who are required to use their cars and who have to rely on road transport for the basic necessities of life.

Of those figures that I mentioned earlier, it is interesting to note which government is responsible for roads. As we are dealing with Western Australia, I might point out that in Western Australia the federal government has responsibility for 4,634 kilometres of roads, the state government has responsibility for 19,596 kilometres of roads and local authorities have responsibility for 118,820 kilometres of roads. For the whole of Australia, the federal government is responsible for 18,479 kilometres, state governments around the country are responsible for 151,867 kilometres and local governments are responsible for a massive 620,247 kilometres of roads.

According to these statistics, the amount attributed to Western Australia in national highway allocations and untied federal funds was $58.13 million; state, $43.4 million; and local authorities, $51.45 million. Whichever way you look at it, the Commonwealth rips off an enormous amount from road users and gives back very little.

One good thing the Labor Party did, once upon a time, was introduce the black spots program. That came in in 1991. Mr Robert Brown, the then Minister for Land Transport, said that it was `one of the most outstanding programs for road safety that has ever been adopted by any government in Australia'. I agree with him, but what happened to it? The Keating government terminated that program in 1993. That is an absolute disgrace.

I notice that Senator Coulter talked about safety aspects. If some decent amounts of money were spent on the road system, then, as that black spots program proved, you would not have those accidents and there would not be that enormous cost to the Australian public. For every $500,000 spent on the black spots program, one life was saved. Each road fatality costs Australia $631,000 and the black spots program is estimated to have saved 540 lives and saved Australia some $340 million. That black spots program cost only $270 million. We can see that there was a tremendous return for that outlay. Unfortunately, the Labor government terminated that program in June 1993.

That project had other good flow-on effects in the jobs it created, both directly and indirectly. The road sector has the highest employment generating capacity of all sectors which produce a physical product of economic value. Why did the Labor Party, after introducing the program with a lot of fanfare in the 1990 election, drop it? It is because it has no interest in the road users, particularly those road users in regional Australia.

As well as the additional costs of poor roads and the huge fuel excise and the fuel tax that the Labor Party rips off, which debilitates people in regional and rural Australia, there is damage to the vehicles of people in remote and regional Australia caused by the poor condition of our roads. That is a cost which city people do not have to bear. People in the country have to spend much more on repairs and maintenance because of the standard of roads.

The standard of the roads, or their lack of any standard, also makes it more difficult, time consuming and costly to get goods from the farm, the factory and the mine to the ports. That additional cost makes us less competitive in those products which we export overseas. If we are less competitive, we sell less. If we sell less, we earn less. If we earn less, we have fewer jobs. Of course, we have an increasing balance of payments problem and increasing foreign debt. So if we could get some decent roads and get our goods from the productive parts of Australia to the ports easily and more cheaply, it would be much better in all aspects of Australia's interests.

I understand there is legislation that needs to be dealt with at an early date so, much as there are many other things I would like to address on this subject, I will curtail my remarks. In doing so, I simply say to the government that it really should look at the cost of fuel in Australia and at why there is such a wide variation in fuel prices. This has been looked at time and again by any number of inquiries. I see the Labor Party in the New South Wales election promising to do it again. The Labor government does not need more inquiries; it just needs to take some action. Something like terminal grade pricing would be very beneficial. If it could get rid of that Laidley agreement, which was a blackmail attempt, I understand, by the unions to hold Australia to ransom yet again, then it would find that there would be more competition in the petrol distribution network, which would lead to cheaper prices.

I want to indicate that, as the shadow minister for regional development and infrastructure, I am currently looking at the announced direction of the coalition on reinvesting within Australia a portion of the proceeds of privatisation in the linking Australia program that has been announced. That is something where we do want to pour back into infrastructure within Australia some of the proceeds of privatisation—in projects that will give a return to the nation. Major infrastructure projects are the things we are looking at.

I note, in passing, that Senator Coulter was talking about the Darwin to Alice Springs railway. It is probably worth putting on record that I think the Democrats in the South Australian state parliament were a part of the deal with the rotten Labor government back there a few years ago that spent some $850 million on the Myer-REMM office building in Adelaide. It is currently worth, as I understand it, $150 million. So no wonder the State Bank which financed it went broke. The state government spent $850 on it—it is now worth $150 million—but for that $850 million the government could have built the Darwin to Alice Springs railway. That state government at the time was interested, as this government is, only in the flash projects. It was not interested in the real projects that give a return to the nation. So we still do not have that Darwin to Alice Springs railway.

I urge the Senate to support the motion. I think it is a very worthwhile motion and one that, no matter that it relates particularly to Western Australia, all senators should support. I certainly urge the Senate to vote that way.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a brief personal explanation as I claim to have been misrepresented.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very briefly, there are two points of misrepresentation. Firstly, there was a smear against the Democrats. As I was a member of the Democrats in relation to the Myer-REMM development, I know that we were certainly not in any way part of that development or that agreement. Secondly, and more seriously, Senator Ian Macdonald earlier repeated something which he knows to be untrue, and that is in relation to his claim that—

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. This is supposed to be Senator Coulter claiming that he has been misrepresented or accused of something. This is part of the debate. Senator Coulter has had his say. If he wants to enter into the debate, that is fine, but it is not appropriate under this standing order.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—He has been given leave.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the point of order, Mr Deputy President: I have only spoken about six words. I do not think that Senator Macdonald has any right to interject at that point at all.
—There is no point of order. I think you have spoken more than six words, but there is no point of order.

—Senator Macdonald has claimed that we would increase the tax on fuel by some 17c—I think they were his words in the debate a moment ago—but he failed totally to mention that we would remove totally the cost of third party insurance and the—

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Ian Macdonald

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: Senator Coulter obtained leave under standing order 190, which states:

PARA.TAB: By leave of the Senate, a Senator may explain matters of a personal nature, although there is no question before the Senate . . .

INTERJECT.PARA: This cannot come within the definition of a matter of a personal nature. Standing order 191 states:

PARA.TAB: A Senator who has spoken to a question may again be heard, to explain some material part of the Senator's speech which has been misquoted or misunderstood, but shall not introduce any new matter . . .

INTERJECT.PARA: Under either of those standing orders, and I am not quite sure which one Senator Coulter is claiming, he simply is just taking part in the debate. It is not part of the rules. Fine, have a debate some other time, but this is not the time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under standing order 190 or 191, debate is not permitted. I do not think Senator Coulter is debating at the moment. It might have been better to proceed under standing order 191. But he claims to have been misrepresented. He was given leave under standing order 190, so I ask him to proceed. He would aware that no debate is allowed.

—I am certainly aware of that. Senator Ian Macdonald is referring to the fact that he talked about the Democrats and that he did not actually name me. I have frequently enunciated that policy. I did so particularly when I was the leader of the party and it appeared in our Getting to work document. It is that document to which Senator Macdonald referred. Quite clearly, he is referring to me, if not by name, certainly by clear implication. He failed to mention that we would move totally across to the registration of third party insurance so that that increased cost was totally written off against those deductions. That is the point which he fails to mention. He has repeatedly failed to mention it in other debates. It is quite unfair of him to only give one half of the story and, therefore, to misrepresent our position so that he gains some totally unfair and unjustified advantage.

—I also support Senator Panizza and his Western Australian colleagues. It is a very particular Western Australian motion. As Senator Ian Macdonald and other speakers from other states have pointed out quite clearly, it allows us to speak generally on the matter of road funding and the problems in every state and across Australia.

PARA.TAB: Senator Panizza is to be congratulated and endorsed for his motion, because he is showing himself to be an on-the-ground type of politician, particularly when he mentions the Eyre Highway, or highway No. 1. Senator Coulter talked about misrepresentation. Senator Coulter tried to claim that the greenhouse effect is to blame for the destruction of the Eyre Highway. In other words, the cyclone came about because of these new weather patterns resulting from the greenhouse effect. That is a great misrepresentation.

The point Senator Panizza was trying to make—everyone else understood it except Senator Coulter—is that the destruction the cyclone brought upon highway No. 1 was exacerbated by the fact that the road had already deteriorated. The floods that affected that highway exacerbated its destruction. In fact, it is still flooded to this day. There is great concern for the people in those districts in relation to communications and simple day-to-day supplies.

The problem is in every state. Every state can come up with examples of federal highways in deterioration. My state of Victoria is no exception. One can follow the money trail back to the Treasury and the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). While this government collects well over $10 billion in revenue through petroleum taxes, as has been said by previous speakers, it only spends about $800 million or $820 million on road funding. To put that into perspective, since 1992-93—the time that Paul Keating became Prime Minister and took the reins of the Treasury—funding has halved while the collection of excise taxes has increased to the tune of $4 billion to $5 billion. He has halved road funding yet increased excise taxes. Where has that money gone? It has gone straight into consolidated revenue. It is nothing more than a tax grab simply to finance the government's other excessive and wasted expenditure in its budget.

The coalition government—the Fraser government—had a fine record in relation to road funding and excise tax. That was when Ralph Hunt was the minister. He has now left the parliament. Ralph Hunt had a very fine record in relation to road funding. In his year in office—1983-84—road funding was $1.2 billion, yet the revenue collected from petrol was simply $2 billion.

So you can see that in those days it was a direct swap. That was the original purpose of the tax but, of course, it has gone far and wide since then. That is where the particular problem lies in every particular state—that is where the problem lies in Western Australia and in Victoria. I will come to the figures for Victoria, which are looking just as painfully bad as those for Western Australia.

The importance of a good and efficient road system goes without saying. What a good and efficient road system brings to the country is known to all; it is even known to the other side of the House: good roads are good for the environment. You would not think so if you were listening to Senator Coulter's speech. Senator Margetts was a little more moderate, and you would think she would be the extreme green. The extreme green is Senator Coulter.

A good, efficient and high standard highway system is good for the environment because it reduces fuel consumption as well as the concentration levels of exhaust emissions—a pretty basic fact but overlooked or utterly ignored by Senator Coulter. Road achievements that would help achieve these environmental benefits include: removing bottlenecks; upgrading highways; providing bypasses; and coordinating traffic signals. All those types of micro activities would bring about a better environment.

Senator Coulter went a step further by pushing for a more integrated or a bigger rail system at the cost of our road system. That may sound like a very idealistic and proper approach to matters, particularly if you are talking to the Leader of the National Party, Tim Fischer. He is also one who pushes for a more efficient and upgraded rail system.

Senator Coulter should have picked up that all the promises for a more efficient and upgraded rail system made in One Nation were never met. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating), who sees the road system, the highway system, as an evil, on 16 February 1993 said, `To have trucks racing up and down the highways breaking them up and killing people was, of course, something we could not stand.' So in the first One Nation grants he dedicated some $450 million to upgrading the rail system—a fine sentiment.

But they are still waiting for that money—it never arrived. That just about sums up the whole One Nation package. But on this particular point, the Prime Minister's promise to upgrade the rail system never arrived—the $450 million never arrived. So both systems are degraded.

Senator McKiernan, an old unionist, should realise that a good and efficient road system is good for employment. It is estimated that some 96,000 people are directly employed in constructing, maintaining and administering Australia's road system. Road construction ranks equal second out of all the industrial sectors in job creation. For every $1 million spent on roads, it is estimated that an extra 35 jobs are accompanied by the savings of $350,000 in unemployment benefits. So good roads are good for jobs.

Good roads and a good, efficient upgraded road system are, overall, good for the economy. It is estimated that transport reforms would bring about a potential 3.1 per cent increase in GDP if they were implemented in full. Road pricing would add 16 per cent of that 3.1 per cent. So that is the contribution a good and efficient road system would bring to our economy—it would just simply and properly add to the GDP growth in this country.

It is pretty basic economics that, if you can transport your loads on an efficient road system, you will get them to port a lot cheaper and a lot faster. As mentioned by Senator Macdonald, good and efficient roads are good for safety; they are good for lives.

One of the great disappointments with respect to roads was the abolition of the black spots program. As I travel around country Victoria, whenever the subject of roads comes up, the black spots program is inevitably mentioned. It was probably the only kudos the government ever received. Regardless of the fact that the program was brought in under another name—a former minister for roads, Ralph Hunt, a National Party member, brought it in during the Fraser years—it was a good and honourable program and a reaction to a problem. But, sadly, it was abolished. Most people say, `When you get back into government, there is one thing you can do: bring back the black spots program.'

As Senator Macdonald said, for every $500,000 spent on the black spots program one life was saved. Each road fatality costs Australia $631,000. That is a great deal of money. The black spots program is estimated to have saved 540 lives in its short time, at a cost of $340 million. That is the cost of saving those Australian lives in dollar terms, let alone in social and emotional terms. The black spots program cost only $270 million.

To the government's credit, it had originally outlaid $110 million. It increased that figure as it went along because of its success. But enter Paul Keating. The program was abolished in June 1993. I can assure you that when we get into government we—particularly country senators and country representatives—will be pushing very hard for its return. That is one program you can be sure will come back on to the agenda.

I want to give my colleague Senator O'Chee a chance to sum up. He will have a lot to say about the government's very poor and pathetic contribution. If Senator O'Chee bears with me for one moment—there is a great deal of material on the government's failure—I want to include the state of Victoria. We cannot let the Western Australians have it all. I have some very potent figures here in relation to my state of Victoria. I will just run through them very quickly and finish on that note.

I refer to the national highway strategy request from Victoria. That request is that the sum that the Victorian road authority has determined is the sum needed to maintain the national highway infrastructure, which is the responsibility of the federal government, in the state at a level determined to be necessary by the federal government's advisers. It put in a simple request for $221 million in order to maintain the federal highways in Victoria. In return, it received $135.7 million. The federal highways are the only responsibility of this government, yet the Victorian government cannot even get the required funds to maintain them at a level that the federal government advisers want. So it is $85 million short. I think those figures say it all. Victoria is getting just as ripped off as Western Australia is. For that reason I give my full endorsement to Senator Panizza's motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —This motion is a matter of vital importance. The road infrastructure of this country has continued to be eroded by Labor's lack of commitment to spending money on the things that count—spending money on building infrastructure to create jobs and opportunities for Australians. When Senator Panizza brings this motion before the chamber, as he quite correctly has, it is more than just a condemnation of spending on roads. It is a condemnation of the government's failure to spend on investing for the future. That is what the road network of this country is: it is an investment in the future.

PARA.TAB: As we speak, I note that we are on broadcast. This is drivetime in Western Australia. If you are sitting in a traffic jam in Western Australia—tick, tick, tick as the clock goes by—remember one simple fact: you are sitting in a traffic jam because the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Labor government will not allocate funds to maintain Western Australia's road network. That is the simple truth of this matter. The Prime Minister and the Labor government are responsible for the traffic situation in Western Australia.

We have a situation where Western Australia needs an injection of $100 million a year over the next decade to maintain its road network. That is the only way to address the consequence of Labor's failure to properly fund the road network in that state over the last 12 years. But it is not forthcoming from this government because Labor's representatives from Western Australia have what they consider to be more important ways to spend the taxpayers' money.

As an example, let us take one of the ideas brought forward by one of Labor's representatives from Western Australia—someone whom honourable senators would think would have an understanding of the problems with the road network. I am referring to the former Premier of Western Australia, the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence). Dr Carmen Lawrence has come to the parliament with a great reputation. She was made minister responsible for Australia's health. As though there were not enough crying problems with Australia's health, this minister decided to spend over $250,000 on what she calls a safe sex guide—what most of us would call a sick sex guide. That is how the Labor Party seems to find the priorities for public spending in this country: spend money on a sick sex guide instead of spending money on things that count.

I find that a pretty poor performance from a representative of Western Australia. We had another pretty poor performance in this place this afternoon from another representative of Western Australia, Senator McKiernan. He is not going to vote for this motion. His objection to this motion was some sort of rabid nonsense; that he did not like Mr Eric Charlton, the Minister for Transport in Western Australia because he said he was going to drive road trains right into the centre of Perth. What a lot of nonsense!

What Mr Charlton has done—and what the coalition government in Western Australia should be commended for—is run road trains into Kewdale, which is an integrated transport centre, so as to relieve road pressure in the rest of the metropolitan area. In that way a lot of transhipment operations can be centralised, and that is only good for the state. But, of course, Senator McKiernan is not going to vote for it and the Labor Party is not going to vote for it.

Will the Labor Party senators for Western Australia stand up for their state when this motion comes up? I know where they will be. They will be on the other side with the government because they toe the line and they do not represent their state.

My friend and colleague Senator Panizza asked me to make some comments on his behalf in closing this debate, and I certainly intend doing so. The most important of those comments is that Mr Eric Charlton, the National Party member and Minister for Transport, and Mr Richard Court—

TALK.START.PARA: —And a good minister, too.

—He is a very good minister, Senator Boswell. Mr Richard Court is the Liberal Premier—and a good Premier. Those two gentlemen came to Canberra in November, pleading with this federal government to provide more money for roads in Western Australia. What did they get?
—Nothing.

—Nothing—exactly, Senator Abetz. They got short shrift from the Labor Party. Did they find the Western Australian federal Labor parliamentarians supporting them? Of course not! That is why Labor ought to be condemned. The Minister for Finance (Mr Beazley) says that the Great Eastern Highway is a beautiful highway. Mr Beazley should know; he gets to see a lot of it from 38,000 feet. Senator Panizza is a man who drives the highway regularly and he knows the truth.

PARA.TAB: The truth is that the roads in Western Australia are suffering under Labor. The roads in Western Australia are suffering because of this Labor government's failure to prioritise spending in such a way that we get investment for the future. There are many more things that could be said. Honourable senators on this side have presented a very cogent case. Senator McGauran has presented an excellent case.

Of course, the Greens have disappeared, as Senator Abetz reminds me. Senator Chamarette came in and then went out. The issues speak for themselves. The arguments put on this side of the chamber are coherent. There has been no solid argument from the other side. I urge honourable senators to support this motion.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Finance and Public Administration Legislation Committee

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 2 March, on motion by Senator Reid:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to address this report. This report is a result of a supplementary hearing that the Senate ordered to have certain answers provided in relation to the National Media Liaison Service. Most people would be aware that the National Media Liaison Service is referred to as aNiMaLS. The reason for that is that there are many people on this side of the chamber in particular and many journalists throughout this country who are absolutely convinced that the National Media Liaison Service, which spends in excess of $1.5 million worth of taxpayers' funds, is in fact not a liaison service but rather a propaganda machine for Labor Party purposes.

PARA.TAB: The genesis of the supplementary hearings was founded on a Senate resolution because the Senate did not believe that satisfactory answers had been given. Indeed, at the first lot of estimates hearings to do with the National Media Liaison Service the minister present, the Minister for Trade (Senator McMullan), could not even tell the estimates hearing what the budget was. He was asked: what is the total global figure? He did not know; he was unable to tell. If we are to have a Senate estimates committee system that is operative and that does provide for accountability within this country, then we ought to have a minister that is able to provide answers.

The minister on that occasion did not have Mr Epstein, the Director of the National Media Liaison Service, present either. The government, in its usual style, using its numbers, signed a report on the supplementary hearings, but I submit to the Senate that the minority report signed by me and three other colleagues is in fact the more cogent report and deals with the situation very effectively.

First of all, the minority report dealt with the absolute and utter farce of Mr Epstein claiming that he was not the Director of the National Media Liaison Service—he absolutely denied it. He said, `That is not my role. My directory is director of the Ministerial Media Group.'

Our minority report summarises the Hansard. Evidence was clearly provided to the committee which showed that Mr Epstein's employment minister, the Minister for Finance, Kim Beazley, described Mr Epstein as the Director of the National Media Liaison Service. So the minister who employs him got it wrong.

The Minister for Administrative Services, Senator McMullan, who represents the Minister for Finance in this chamber, also got it wrong. The Ministerial Directory got it wrong. The Commonwealth Government Directory got it wrong. The phone book got it wrong. It was absolutely extraordinary that somebody would come before a Senate estimates committee and seek to deny that his role was that of the Director of the National Media Liaison Service.

When Mr Epstein was confronted as to why this error was allowed to come into Mr Beazley's letters, Senator McMullan's letters, and a whole host of documents, he said—this is recorded on page 62 of the Hansard:

SPEECH.PARA: I have attempted on a number of occasions, by telephone, to persuade the people handling the parliament phone book that they have got it wrong.
I then made the comment:
But communication is your expertise, is it not? And you still have not corrected it within two and a half years!
The latest Communications Directory, published February 1995, lists at page 127 `National Media Liaison Service—Director—Mr Epstein, David'. So we have that mistake repeated yet again.

PARA.TAB: One wonders why Mr Epstein wants to deny the fact that he is the Director of the National Media Liaison Service. It is very interesting, when you do a bit of research, because I was wrong when I said that Mr Epstein had 2 1/2 years to fix this up. In fact, it is in excess of 3 1/2 years, or thereabouts.

In response to a question on notice from Senator Alston on 14 November 1991, former Senator Graham Richardson admitted that Mr Epstein was in fact the Director of the National Media Liaison Service. So former Senator Richardson had no compunction about saying that Mr Epstein is the Director of the National Media Liaison Service. Mr Beazley had none, Senator McMullan had none, and all these directories have none. Then, for some reason we have Mr Epstein trying to deny that he is the Director of the National Media Liaison Service.

All I can say is that in my former life as a lawyer I would love to have had such a wealth of evidence to put in front of a jury because I have no doubt what the verdict would have been. It would have been guilty, guilty, guilty on each count of misleading the Senate estimates committee.

The other matter that I want to touch on is the absolute denial by Mr Epstein that the National Media Liaison Service was used for political purposes—categorically denied by him and by the Minister for Administrative Services. In question time today I asked a question of the minister in relation to the ALP Communications Directory, in which Gary Gray, the national secretary, wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: The Communications Directory lists the names, phone numbers . . . of the most influential people in the ALP . . .
He goes on to say:
We hope that the directory assists you in finding your way around the Labor Party . . .
Surprise, surprise, in the index, page 46, who do we find? It is none other than the National Media Liaison Service.

PARA.TAB: So the question is asked: how does the National Media Liaison Service assist people in finding their way around the Australian Labor Party? Why is it that Gary Gray says that this document lists the influential people and bodies within the ALP? It lists the ACTU, state parliamentary members and federal parliamentary members—all people and bodies to do with the Labor Party. Smack bang in the middle on page 46 is the National Media Liaison Service, which the minister was assuring us at a Senate estimates committee was a dinky-di public service completely divorced from Labor Party politics.

Why didn't he have the health department in this directory? Why didn't he have the primary industry department in this directory? Why weren't all the other Public Service agencies referred to in this Labor Party directory? The answer is very simple and very clear: the National Media Liaison Service is used by the Australian Labor Party for its own party political purposes.

Mr Acting Deputy President, you may recall the answer given by Senator McMullan. In typical style, he could not answer the substance of the question, so what did he say? He said, `I wouldn't mind if the Liberal Party put the National Media Liaison Service into its directory,' and then he sat down. A very short answer to avoid the substance of the question!

What did I do? I moved that the Senate take note of that answer and, in response, Senator McMullan then admitted that, in the next issue of the ALP Communications Directory, it had taken out the reference to the National Media Liaison Service because it was an error. It should not have been in there in the first place. If that is the case, it should not be in a Liberal Party directory, either. He was too smart by half with the answers he gave and, I submit, misled the Senate and the people of Australia. The Labor Party has been caught out in relation to the National Media Liaison Service. It is clearly a vehicle for the Australian Labor Party to peddle its propaganda, giving itself a $1.5 million advantage over the Liberal Party. (Time expired)
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.
Debate resumed from 2 March, on motion by Senator Troeth:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Troeth Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commented partly on this report last week, and I would like to conclude my remarks on it tonight. Last week, I was in the process of explaining that political life as such will never appeal to everyone and, therefore, it is extremely unlikely that we will have very large numbers of both men and women stampeding to nominate for election to the federal parliament. I was very interested in the editorial of the Australian Financial Review—

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Chapman)—Senator Troeth, the clerk has drawn my attention to the fact that you have spoken on this report.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, and I sought leave at that stage to continue my remarks.
—But the time allowed for you to speak is up. You can seek leave to continue.
—I seek leave to speak for five minutes.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I was very interested in the editorial of the Australian Financial Review on Tuesday, which brought forward reasons for women not advancing in business management. To my mind the reasons advanced in that report could also be applied to politics. It stated one of those reasons was:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that women, be they at work or elsewhere, put at least as much emphasis on the value of interpersonal relations as on building a successful career.
To build interpersonal relations you obviously need to be with your family and, as we all know, that is not possible all the time in federal politics. The other reason it put forward was:

PARA.TAB: Finally, the chance of women winning their way to the top is heavily constrained by society's view of what constitutes appropriate female and male roles, especially when it comes to looking after children.

SPEECH.PARA: I point out that, although this has changed to some extent in my experience of candidacy in politics, it still has not changed to an enormous extent and women are still constrained by their role in that regard and, therefore, do not particularly look to a career in politics.

PARA.TAB: However, as I said before, the ALP has advocated the use of quotas. The coalition does not support the use of quotas. Without trying to antagonise Senator Crowley too much, I would like to point out that we have selected many women candidates in winnable ALP marginal seats for the next federal election.

TALK.START.PARA: —And they will win them, too.

—The point is, as Senator Abetz correctly points out, that they are winnable seats. It is no use preselecting women for seats that they cannot win. It is a waste of everyone's time if we want to get more women in parliament.

PARA.TAB: There are two winnable seats in Victoria, two winnable seats in South Australia, three winnable seats in New South Wales and two winnable seats in Queensland. Those women who have won preselection for those seats have been identified and encouraged to pursue a career in politics. We have done that without the use of quotas. Similarly to the ALP, we would like to see a better balance of women in parliament. But this is the way we believe it should be done—through identification, encouragement and then preselection of those women from the field of candidates who choose to preselect for that seat. So it is totally open competition.

I do not have any definitive answers as to the most foolproof way of increasing the number of women in parliament, but we need to be continually looking at how far we have come and not stop evaluating ways of achieving our aims. But only by choosing women on merit will they gain the credibility and respect needed to maintain and increase the numbers of women parliamentarians. It is to be hoped that the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters will in the future take a more positive role and, I would hope, make more positive comments in its approach to this very important matter.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are some splendid young people in this country and I wish to take just a moment to mention four of them—three of them young Canberrans—who are going to a music festival in St Petersburg to participate in an international youth music festival, the Virtuosi of the Year 2000 competition, being held in March of this year.

PARA.TAB: It is a very prestigious competition and auditions were called for nationally. Five Australian students were selected as being of sufficient standard to compete. Four of them have taken up the offer, and three of these come from the Canberra School of Music. The festival has attracted students from Russia, the Ukraine, Germany, Holland, Italy, the USA, Finland, Austria, Korea, Japan, and France. So we can be proud, indeed, of these young people, the five who were selected, four of whom will be attending representing Australia to participate and, hopefully, do very well.

The competition is judged by an international jury consisting of prominent musicians from all of the countries competing. John Luxton, who is head of the keyboard department of the Canberra School of Music, has this year been invited to be one of the jurors. We commend him also for his achievement.

The three students from the Canberra School of Music are, firstly, Lachlan Redd, aged 20 years, a pianist in the third year of his Bachelor of Music course, who later this year apparently will be on the ABC's Quest program. Secondly, Judith Hurst, 16 years of age, is a violinist who has done all her music training in the pre-tertiary program of the Canberra School of Music and for many years has been a scholarship holder there; last year she was the runner-up in the national youth concerto competition in Brisbane. Thirdly, Duncan Sutherland, 15 years of age, is a young pianist; he too has been part of the pre-tertiary program for several years and has held scholarships at the Canberra School of Music.

Apart from taking part in the competition in St Petersburg, which begins on 23 March, there will be master classes, which these three students will be able to attend, with prominent Russian musicians. A concert has been organised in one of the famous concert halls in St Petersburg, under the banner of `Young Australian Musicians for the first time in Russia'. Judith Hurst, with her mother, has already left Canberra; I believe that the others leave on 15 March for the competition which begins on 23 March.

I am sure all senators would join with me in wishing these young people well. They are obviously talented. But, in addition to that, you do not get to these sorts of international competitions without an enormous amount of dedication and commitment. Once again, I wish them well and, as I said, I am sure other senators would join with me in doing so, including my colleague Senator McMullan who is also in the chamber at the present time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last evening I had cause to rise in the adjournment debate because of interest in a media statement that I issued on 2 March. I had that statement incorporated into Hansard.

PARA.TAB: There have been some further developments on parts of that statement during today, none the least of which was a story that appeared in the Australian newspaper on page 2, entitled `Senator whips up migration paranoia'. There has also been a statement, I understand, that Senator O'Chee made in the taking note of answers after question time today. I did not hear Senator O'Chee. I was not advised before he spoke that he would be speaking or that he would be mentioning me in his speech. I was in the chamber until close on 3.30 p.m. and he spoke, as I understand it, around about 3.35 p.m. or 3.40 p.m. At that time I was doing a media interview with a radio station in Adelaide, so I did not hear what he had to say—not that I would have, in any case, cancelled the media interview to listen to Senator O'Chee.

But I rise tonight just to perhaps draw attention to the full contents of the press statement that I issued. Senator O'Chee, in the joint statement he issued with the Hon. Helen Sham-Ho, quoted part of a paragraph of the press statement that I issued on 2 March. That, in some way, distorts the complete message that I was putting forward in issuing the press statement. I will read into the record the full paragraph from which Senator O'Chee and the Hon. Helen Sham-Ho have quoted. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: I appreciate that interdiction would be a most serious step to take and should only be considered as a last resort, but the Government will have to consider it if the Bill is lost.
The part that was quoted in the media continues:

I would anticipate that hundreds of thousands of people from China and some other Asian countries will shortly be making plans to get to Australia. They will hear, if they have not already heard, that the numbers are in the Senate to defeat the Bill.

In not quoting the paragraph fully, somewhat of a distortion has been put on the words that I used. When you read the total press statement, it reinforces the view that I have that a distortion has occurred. I started the statement by saying:

Australia will have to consider implementing a policy of interdiction and turning boats around at sea if the Bill relating to China's One Child Policy is defeated. The Bill is currently before the Parliament . . .

I have read those words into the record for the sake of the record. I understand what politics is about. I understand that, from time to time, distortions on statements will occur because it is part of the political game. I do get a bit offended, though, when I am almost accused of being a racist. I really would resent that and would go to great lengths to clear my name. That is the inference and implication in some of the media comments that have been made about my statement.

PARA.TAB: I am surprised, though, that Senator O'Chee went to the lengths that he did yesterday in attempting to whip up a bit of a storm about the content of the statement I issued a week ago. It is not as though the media had not noticed it a week ago. I recall the Canberra Times ran a story on it on Saturday, and both the Australian Associated Press and the West Australian ran a story on it. It took until Wednesday of this week for any further attention to be drawn to it.

On 12 July 1994 in the West Australian—and it was in other newspapers as well around the country; most certainly it was in the Canberra Times—there was a story headed `Boat people "threat" looms'. It was written by Norman Aisbett. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Up to 20,000 ethnic Vietnamese in the southern China city of Bei Hei will present Australia with a big boat people problem, according to Indo-China Refugee Association president Marion Le.

I put it to the Senate that if my comments—the part comment that has been used—are seen in any way to be, in Senator O'Chee's words, `disgusting paranoia' those very same assertions could be directed at Ms Le and the Indo-China Refugee Association. I did not make those assertions at the time. Her words did cause me great fears at the time, but I never said—and I would not even now—that it was disgusting paranoia or even touching on racism.

PARA.TAB: I do not believe the comments that were quoted were the most important comments I put in the press statement. I sought to make a number of points in the press statement. Another one states:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Howard must also act to neutralise the influence that the secretive National Civic Council has on his Party. The NCC influence has already caused his Party to make an embarrassing backdown on the Compensation Bill (Migration Amendment Bill No. 3 [1994]) which was passed this week in the House of Representatives, after it had been defeated in the Senate last year.
I went on further in the statement to say:

Outrageous statements from NCC inspired asylum support groups that distort the aims and objectives of the Bill and Government policy, are further exaggerated and given credence in the media. This further compounds and confuses the signals being sent to Asia. People who want a better life will, in their thousands, maybe tens of thousands, make their way illegally to Australia.

I think that influence of the National Civic Council is of great concern, and has to be of great concern, to all of us in this parliament, not only to members of the Liberal Party. It is enormously strong. Sooner or later it will be fully exposed.

PARA.TAB: Another important point I raised in the press statement was the matter of legal actions and the blocking, as I described it, of the court system by people who have failed to gain refugee status in the first instance because they have an army of lawyers prepared to give them free legal advice. I questioned the availability of free legal representation to illegals from the various legal aid commissions of Australia and I also asked how the legal aid commissions could justify expending very scarce resources on illegals when they continually complain that they have insufficient funds to meet the demands on these resources from Australians who are lawful and legal in the country. I ended my press statement by saying:

SPEECH.PARA: Stopping the illegals landing in the first instance would be one way of solving these problems, but this action should not even be considered—
I repeat: should not even be considered—

until Mr Howard is given an opportunity to put things right in his own Party. If he puts Australia and the Australian taxpayer's interests before those of the illegal boat people, pledges support and passage of the Government's Bill, then the last ditch action of interdiction need not be considered.

I conclude my remarks by commending the opposition and, indeed, Mr Howard—I do not do this very often—for the fact that the revised version of the bill, slightly amended, passed the House of Representatives no later than yesterday afternoon, probably around the same time as I was addressing my remarks in this chamber. I am very pleased on behalf of the taxpayers, particularly of my state of Western Australia, that this has happened. I will not try to score any political points from the fact that it is the second major backdown by the opposition parties on the question of migration legislation.
