TALK.START.PARA: —I too thank my colleagues, especially Senator Woodley and Senator Abetz, for allowing me to take precedence in this debate. I rise tonight to condemn the failure of the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) to properly discharge his duties as first law officer and as a member of parliament. The matter relates to the overturning by the full Family Court of a decision by a single judge on the basis of perceived bias. While the actions of the judge are central to the issue, I do not rise to consider the judge's behaviour or whether it should be considered by this parliament. My concern is the way the matter has been handled by the Attorney-General.

PARA.TAB: It is important to distinguish between a finding of appearance of bias and actual bias. A finding of appearance of bias at law will overturn a decision on the basis that justice must not only be done, but must be seen to be done. The threshold for overturning a decision is therefore the appearance of bias. The question of whether actual bias was displayed need not be addressed. Confidence in the judicial system will be lost if there is a public perception of bias in the courts.

In the particular matter there were four grounds of appeal. Three related to the property matter in dispute but the first ground alleged that the decision of the judge was unsafe and should be set aside as it raised a reasonable apprehension of bias. The appearance of bias was generated because the judge had a serious and close personal relationship with a solicitor who had acted for one of the parties and, while having passed it on to his junior, nonetheless kept a watching brief over the file and took the file back on or about the day after the matter was heard. The full court determined that both the judge and the relevant solicitor had a duty to disclose the relationship to the other party or, as an alternative, the judge should have declined to hear the case.

The full court said that in its opinion the matter raised a question as to the integrity of the judicial process and had caused a miscarriage of justice. It upheld the appeal on the first ground and therefore did not hear evidence in relation to the remaining three. The Attorney was advised of the decision which made it clear that the integrity of the judicial process had been called into question. That is a very serious matter.

There are two questions which should have immediately occurred to the Attorney. The first question is: how serious a matter is this? Could the failure to disclose the relationship be considered misconduct in the constitutional sense? This should occur to the Attorney because, as he would well know, the constitution spells out the process by which any judge of the High Court and any other courts created by parliament can be removed. The constitution does not say that it is up to the Attorney to decide whether any conduct merits the removal of a judge, and it does not say that it is up to the chief justice of any particular court to decide that. It makes it very plain that the decision is one for parliament alone. So the first question the Attorney should have asked himself was not the egocentric, self-important question: am I satisfied that this conduct does not warrant removal? Rather, he should have asked himself: is this behaviour of such a nature that parliament could consider it to be misconduct in the constitutional sense?

The second question is: has this happened only once, or are there more occasions involving this particular judge and this particular solicitor? The conduct concerned has caused considerable disquiet amongst family law practitioners, and that would undoubtedly be quite dramatically exacerbated if there had been more than one occasion. The Attorney, as first law officer of the Commonwealth, has a responsibility to protect the judiciary from unwarranted attacks and to do what he can to maintain the integrity of the judicial system. That responsibility is a heavy one. It should mean that, when a problem arises that has the potential to damage that integrity or the potential to invite attack, he should take whatever steps he properly can to defuse the situation.

But the Attorney failed to consider either of these questions. He had a conversation with the Chief Justice of the Family Court and that was that. I have sought an opinion from Mr Tony Morris QC as to whether the conduct of the judge in question is capable of constituting proved misbehaviour according to the constitution. On the available evidence—bearing in mind that the judge has not presented her case—Mr Morris, in a very comprehensive and detailed opinion, is of the clear view that parliament could conclude that the conduct amounts to misbehaviour. The Attorney should have sought his own advice, which in all likelihood would have been in the affirmative.

An opinion that parliament could find proved misbehaviour of course does not mean that it should or would. I am making no comment in that respect at this time. But, if the Attorney wanted to do all that he could to maintain confidence in the judiciary and to protect the judiciary from damaging criticism, he should have contacted me, Senator Spindler, the Greens and Senator Harradine. He should have alerted us, as the legal spokespersons for those parties, as to what had happened. If we were all of the same view that he came to—namely, that this did not fit into the constitutional sense of misconduct—that would have been the end of the matter. If anyone was of a different view, the Attorney could have at least said that he had done all he could. Such action would have given knowledge and information to members of parliament to consider the exercise of their constitutional duties.

In addition, the Attorney must have known and been able to foresee that members of the profession would be concerned and annoyed at what had happened and that, by just carelessly brushing the matter aside, he was running the risk that pressure would build up in the profession—which of course it has. The impression has been created that he and the Chief Justice think they can have a cosy little chat and decide for themselves whether a judge should be able to keep his or her job. The difficulty that I and others had in getting a copy of the judgment in no way helps dispel the rumour that there was intended to be some sort of cover-up. It all looks very second rate.

The Attorney in his own press release has displayed a devastating failure to understand the issues. The failure to grasp the issues is presumably what led him to make the mistakes. It is infinitely preferable that we judge him a fool rather than being left with the view that he is a knave. His first error was that he said the court concluded that there may have been an apprehension of bias. The Attorney-General of the Commonwealth should be able to read and understand a judgment and should know that the court was categorical in its finding of perceived bias. We have to ask why the Attorney would seek to soften the finding of the court, why he would seek to distort the truth and pretend that the court had found there may have been an appearance of bias rather than stating the truth: namely, the court had found there actually was the appearance of bias and that the judge's failure to disqualify herself led to a miscarriage of justice.

For the Attorney-General to attempt to dilute the clear finding of the full court is disappointing, to say the very least. In the second paragraph of his release, the Attorney-General went on to note that he had been assured by the Chief Justice of the Family Court that he was satisfied that no actual bias was displayed. The clear implication was that, if there was no actual bias, there was no problem. The implication that is sought to be drawn is quite misleading. It is clear that the judge's action in creating an appearance of bias could in itself amount to misconduct. Implying that the judge did nothing wrong is quite misleading.

The issue of actual bias was not before the appeal court. In his statement, the Attorney indicated that he was assured by the chief justice that there was no actual bias displayed. I do not question the necessity for and the desirability of the chief justice making inquiries about this matter and forming an opinion. The chief justice has very kindly outlined for me the inquiries he undertook, which included discussions with the judge in question and examination of material before the appeal judges. In doing so, he came to the view that there was no actual bias. But, since the appearance of bias is what undermines the judicial system, his conclusion in that sense is irrelevant.

Given that the conclusion was reached after what must be termed a superficial inquiry, in which the relevant parties—particularly the appellant—did not have the opportunity to present their case or to test the evidence, it concerns me that the statement was relied on by the Attorney, was repeated by the Attorney in his press release and will therefore be relied upon by the public at large as a statement of fact. The truth is that the Attorney could not possibly know for himself. In any event, the question of actual bias misses the point.

The final two paragraphs of the Attorney's statement offer nothing to support the integrity of this system. He invites me to make the same error he did: simply speak to the chief justice and accept without question whatever he tells me. He then goes on to say that the appeal process is the proper way to deal with any misbehaviour by a judge. Of course, it is not the proper way. The appeal process has simply confirmed the judge's error. It has put the parties back to square one at great cost. It has done nothing about the judge's mistake other than to recognise and confirm that it happened. The Attorney's response has been inadequate, to say the at least. I repeat: I give the Attorney the courtesy of judging him a fool rather than a knave. I thank my colleagues for letting me proceed ahead of them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Abetz for letting me proceed. For some time last year, I tried to speak in a debate in the Senate on a report which I believed to be quite inadequate in its dealing with some aspects of the world arms trade. Foreign policy generally consists of either reaction to perceived threats or crisis management. During the Cold War, Australia followed the lead of the United States. It regarded the threat of the Soviet Union as paramount and reacted with the United States to crises where the Communist world seemed to be getting an advantage.

PARA.TAB: The policy of the Soviet Union mirrored the policy of the non-Communist states. The same lack of concern applied to the question of what would happen afterwards if the Cold War did not turn into a hot war. During this period, both sides armed themselves and their supporting states. Sometimes the results were both ludicrous and tragic. Ethiopia was a client state of the United States and Somalia was a client state of the Soviet Union. Later, Somalia became a client state of the United States and Ethiopia became a client state of the Soviet Union. The United States and the Soviet Union poured arms into both countries. The tragedy of that is not yet over. Both Ethiopia and Somalia produced food surpluses before they became involved in great power rivalry. Famines in both countries resulted from the massive overload of arms. At least, that was one of the causes.

Local conflicts prevented Ethiopia and Somalia from feeding themselves. The policies of both sides in the Cold War caused massive human suffering, which still continues in the Horn of Africa. It does not make economic sense. The combined profits of all the arms makers are probably much less than the cost to the rest of the world to help people who need help only because they were involved in the Cold War.

Since the Cold War has ended, we have had the Gulf War. Nations whose military potential would be quite low if they had to make their own weapons received arms from both superpower blocs. The Gulf War can be blamed in part for the massive flow of arms into the Middle East. The 10 biggest arms importers in the years immediately before the Gulf War were India, Saudi Arabia, Iraq, Japan, Afghanistan, Turkey, Egypt, Spain, Czechoslovakia and North Korea. Note that four of the 10 biggest importers of arms were in the Middle East.

In 1987-1991, Iraq had the third biggest volume of arms imports. Assume there was a generous profit margin of 50 per cent on the arms supplied. There is no accurate estimate of the cost of the Gulf War but $US200,000 million is a frequent estimate of property and environmental damage. This is a greater amount than the gross arms sales by the 10 top arms exporters in the five years before that war. That would mean that, for every $1 earned from arms sales to Iraq, $40 was spent on the war. Much of the profit from the arms sales went to the arms dealers. But the cost of the war was a burden on the taxpayers of the countries involved.

Australia supplied Iraq with training aircraft for the military. One would suspect that the cost of operating the three frigates Australia sent did not make up for that. Some of the money Iraq spent on arms was supplied by Kuwait, which wanted Iraq as a proxy to fight Iran. Kuwait lent Iraq money to buy weapons which were used later to invade Kuwait. The United States sold Iraq weapons and then participated in a destructive war to neutralise them. It did not make financial sense or any other kind of sense.

The total sales of arms by the 10 leading exporters in the five years before the war were less in dollar terms than the cost of the Gulf War itself. The arms suppliers made a profit and the rest of the world paid. The long-term cost of arms sales can greatly outweigh the short-term financial benefits. Generally, human lives and suffering do not matter where there is money to be made, but the arms trade does not make sense, even in economic terms.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —My contribution to the adjournment debate tonight is to hopefully have the last word in relation to the allegations made against me by the temporary member for Bass (Mrs Smith). At approximately this time two days ago, Mrs Smith grossly defamed me in the other place. She made outrageous allegations, which were completely and utterly untrue. Twenty-four hours ago, the temporary member for Bass had the decency to apologise for those comments. However, I believe two matters ought to be cleared up in relation to the apology, which is now shown in the Hansard of the House of Representatives.

PARA.TAB: First of all, the member for Bass sought to lay the blame for the information provided to her by the parliamentary information service. I have undertaken inquiries in relation to my register of senators' interests. My changed circumstances were filed in July last year. Anybody can look through the register to obtain information if they firstly see the appropriate officer in this place.

Whilst it is quite clear that the federal member for Bass got her research absolutely and devastatingly wrong, I believe it is highly inappropriate to seek to blame the parliamentary information service for her behaviour the previous day. In seeking to apologise, the member for Bass said:
I made a statement regarding his pecuniary interest in a legal firm in which he had been a part owner and that it may have been in contravention of parliamentary privilege . . .

SPEECH.PARA: It looks as though her capacity to research and read documents is appalling. If she had looked back at the speech she gave only 24 hours before, she would have realised that she gave me no benefit of the doubt. There was no comment that I may have breached—listen to the words of Mrs Smith which come straight from the Hansard:
Senator Abetz . . . made a comment for which he received financial return.
There was no `maybe' about it. It was asserted as a bold fact. Of course, it was a blatant untruth. She then went on to say:
Senator Abetz has committed the worst of all political crimes . . .
There was no suggestion that I may have done so—just a bland statement that I had done so. She then kept on by saying:
I really must say that this is the most appalling abuse of political position that I have encountered so far in my time here.

There was no `may'. There was no suggestion that I may have done that. She asserted all that as being absolute gospel, no ifs or buts. As history now records, everything that the federal member for Bass sought to impute to me was without foundation and was absolutely and utterly wrong. In fact, the evidence had been on the public record for in excess of seven or eight months for her to get it right. Then for her to give this lukewarm apology and try to rewrite the history of 24 hours before, I believe, compounds what she did to me, my family and my colleagues and associates in Tasmania.

PARA.TAB: In this game of politics I do not mind mixing it and matching it with people about their political views or beliefs or arguing that they are wrong in relation to the way they think Australia ought to be run. When we start imputing, and if fact saying, that people are engaging in criminal conduct, one would hope and trust that the research is done very thoroughly and that the facts are got right. Even if it was done in good faith, there ought to be an absolute and unreserved apology.

For her to try to blame the parliamentary information service when the information was available to her, I find to be appalling. To say that she had asserted that I may have contravened my parliamentary position and the trust that the people of Tasmanian had placed in me is, with respect, not reflective of what she had said only 24 hours before. She finished her speech last evening by saying:

SPEECH.PARA: So I stand proudly in the House and offer Senator Abetz my apologies for what I said last night.

For her to say that she still stands proudly in the House despite the hurt and injury that she has occasioned to my name, my professional standing and my parliamentary standing is, I believe, an apology that is simply forced. She knew she got it wrong so she made a grudging apology.

PARA.TAB: In recent times we have seen the Prime Minister of this country make a similar

SPEECH.PARA: allegation against the Leader of the Opposition in relation to this alleged Packer-Howard deal on media ownership. If that were true—and of course it is not—the consequences, I would suggest, are very serious for this country. There was no shred of evidence produced, but the bucket job on the Leader of the Opposition by the Prime Minister continued unabated.

PARA.TAB: Then when the Leader of the Senate was asked by Senator Hill to put up or shut up on the claim, Senator Evans came out with a most distorted conglomeration of bits and pieces that did not even amount to circumstantial evidence. It did not even provide sufficient evidence to convict somebody of a parking ticket offence. It was absolutely outrageous.
When the Labor Party got caught out on that, what did it do? The Prime Minister

SPEECH.PARA: straightaway started to talk about the republic. It seems to me that there has come within the Labor Party a sense of desperation, a sense that it is going to lose the next election unless it can smear and besmirch members of the opposition and accuse them of conduct which clearly, if true, would have been unbecoming and highly inappropriate for a member of parliament.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the matter I was involved in, it was backbencher to backbencher. With the Prime Minister it was leader to leader. It appears as though the Labor Party is embarking upon a campaign of denigration, and I want to bring to the people of Australia tonight the very clear and distinct impression that I have that this is a deliberate campaign designed to denigrate the Liberal Party and the opposition, and to ensure that the public debate gets distracted from the real issues: the high interest rates, the overseas debt, the unemployment, the drought, the lack of road funding in Western Australia—all those other issues that are in fact the real issues. I look forward to getting back to the debate on the real issues that this country faces.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Regional Development, upon notice, on 1 February 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to housing access and affordability:
(1) During the last 3 years, how many studies has the Government commissioned into the development of an accountability framework for the Commonwealth/State Housing Agreement.
(2) What organisations carried out these studies.
(3) What was the cost of these studies.
(4) Could copies of these studies or reports be made available.
(5) Who are the members of the Commonwealth/State steering committee overseeing the development of an accountability framework.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Housing and Regional Development has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) One consultancy on this topic was let in 1994 by the Australian Housing Research Fund (which is jointly funded by the Commonwealth and the States).
(2) Coopers and Lybrand

(4) The Consultancy undertaken by Coopers and Lybrand formed one part of the review of the administrative arrangements being conducted as part of the renegotiation of the Commonwealth/State Housing Agreement (CSHA). The main work of the consultancy involved the preparation of materials to inform Commonwealth and State representatives undertaking a review of existing CSHA arrangements.

These materials formed the basis of a workshop attended by Commonwealth and State officials and the outcomes of this workshop have been incorporated into the ongoing work of officials for Housing Ministers. Papers relating to the Housing Ministers work program have not yet been released, but it is intended that there will be extensive consultation on the details of the new CSHA around the middle of the year.

(5) A number of overlapping working groups involving staff from all States and Territories and the Commonwealth have been working on revisions to the CSHA under the direction of the Chief Executive Officers of Commonwealth, State and Territory Housing Departments/Authorities. As such there is no one group which is working on this aspect of the negotiations.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 9 February 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to Roebuck Bay, south of Broome, Western Australia, which is one of the 5 most important feeding habitats for migratory wading birds in the world and which is listed for protection under the Ramsar Convention:
(1) Is the Minister aware that the Western Australian Government has determined that exploration licences being applied for in and around the Ramsar area can be granted without formal assessment.
(2) What discussions have there been between the State Government and the Commonwealth concerning mineral exploration and mining in Roebuck Bay.
(3) If such discussions have taken place, what has been the Commonwealth's advice.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes, I am aware that such licences occurring within the jurisdiction of the State Government can be granted without formal assessment. I am advised that this is at the discretion of the Western Australian Minister for the Environment, on advice from the Western Australian Environment Protection Authority.

(2) Within my Portfolio, officers of the Australian Nature Conservation Agency (ANCA) have discussed the matter with officers of the Western Australian Department of Conservation and Land Management and the Western Australian Department of Environment Protection. ANCA understands that although final approval for the exploration licences has not yet been given, a condition of the licences is likely to be that the proponents may not carry out any activity of environmental significance without referring proposals for such activities back to the Western Australian Environment Protection Authority for approval. It is at this

ANSWER.PARA: stage that such activities may require formal assessment under State legislation.

PARA.TAB: (3) I am not aware that the Commonwealth Government has provided any formal advice to the Western Australian Government on this issue to date. I am mindful of the very high environmental significance of the Roebuck Bay Ramsar site. It is my intention to make clear to the Western Australian Minister for the Environment the responsibility of the Commonwealth Government to ensure that these values are not compromised by any proposed actions at the site.
